document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence - Reviews
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence - Reviews

Evidence on the surgical management of faecal incontinence - including sacral nerve stimulation, biofeedback and implants.

Surgical Management


Sacral nerve stimulation


Biofeedback


Implants


Other articles of interest




Articles selected on the surgical management of faecal incontinence:

Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewers' Commentary
Methods of repair for obstetric anal sphincter injury (Review) Fernando RJ et al
[Citation]
[PubMed abstract] 		This review highlights the paucity of high quality data available in the assessment of the efficacy of the two primary techniques of external anal sphincter repair. Whilst it does not provide an answer to the debate on as to the best technique for sphincter repair, it highlights the important issues that should be considered when designing future studies comparing the two techniques.
Overlapping compared with end-to-end repair of third- and fourth-degree obstetric anal sphincter tears: a randomized controlled trial Farrell SA et al
[Citation][PubMed abstract] 		This RCT compared two widely used methods for primary repair of acute obstetric anal sphincter injuries. It is the first study to exclusively include only primiparous patients who had complete third or fourth degree tears. It is carefully constructed, executed and reported and provides excellent level 1 evidence. The authors convincingly demonstrate that in this ‘clean’ group, end-to-end repair is associated with a clinically useful reduction in flatal (but not faecal) incontinence. There is a balanced discussion of the literature including the earlier Cochrane review (referenced above) and useful recommendations are made for future practice. This should not be confused with choice of procedure for delayed secondary repair which was not addressed. Essential reading.


Articles selected on sacral nerve stimulation:

Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewers' Commentary
Is sacral neuromodulation for fecal incontinence worthwhile in patients with associated pelvic floor injury? Oom DM et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		This paper is a study that prospectively evaluated the population of female patients considered for SNS as treatment of FI in respect of the presence of US detected pelvic floor deficiency, compared with women who had no US detected pelvic floor deficiency. It uses a relatively new method (US) of detecting pelvic floor deficiency, and determined no difference in the efficacy of SNS between the women with or without detectable pelvic floor defect. The overall study design is that of a prospective inclusion of patients with follow-up through test- and permanent SNS implantation. The efficacy of SNS was determined largely by the number of episodes of FI per week, and it would have been desirable to have more data based on validated scoring systems of FI presented. Nonetheless, the study has great value as it confirms that pelvic floor injury per se has no detectable effect on the outcome from SNS; indeed, women with pelvic floor injury had a higher rate of excellent outcomes than women without such defect.
Infection rates in a large investigational trial of SNS for FI

Wexner SD et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		A multi centre trial involving 120 patients has shown, amongst other things, that if you implant a lump of metal into people some of them will get infected. In this case 13 cases of which four occurred late and resulted in explantation. Most of the early ones were successfully treated with antibiotics and/or drainage.
Six years of experience with sacral nerve stimulation for fecal incontinence. Michelsen HB et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		This paper provides possibly the largest published single centre experience of SNS. Outcomes in terms of functional resullts and complications are inkeeping with previous reports. It is interesting that 25/56 (45%) of initially negative test procedures were subsequently repeated, with 21/25 (85%) subseqently becoming positive with patients going on to permanent implant.The series also describes the outcome of a fairly agressive approach to functional failures with 12/16 (75%) of these patients going on to have reimplantation with a 44% (7/16) success rate.Understanably, long term follow up data is limited with 9% (16/177) and 6% (10/177) of patients reaching 5yrs and 6yrs respectively.
Sacral nerve stimulation for fecal incontinence: results of a 120-patient prospective multicenter study. Wexner SD et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		One of the largest reported series of patients undergoing SNS involving 16 centres in North America and Australia. Outcomes in terms of functional results and complications are inkeeping with previously published series. Interestingly,, the authors report on the initial pool of 285 patients with details as to how the 100 included in the prospective study were derived. The study confirmed sustained significant QoL improvement following the procedure with the longest published follow up of 3 years.


Articles selected on biofeedback / electrical stimulation:

Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewers' Commentary
Triple target treatment (3T) is more effective than biofeedback alone for anal incontinence: the 3T-AI study. Schwandner T et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		The paper is the description of a good-sized multi-centre RCT aimed to compare the efficacy of a new therapeutic concept (medium frequency electrical stimulation plus Biofeedback with Biofeedback alone) in the treatment of FI. In particular, new technologies have enabled patients to carry out this treatment at home and with low morbidity. The methodology of the trial appears overall sound sound, using validated questionnaires to assess the degree of FI. The study is powered to detect a significant difference between baseline continence scores, and end-point scores at nine months. CONSORT type flow-diagram is given. Table 6 appears erroneous and not in line with the data in the flow diagram, or the text. The beneficial effect of the treatment arm of the study has not been demonstratred well due to presentation of statistical significance testing.
The study has an overall high drop-out rate, particularly for the control group, indicating dissatisfaction with the Biofeedback treatment. This differed from a higher proportion of patients who completed the stimulation / biofeedback treatment at 9 months. More patients had full continence in the stimulation / biofeedback arm of the study than in the Biofeedback arm, indicating some value in this treatment.
The study is of value as it reports comparatively good outcomes achieved through a combination treatment in an ambulatory setting. It certainly merits further evaluation of this specific treatment modality (Biofeedback & medium-frequency stimulation).
Biofeedback therapy in fecal incontinence and constipation Enck P et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		This paper is a meta-analysis of randomised-controlled studies on biofeedback treatment (BFT) in faecal incontinence and constipation caused by pelvic floor disorders. It concludes that the benefits of BFT in faecal incontinence remains unproven, with no significant differences between either EMG-BFT compared to non-EMG BFT (4 studies), and BFT compared to other modalities (4 studies). For constipation, EMG-BFT compared with non-EMG BFT shows no difference, but BFT compares favourably to non-BFT treatments. The paper furthermore gives thorough background information on the history and development of BFT, which is a valuable resource in itself. The paper overall is a credible effort to analyse the quantitative effects of BFT across a number of relatively small RCTs, although it does not support the use of BFT in the treatment of faecal incontinence, which has been seen as the prime indication for BFT, and contrasts with large part of the non-RCT evidence.


No articles were selected on implants:

Other studies of interest:

Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewers' Commentary
Perianal injectable bulking agents as treatment for faecal incontinence in adults (Review) Maeda Y et al
[Citation] [Link to full text] 		Whilst it is not possible to draw definitive conclusions for clinical practice from the limited data available and analysed in this study, it nonetheless provides the clinician a basis from which to obtain informed consent from patients when considering this treatment modality in the management of passive faecal incontinence.
Neurogenic bowel management after spinal cord injury: a systematic review of the evidence Krassioukov A et al
[Citation] [Link to abstract] 		This is a thorough up to date review of the evidence for the management of constipation and faecal incontinence in patients with spinal cord injuries. It deserves to be read by all who treat these patients. It emphasises that no one method is best.
Management of fecal incontinence in adults Norton et al[Citation][Link to abstract] This is a review article prepared by the committee for International Consultation on Incontinence. The article documents studies examining the risk factors and places the role of faecal incontinence within the setting of the patient as a whole. It provides a summary of level of evidence and recommendations for research. The levels of evidence are generally poor. However the paper provides a useful resource for clinical practice with a good summary of the treatment options available.
Neurologic fecal Incontinence Wyndaele et al
[Citation] [Link to abstract] 		This is a well written article. It summarises the pathophysiology of incontinence for different neurological lesions and treatment including the surgical options. Tables are provided showing the evidence and results of different surgical options along with complication rates. Once again the levels of evidence in the individual cited papers are poor but they are the only ones available. The article would be easy to use and aid understanding the surgical options available in clinical practice.
Percutaneous tibial nerve stimulation for the treatment of urge fecal incontinence Boyle DJ et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		Interesting, topical paper. Although only level III evidence, this series is prospective with good inclusion and exclusion criteria. Importantly patients with sphincter damage are included. The results on 31 consecutive patients, showed significant reduction in frequency of episodes of urge faecal incontinence, reduction in faecal incontinence scores, and, improved ability to defer defaecation. Whilst more labour intensive than permanent SNS, cost for tibial stimulation are likely to be less. The authors recognise that a randomized, sham-controlled trial alongside SNS is required. Multi-centre recruitment for such a trial may be imminent.
Executive summary: The international consultation on incontinence 2008 – committee on: “dynamic testing”; for urinary of fecal incontinence. Part 3: Anorectal physiology studies Rosier PFWM et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		Whilst this is Level IV evidence, this consensus expert opinion reinforces current views on the validity of the various components measured during “anorectal physiology” studies. Whilst individual biases have crept into this narrative, overall the view appears balanced and with up to date references. Importantly, for the trainee this is an encompassing summary of the available components of anorectal physiology testing. For those proponents of testing, the proposed subdivision of faecal incontinence aetiologies into traumatic, neuropathic, combined, and, idiopathic, (as defined by the Leeds group) is pertinent and in this reviewers opinion key to defining treatment outcomes.
Chronic posterior tibial nerve transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) to treat fecal incontinence (FI). Eléouet M et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		There are now several reports of the use of TENS to stimulate the posterior tibial nerve exploiting acupuncture principles to treat faecal incontinence. This single-arm pilot study of 32 patients demonstrated slight improvement in symptom scores after three months treatment.
Modified dynamic gracilis neosphincter for fecal incontinence: an analysis of functional outcome at a single institution. Hassan MZ et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		Much has been written about dynamic graciloplasty but this study is relatively novel in using external percutaneous low-frequency stimulation together with biofeedback. Thirty-one heterogeneous patients were studied over approximately 14 years with incomplete post-operative assessments. Those with traumatic sphincter injuries appeared to benefit most with results comparable to those with an implantable stimulator. This technique may be more cost-effective.
Anal physiology testing in fecal incontinence: is it of any value? Zutshi M et al
[Citation] [PubMed abstract] 		A retrospective database report on the value of physiology in 53 women undergoing overlapping sphincter repair. Only limited anal manometry and anal canal length were assessed together with continence and quality of life measures. Anal ultrasound was only performed pre-operatively. While mean squeeze anal pressures improved post-operatively, no correlation between pressures and other measures was demonstrated. Anal canal length also increased after sphincter repair but didn’t correlate with symptom improvement. The role of simple anal manometry remains undefined.


References:

1. Fernando RJ, Sultan AHH, Kettle C, Thakar R, Radley S. Methods of repair for obstetric anal sphincter injury. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 3. [This review was edited with unchanged conclusions in February 2010] [Link to abstract]

2. Farrell SA, Gilmour D, Turnbull GK, Schmidt MH, Baskett TF, Flowerdew G, Fanning CA. Overlapping compared with end-to-end repair of third- and fourth-degree obstetric anal sphincter tears: a randomized controlled trial. Obstet Gynecol. 2010 Jul;116(1):16-24. [Link to abstract]

3. Oom DM, Steensma AB, van Lanschot JJ, Schouten WR. Is sacral neuromodulation for fecal incontinence worthwhile in patients with associated pelvic floor injury? Dis Colon Rectum 2010 Apr;53(4):422-7 [Link to abstract]

document.title: 3M Capital Hip System: the lessons learned from an investigation
document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,PROSTHETICS,ARTHROPLASTY,SURGERY,SURGERY,LIMBS,PELVIS & HIP,HIP REPLACEMENT,HIP AND PELVIS]]>
document.description: Information leaflet for people who have been affected by the use of the 3M Capital Hip Joint in total hip replacement operations.
document.body:
Information leaflet prepared by the Clinical Effectiveness Unit of The Royal College of Surgeons of England. It is aimed at people who have been affected by the use of the 3M Capital Hip Joint in total hip replacement operations, particularly those women and men who received Capital Hips and who have taken part in the investigation.


Contents:-

  • The issue: introduction to the 3M Capital Cemented Hip System and its performance.

  • The investigation: about the investigation carried out by The Royal College of Surgeons of England.

  • The findings of the investigation: details of the participants of the investigation and the assessment of performance; results of the patient questionnaire and a comparison of the Capital Hip with other types of hip replacement.

  • Conclusions and recommendations: the leaflet lists recommendations resulting from the investigations that can be applied by healthcare teams for the benefit of future patients.

Related document: Investigation of the performance of the 3M Capital Hip System

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A mixed bag : an enquiry into the care of hospital patients receiving parenteral nutrition
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,PATIENT SAFETY,CRITICAL CARE,PROCEDURES AND INTERVENTIONS,NUTRITION,CRITICAL CARE MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
The NCEPOD report 'A mixed bag' follows a unique national review of parenteral nutrition (PN). It examines the assessment, administration, catheter care and monitoring of patients nationally receiving parenteral nutrition. It reports findings in adult and neonatal nutrition and organisational data, making specific recommendations for each.

Principal findings:

  • Record-keeping
    There was poor documentation of nutritional issues. 27 hospitals that supplied adult PNand 24 hospitals that supplied neonatal PN did not have a central record of the patient to whom it was administered. There was also poor recording of the position of the catheter tip.

  • Staffing
    Despite a high proportion of the patients in the study being surgical there was a very low involvement of surgeons in nutrition teams.
    53% of hospitals did not have a dedicated CVC/PICC catheter insertion service.

  • Timescales
    62% of hospitals could provide adult PN and 63% of neonatal PN within 6 hours of request. However, there were delays in recognising the need for PN in 28% (71/252) of neonates and a delay in starting PN once the decision to commence PN had been made in 17% (36/210) of the neonates.

  • Complications
    Complications were avoidable in 54% of adult and 19% of neonates. 58% of adults in the study had a catheter and/or metabolic complication.

  • Guidelines
    81% of hospitals had guidelines on initiating PN.
    81% of hospitals had guidelines on changing and handling PN bags.

 

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A multicentre randomised controlled trial of the use of continuous positive airway pressure and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation in the early treatment of patients presenting to the emergency department with severe acute cardiogenic pulmonary oedema: the 3CPO trial
document.body:
Objectives: To determine whether non-invasive ventilation reduces mortality and whether there are important differences in outcome by treatment modality.

Design: Multicentre open prospective randomised controlled trial.

Setting: Patients presenting with severe acute cardiogenic pulmonary oedema in 26 emergency departments in the UK.

Participants: Inclusion criteria were age > 16 years, clinical diagnosis of acute cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, pulmonary oedema on chest radiograph, respiratory rate > 20 breaths per minute, and arterial hydrogen ion concentration > 45 nmol/l (pH < 7.35).

Interventions: Patients were randomised to standard oxygen therapy, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) (5–15 cmH2O) or non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) (inspiratory pressure 8–20 cmH2O, expiratory pressure 4–10 cmH2O) on a 1:1:1 basis for a minimum of 2 hours.

Main outcome measures: The primary end point for the comparison between NIPPV or CPAP and standard therapy was 7-day mortality. The composite primary end point for the comparison of NIPPV and CPAP was 7-day mortality and tracheal intubation rate. Secondary end points were breathlessness, physiological variables, intubation rate, length of hospital stay and critical care admission rate. Economic evaluation took the form of a cost–utility analysis, taken from an NHS (and personal social services) perspective.

Results: In total, 1069 patients [mean age 78 (SD 10) years; 43% male] were recruited to standard therapy (n = 367), CPAP [n = 346; mean 10 (SD 4) cmH2O] or NIPPV [n = 356; mean 14 (SD 5)/7 (SD 2) cmH2O]. There was no difference in 7-day mortality for standard oxygen therapy (9.8%) and non-invasive ventilation (9.5%; p = 0.87). The combined end point of 7-day death and intubation rate was similar, irrespective of non-invasive ventilation modality (CPAP 11.7% versus NIPPV 11.1%; p = 0.81). Compared with standard therapy, non-invasive ventilation was associated with greater reductions (treatment difference, 95% confidence intervals) in breathlessness (visual analogue scale score 0.7, 0.2–1.3; p = 0.008) and heart rate (4/min, 1–6; p = 0.004) and improvement in acidosis (pH 0.03, 0.02–0.04; p < 0.001) and hypercapnia (0.7 kPa, 0.4–0.9; p < 0.001) at 1 hour. There were no treatment-related adverse events or differences in other secondary outcomes such as myocardial infarction rate, length of hospital stay, critical care admission rate and requirement for endotracheal intubation. Economic evaluation showed that mean costs and QALYs up to 6 months were £3023 and 0.202 for standard therapy, £3224 and 0.213 for CPAP, and £3208 and 0.210 for NIPPV. Modelling of lifetime costs and QALYs produced values of £15,764 and 1.597 for standard therapy, £17,525 and 1.841 for CPAP, and £17,021 and 1.707 for NIPPV. These results suggest that both CPAP and NIPPV accrue more QALYs but at higher cost than standard therapy. However, these estimates are subject to substantial uncertainty.

Conclusions: Non-invasive ventilatory support delivered by either CPAP or NIPPV safely provides earlier improvement and resolution of breathlessness, respiratory distress and metabolic abnormality. However, this does not translate into improved short- or longer-term survival. We recommend that CPAP or NIPPV should be considered as adjunctive therapy in patients with severe acute cardiogenic pulmonary oedema in the presence of severe respiratory distress or when there is a failure to improve with pharmacological therapy.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A multi-centre retrospective cohort study comparing the efficacy, safety and cost-effectiveness of hysterectomy and uterine artery embolisation for the treatment of symptomatic uterine fibroids. The HOPEFUL study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ WOMEN'S HEALTH,GYNAECOLOGICAL TUMOURS,SURGICAL ISSUES,FIBROIDS,SURGICAL TECHNIQUES,SURGERY,SURGERY,FEMALE REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS,BENIGN GYNAECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS,FIBROIDS,BENIGN]]>
document.body:
Objectives: To examine and compare the medium-term results of hysterectomy and uterine artery embolisation (UAE) as a treatment for symptomatic uterine fibroids with regard to safety, efficacy, special issues in the UAE group, cost-effectiveness, and women's own perspectives on the treatments.

Design: Data were collected locally from patients' hospital records and also from patients themselves by postal questionnaire. Questionnaire data included free-text comments and this qualitative material was analysed using constant comparison. A two-stage probabilistic decision model was designed to estimate UK NHS costs and health outcomes in terms of quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs).

Setting: Eighteen NHS hospital trusts, 17 in England and one in Scotland.

Participants: Eligible women (972 UAE, 762 hysterectomies) who had received treatment specifically for symptomatic fibroids were identified.

Interventions: The UAE patients were treated by experienced interventional radiologists and all received their index UAE prior to the end of 2002, ensuring a minimum 2-year follow-up. The average length of follow-up was 8.6 years for the hysterectomy cohort and 4.6 years for the UAE cohort.

Main outcome measures: Primary outcome measures were complication rates to assess the comparative safety of the two interventions. Secondary outcome measures related to treatment efficacy including resolution of symptoms and patient-reported satisfaction with treatment. Further efficacy outcome measures obtained in the UAE group included fibroid/uterine size shrinkage and further treatments required for unresolved fibroid symptoms. Data were also gathered on pregnancies post-UAE.

Results: Data were available for 1108 women (649 UAE and 459 hysterectomy). Fewer complications were experienced by women in the UAE cohort compared to the hysterectomy cohort: hysterectomy n = 120 (26.1%), UAE n = 114 (17.6%), adjusted odds ratio 0.48 [95% confidence interval (CI) 0.26 to 0.89]. When only the severe/major complications were considered, this odds ratio was reduced to 0.25 (95% CI 0.13 to 0.48). Expected general side-effects of UAE occurred in 32.7% of the UAE cohort, of which 8.9% also experienced complications. Obesity and medical co-morbidity predisposed women to complications, whereas prophylactic antibiotics appeared to protect against both complications and the expected side-effects of UAE. More women in the hysterectomy cohort reported relief from fibroid symptoms (89% versus 80% UAE, p < 0.0001) and feeling better (81% versus 74% UAE, p < 0.0001), but only 70% (compared with 86% UAE, p = 0.007) would recommend their treatment to a friend. In the UAE cohort, 18.3% of the women went on to receive one or more further fibroid treatments including hysterectomy (11.2%). After adjusting for differential time of follow-up, the UAE women had up to a 23% (95% CI 19 to 27%) likelihood of requiring further treatment. The free-text data indicated that many women, in both cohorts, felt that their treatment had been a complete success. In the UAE cohort there were several areas where expectations were apparently high and outcome had not fulfilled their expectations. Disappointment was expressed mainly about continuation or return of symptoms or failure to become pregnant. Many continued to have remaining questions about their treatment. The economic analysis indicated that UAE is less expensive than hysterectomy even after further treatments for unresolved or recurrent symptoms are taken into account, with little difference in QALYs between the two treatments. Younger women are exposed to the risk of recurrent fibroids and subsequent additional procedures over a longer period and consequently UAE may no longer be cost-effective.

Conclusions: The study results suggest that both UAE and hysterectomy are safe. No unexpected problems were detected following UAE after a long follow-up period (average 5 years). Complications are less common for UAE than hysterectomy. The cost-effectiveness analysis favours embolisation even after taking account of complications, expected side-effects associated with the procedure and subsequent re-treatments for women with a preference for uterus preservation. It is important to improve the management of expectations following UAE, particularly regarding fertility. The data suggested that fertility and miscarriage rate are consistent with those of age-matched women with fibroids. UAE is an effective treatment for some women with fibroids and our trial supports the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence guidance that it should be made available as one of the options for treatment, with a possible reduction in the need for hysterectomy as the first-line treatment. Further research is needed into which women will be treated most successfully by UAE, the best method of achieving effective embolisation, advice for women who desire future fertility, the role of prophylactic antibiotics in UAE, and the effects of HRT use after UAE on recurrence of fibroid symptoms.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

SAGES (The Society of American Gastrointestinal and Endoscopic Surgeons), aware of the vital role of endoscopy and minimal access surgery to patient care, has developed and implemented an educational programme to help surgeons improve outcomes for patients who require these procedures.

Part of this educational programme is the freely available SAGES Educational Video Library. All videos were submitted to or presented at past SAGES annual meetings and cover the following categories:

  • Bariatric Surgery

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A prospective randomised comparison of minor surgery in primary & secondary care. The MiSTIC trial
document.body:
Aims and objectives: The objective of this study was to determine whether there is equivalence in the competence of GPs and hospital doctors to perform a range of elective minor surgical procedures, in terms of the safety, quality and cost of care.

The aims were:

  • to conduct a randomised controlled equivalence trial of minor surgery in two settings
  • to collect data on quality of surgery, patient satisfaction, patient safety and cost of procedure in two settings
  • to review data from this trial and from other sources in order to consider future direction and future research in this area.
Methods:
  • Design - This prospective randomised controlled equivalence trial was undertaken in consenting patients presenting at general practices and needing minor surgery
  • Setting - The study was conducted in the south of England. At the time of this trial, minor surgery provision was provided mainly via a fee for service contract with general medical practitioners, with some serious pathology treated in hospital.
  • Participants - Participants were consenting patients presenting at general practices. They all needed minor surgery in specified categories and the recruiting doctor felt able to offer treatment or to be able to refer to a colleague in primary care.
  • Interventions - Patients were randomised, on presentation to their GP, to either treatment within primary care or treatment at their local hospital. Evaluation was by assessment of clinical quality and safety of outcome, supplemented by examination of patient satisfaction and cost-effectiveness.
  • Main outcome measures - The primary measure was surgical quality assessed by blinded assessment of wound appearance, between 6 and 8 weeks postsurgery, by two independent observers, using photographs of wounds. Secondary measures included satisfaction with care, which was obtained by means of a patient questionnaire; safety of surgery in terms of recognition of and appropriate treatment of skin malignancies, obtained by an examination of histological material supplied and cross-referencing with referral forms from GPs; and resource use and implications.

Results: Please refer to full text document for details of results.

Conclusions: The safety of patients is of paramount importance and this study does not demonstrate that minor surgery carried out in primary care is safe as it is currently practised. There are several alternative models of minor surgery provision worthy of consideration, including ones based in primary care that require all excised tissue to be sent for histological examination, or that require further training of GPs to undertake the necessary work. The results of this study suggest that a hospital-based service is more cost-effective, but at the moment there is not the capacity in hospitals to take on the workload of minor surgery, and it would likely be unpopular with patients if it were to happen. It must be concluded that it is unsafe to leave minor surgery in the hands of doctors who have never been trained to do it. If the capacity to undertake the work is present in primary care, then the increased costs associated with training doctors to do it must be borne.

Citation: This technology assessment was prepared for the NHS R&D Health Technology Assessment Programme.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

      ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A review of policies and processes for the introduction of new interventional procedures
document.body:
Objectives: To identify and review both Australian and international policies and processes for the introduction of new interventional procedures into clinical practice, with the aim of determining:
  1. how decisions about the adoption of new interventional procedures are made
  2. the extent to which evidence-based information, particularly health technology assessments (HTAs), is used in the decision-making process.
 

Methods: Please refer to the original document for the methods used.

Results: Please refer to the original document for the results. 

Conclusions: Increasing numbers of healthcare organisations, both in Australia and internationally, are establishing formal policies and processes for the safe introduction of new interventional procedures into clinical practice. Decision-making about the adoption of such procedures appears to be focused largely on clinical outcomes such as the clinical need and burden of disease and the safety, efficacy and effectiveness of the procedure, as well as organisational outcomes such as the cost considerations and training requirements of the procedure. Few organisations have reported their experience with such policies and processes however and there is a paucity of information on the outcomes and organisational impact of these initiatives. While it is clear that evidence-based information, such as HTAs, is frequently used in decision-making about the adoption of new interventional procedures, a lack of access to relevant and timely HTAs has been identified as an important barrier to optimal decisionmaking. Therefore, greater effort needs to be put into establishing information infrastructure in order to make evidence more readily available to decision makers. 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A surgical safety checklist to reduce morbidity and mortality in a global population
document.body:
This 'Special Article' published in the New England Journal of Medicine reports on the results of a study led by the World Health Organisation as part of the 'Safe Surgery Saves Lives' patient safety challenge. 

Background: Surgery has become an integral part of global health care, with an estimated 234 million operations performed yearly. Surgical complications are common and often preventable. We hypothesized that a program to implement a 19-item surgical safety checklist designed to improve team communication and consistency of care would reduce complications and deaths associated with surgery.

Methods: Between October 2007 and September 2008, eight hospitals in eight cities (Toronto, Canada; New Delhi, India; Amman, Jordan; Auckland, New Zealand; Manila, Philippines; Ifakara, Tanzania; London, England; and Seattle, WA) representing a variety of economic circumstances and diverse populations of patients participated in the World Health Organization's Safe Surgery Saves Lives program. We prospectively collected data on clinical processes and outcomes from 3733 consecutively enrolled patients 16 years of age or older who were undergoing noncardiac surgery. We subsequently collected data on 3955 consecutively enrolled patients after the introduction of the Surgical Safety Checklist. The primary end point was the rate of complications, including death, during hospitalization within the first 30 days after the operation.

Results: The rate of death was 1.5% before the checklist was introduced and declined to 0.8% afterward (P=0.003). Inpatient complications occurred in 11.0% of patients at baseline and in 7.0% after introduction of the checklist (P<0.001).

Conclusions: Implementation of the checklist was associated with concomitant reductions in the rates of death and complications among patients at least 16 years of age who were undergoing noncardiac surgery in a diverse group of hospitals.  

Publication history: Published in the New England Journal of Medicine 'Online First' on 14th January 2009, in print on 29th January 2009.  

Access:  Available to the general public.

document.title: A systematic review and economic model of switching from non-glycopeptide to glycopeptide antibiotic prophylaxis for surgery
document.description: From the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme.
document.body:
Report from the Health Technology Assessment programme, part of the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR).

 

Objectives: The overall objective as stated in the abstract "determine whether there is a level of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) prevalence at which a switch from non-glycopeptide to glycopeptide antibiotics for routine prophylaxis is indicated in surgical environments with a high risk of MRSA infection."

 

Methods: Please see full report for details of the search strategies and results and the review process for this investigation.

 

Results: See full report for a detailed review of the clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness of the treatments being investigated and the development of a cost-effectiveness model.

 

Conclusions: The bottom line conclusion as stated in the abstract was that "there is insufficient evidence to determine whether there is a threshold prevalence of MRSA at which switching from non-glycopeptide to glycopeptide antibiotic prophylaxis might be clinically effective and cost-effective." The report recommends options for future research within this area.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A systematic review of intraoperative warming to prevent postoperative complications
document.body:
Bottom–line conclusion:
The prevention of intraoperative hypothermia is important for all patients having surgery, especially for older adult patients and for those having major procedures. Hypothermia can easily be prevented by a range of methods and only one (ie, warming of insufflation gas for laparoscopic procedures) was identified in this review as lacking efficacy. Preventing hypothermia also can reduce treatment costs, and this should be weighed against the costs of using warming therapies, which are relatively low by comparison.

Method: Twenty-six randomized controlled trials were identified, and data extraction and assessment of study quality were carried out by two researchers independently. The results of studies with similar patients, surgical procedures, and outcomes were pooled.
Outcomes measured included postoperative pain levels, thermal comfort, and treatment costs. Postoperative complications identified were shivering, cardiac events, need for blood transfusion, wound infections, and pressure ulcers. Literature search to May 2003.

Results: Overall, there is evidence that preventing intraoperative hypothermia can prevent serious postoperative complications. The evidence related to major surgery, which involves the most risk to patients, and the pooling of data in the studies that measured complications in a total of 1,061 patients, is conclusive. See full text for detail.
Although cost is not an adverse clinical outcome, one study did examine increased costs directly. In relating adverse outcomes to costs, it was found that in normothermia outcomes were improved and therefore costs were reduced. The authors concluded that the cost of preventing intraoperative hypothermia is much less than the cost of treating its adverse consequences.

Citation: Scott EM & Buckland R.  A Systematic Review of Intraoperative Warming to Prevent Postoperative Complications. AORN Journal 2006; 83 (5): 1090-1113

Publication history information: Published in 2006.

Access: Access to the full-text of this article online requires subscription or an NHS Athens password. NHS staff may register for an NHS Athens password here https://www.athens.nhs.uk/region/

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A systematic review of presumed consent systems for deceased organ donation.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION,HEART TRANSPLANTATION,FACIAL TRANSPLANTATION,HEART,LIVER & SPLEEN,HEAD & NECK,FACE,LIVER TRANSPLANTATION,HEART FAILURE,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,SURGERY,URINARY TRACT,KIDNEY & URETER,CONSENT AND ASSENT,TRANSPLANT OPERATION,UK TRANSPLANT,TRANSPLANT CENTRES,ASSESSMENT/SELECTION,DONOR,TRANSPLANTATION]]>
document.body:
Objectives: To examine the impact of presumed consent legislation on organ donation and to review data on attitudes to presumed consent among the public, professionals and any other stakeholders. Data sources: Eight electronic databases (MEDLINE, MEDLINE In-Process, EMBASE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, HMIC, PAIS International and OpenSIGLE) were searched from inception to January 2008. Supplementary internet searches were also performed.

Review methods: A systematic review of studies comparing donation rates in a single country before and after the introduction of a presumed consent law or in countries with and without presumed consent systems. The methodological quality of these studies was assessed and a narrative synthesis of results undertaken. Surveys of attitudes towards presumed consent legislation were also included.

Results: Please refer to full text document for details of results.

Conclusions: Presumed consent alone is unlikely to explain the variation in organ donation rates between different countries. A combination of legislation, availability of donors, transplantation system organisation and infrastructure, wealth and investment in health care, as well as underlying public attitudes to and awareness of organ donation and transplantation, may all play a role, although the relative importance of each is not clear. Further reviews could investigate the factors likely to modify donor rates, such as procedures for family involvement. The way in which families of any potential donor are approached is likely to be an important factor and a review of qualitative research examining the experience of relatives in this context would be useful.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: A systematic review of the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness and economic modelling of minimal incision total hip replacement approaches in the management of arthritic disease of the hip
document.body:
Objectives: To assess the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of minimal incision approaches to total hip replacement (THR) for arthritis of the hip.

Data sources: Major electronic databases were searched from 1966 to 2007. Relevant websites were also examined and experts in the field were consulted.

Review methods: Studies of minimal (one or two) incision THR compared with standard THR were assessed for inclusion in the review of clinical effectiveness. A systematic review of economic evaluations comparing a minimal incision approach to standard THR was also performed and the estimates from the systematic review of clinical effectiveness were incorporated into an economic model. Utilities data were sourced to estimate quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs). Due to lack of data, no economic analysis was conducted for the two mini-incision surgical method.

Results: Nine randomised controlled trials (RCTs), 17 non-randomised comparative studies, six case series and one registry were found to be useful for the comparison of single mini-incision THR with standard THR. One RCT compared two mini-incision THR with standard THR, and two RCTs, five non-randomised comparative studies and two case series compared two mini-incision with single mini-incision THR. The RCTs were of moderate quality. Most had fewer than 200 patients and had a follow-up period of less than 1 year. The single mini-incision THR may have some perioperative advantages, e.g. blood loss [weighted mean difference (WMD) –57.71 ml, p < 0.01] and shorter operative time, of uncertain practical significance. It may also offer a shorter recovery period and greater patient satisfaction. Evidence on long-term outcomes (especially revision) is too limited to be useful. Lack of data prevented subgroup analysis. With respect to the two-incision approach, data were suggestive of shorter recovery compared with single-incision THR, but conclusions must be treated with caution. The costs to the health service, per patient, of single mini-incision THR depend upon assumptions made, but are similar at 1 year (£7060 vs £7350 for standard THR). For a 40-year time horizon the costs were £11,618 for mini-incision and £11,899 for standard THR. Two existing economic evaluations were identified, but they added little, if any, value to the current evidence base owing to their limited quality. In the economic model, mini-incision THR was less costly and provided slightly more QALYs in both the 1- and 40-year analyses. The mean QALYs at 1 year were 0.677 for standard THR and 0.695 for mini-incision THR. At 40 years, the mean QALYs were 8.463 for standard THR and 8.480 for mini-incision. At 1 year the probabilistic sensitivity analyses indicate that mini-incision THR has a 95% probability of being cost-effective if society’s willingness to pay for a QALY were up to £50,000. This is reduced to approximately 55% for the 40-year analysis. The results were driven by the assumption of a 1-month earlier return to usual activities and a decreased hospital length of stay and operation duration following mini-incision THR. If mini-incision THR actually required more intensive use of resources it would become approximately £200 more expensive and would only be cost-effective (cost per QALY > £30,000) if recovery was 1.5 weeks faster. A threshold analysis around risk of revision showed, using the same cost per QALY threshold, mini-incision THR would have to have no more than a 7.5% increase in revisions compared with standard THR for it to be no longer considered cost-effective (one more revision for every 200 procedures performed). Further sensitivity analysis involved relaxing assumptions of equal long-term outcomes where possible. and broadly similar results to the base-case analysis were found in this and further sensitivity analyses.

Conclusions: Compared with standard THR, minimal incision THR has small perioperative advantages in terms of blood loss and operation time. It may offer a shorter hospital stay and quicker recovery. It appears to have a similar procedure cost to standard THR, but evidence on its longer term performance is very limited. Further long-term follow-up data on costs and outcomes including analysis of subgroups of interest to the NHS would strengthen the current economic evaluation.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.title: AANS/CNS guidelines for the performance of fusion procedures for degenerative disease of the lumbar spine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,OSTEOARTHRITIS,DISC DISORDERS,LOW BACK PAIN,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,SURGERY,INVESTIGATION,ANAESTHESIA,SURGERY,SURGERY,SPINAL COLUMN,DEGENERATIVE SPINAL DISORDERS,PAIN MANAGEMENT,ARTHRODESIS,LUMBOSACRAL]]>
document.description: Index page to a chapters 1 - 17 of the lumbar fusion guidelines
document.body:
Aims: to provide an evidence-based, comprehensive set of guidelines to clarify patient care and the best practice standards for degenerative lumbar spine disease.

Recommendations: recommendations and evidence are presented for each of the following chapters:
1: introduction and methodology
2: assessment of functional outcome
3: assessment of economic outcome
4: radiographic assessment of fusion
5: correlation between radiographic and functional outcome 
6: MRI and discography for patient selection for lumbar fusion
7: Intractable low-back pain without stenosis or spondylolisthesis
8: Lumbar fusion for disc herniation and radiculopathy
9: Fusion in patients with stenosis and spondylolisthesis
10: Fusion following decompression in patients with stenosis without spondylolisthesis
11: Interbody techniques for lumbar fusion
12: Pedicle screw fixation as an adjunct to posterolateral fusion for low-back pain
13: Injection Therapies, low-back pain, and lumbar fusion
14: Brace therapy as an adjunct to or substitute for lumbar fusion
15: Electrophysiological monitoring and lumbar fusion
16: Bone graft extenders and substitutes
17:Bone growth stimulators and lumbar fusion

Intended audience: neurosurgeons, orthopaedic surgeons and spine fellows

Methodology and development: the guidelines were prepared by American Association of Neurological Surgeons (AANS) and the Congress of Neurological Surgeons (CNS) Joint Section on Disorders of the Spine and Peripheral Nerves. Literature searches were conducted on MEDLINE from 1966 to 2003. There are some variations in search dates for different chapters. The Board of Directors of the AANS and the CNS Executive Committee reviewed and formally approved the guidelines.

Implications for practice: these guidelines present a well organised and comprehensive evaluation of the literature

Publication history information:
First published in Journal of Neurosurgery: Spine 2005; (6) 636–740 and each individual chapter is available as a separate link from the AANS/CNS Spine Section website. See http://www.spinesection.org/fusion_guidelines.php

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A service in need of surgery? NCEPOD 2005
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.description: This NCEPOD 2005 report describes the process of care of elective (surgical and endovascular repair) and emergency patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms in relation to outcome and also describes the process of care of emergency patients when a decision was made not to operate.
document.body:
Aims: This report describes the process of care of elective (surgical and endovascular repair) and emergency patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms in relation to outcome and also describes the process of care of emergency patients when a decision was made not to operate.
Recommendations are summarised for each chapter:
  • Organisation of vascular services
  • Surgery
  • Anaesthesia
No recommendations were made for endovascular repair or palliative care.
   
Intended audience:
Vascular surgeons, anaesthetists, radiologists, commissioners for Strategic Health Authorities and Trusts
Methodology:
The study was supported by the Vascular Society of Great Britain and Ireland (VSGBI), the Vascular Anaesthetic Society of Great Britain and Ireland (VASGBI) and the Royal College of Radiologists.
A sample size 1,129 operated cases and 106 non-operated cases were expected during the study period, based on a percentage of data from Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) and an estimate made for cases from the independent sector.
Retrospective data collection took place for two months from 1st February until 31st March 2004. All relevant NHS hospitals in England, Wales and Northern Ireland were expected to participate, as well as relevant hospitals in the independent sector, public hospitals in the Isle of Man and Guernsey and the Defence Secondary Care Agency.
Implications for practice:
Organisation of vascular services to manage the high demand on surgical, anaesthetic, radiological and critical care resources by elective and emergency abdominal aortic aneurysm surgery.

Publication history information: Published on the NCEPOD website in 2005

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.title: Ablation for atrial fibrillation: health technology policy assessment (2006)
document.publisher: Medical Advisory Secretariat (MAS), Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-term Care
document.description: A review of the evidence of the effectiveness, safety, and costing of ablation methods to manage atrial fibrillation (AF). The ablation methods reviewed were catheter ablation and surgical ablation.
document.body:
Aims: To review the evidence of the effectiveness, safety, and costing of ablation methods to manage atrial fibrillation (AF). The ablation methods reviewed were catheter ablation and surgical ablation.

Bottom-line conclusion: Catheter ablation appears to be an effective treatment for patients with drug-refractory AF whose treatment alternatives are limited. Ablation technology is continually evolving with increasing success rates associated with the ablation procedure.

Methods: The following databases were searched in March 2006:

  • Cochrane Library International Agency for Health Technology Assessment (first quarter 2006)
  • Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (first quarter 2006)
  • Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (first quarter 2006)
  • MEDLINE (1966 to February 2006)
  • MEDLINE In-Process and Other Non-indexed Citations (1966 to March 1, 2006)
  • EMBASE (1980 to 2006 week 9)

Other sources searched were Medscape on the Internet for recent reports on unpublished trials that were presented at international conferences; and the website Current Controlled Trials (www.controlled-trials.com) for ongoing trials investigating ablation for atrial fibrillation. See the review for full details of the literature review methodology, including the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Results: see full report for details.

Citation: Prepared by the Medical Advisory Secretariat, Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care for the Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee. Completed in March 2006.

Access : Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Acute kidney injury: adding insult to injury
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT SAFETY,SURGERY,KIDNEY DISEASES,CRITICAL CARE MANAGEMENT,ORGAN SUPPORT,RENAL,CLINICAL TOPICS,RENAL AND UROLOGICAL,PROCEDURES AND INTERVENTIONS,CRITICAL CARE,ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY,MANAGEMENT,CAUSES AND RISK FACTORS,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This NCEPOD report highlights the process of care of patients who died in hospital with a primary diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI). It takes a critical look at areas where the care of patients might have been improved. Remediable factors have been identified in the clinical and the organisational care of these patients.

Principal recommendations: All patients admitted as an emergency, regardless of specialty, should have their electrolytes checked routinely on admission and appropriately thereafter. This will prevent the insidious and unrecognised onset of AKI. (Clinical Directors and Medical Directors)

Predictable and avoidable AKI should never occur. For those in-patients who develop AKI there should be both a robust assessment of contributory risk factors and an awareness of the possible complications that may arise. (Clinical Directors and Medical Directors)

All acute admissions should receive adequate senior reviews (with a consultant review within 12 hours of admission as previously recommended by NCEPOD). (Clinical Directors and Medical Directors)

NCEPOD recommends that the guidance for recognising the acutely ill patient (NICE CG 50) is disseminated and implemented. In particular all acute patients should have admission physiological observations performed and a written physiological monitoring plan made, taking into account the degree of illness and risk of deterioration. (Clinical Directors and Medical Directors)

There should be sufficient critical care and renal beds to allow rapid step up in care if appropriate. (Department of Health)

All level 3 units should have the ability to deliver renal replacement therapy; and where appropriate these patients should receive clinical input from a nephrologist. (Clinical Directors and Medical Directors)

All acute admitting hospitals should have access to either onsite nephrologists or a dedicated nephrology service within reasonable distance of the admitting hospital. (Clinical Directors and Medical Directors)

All acute admitting hospitals should have access to a renal ultrasound scanning service 24 hours a day including the weekends and the ability to provide emergency relief of renal obstruction. (Clinical Directors and Medical Directors)

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.title: Acute pain management: scientific evidence
document.publisher: Australian & New Zealand College of Anaesthetists
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,SURGERY,NURSING,CLINICAL LIBRARY,ANAESTHESIA AND ANALGESIA,ANAESTHESIA,SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,INTRAOPERATIVE,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT,RECOVERY,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN MANAGEMENT,ANAESTHETIC TECHNIQUES,ANALGESIA]]>
document.body:
Aims:
To combine the best available evidence for acute pain management with current clinical and expert practice and summarise in an easily readable format for the practising clinician.

Recommendations:
The key messages are summarised for each chapter:
Physiology and psychology of acute pain;
Assessment and measurement of acute pain and its treatment;
Provision and safe and effective acute pain management;
Systemically administered analgesic drugs;
Regionally and locally administered drugs;
Routes used for systemic drug administration;
Techniques used for drug administration;
Non-pharmacological techniques;
The management of acute pain in specific clinical settings including postoperative pain.

Intended audience:
All those involved in the management of acute pain

Publication history information:
Second edition approved by the Australian NHMRC in June 2005. Third edition approved in February 2010.

document.title: American Gastroenterological Association medical position statement: short bowel syndrome and intestinal transplantation
document.description: Recommendations of the American Gastroenterological Association (AGA) on Short Bowel Syndrome (SBS).
document.body:
Aims:  To present the official recommendations of the American Gastroenterological Association (AGA) on Short Bowel Syndrome (SBS).

Recommendations:  Recommendations and information are presented for the following -

  • Medical therapy
  • Dietary management
  • Parenteral nutrition
  • Medication absorption
  • Role of surgery
      - Non-transplant surgery
  • Intestinal transplantation
      - Indications for transplantation
  • Complications of long-term TPN that could lead to the need for intestinal transplantation
  • Current management of the intestinal transplant patient

Intended audience:  These guidelines have been prepared for clinicians.

Methodology:  The recommendations were prepared by American Gastroenterological Association (AGA), however no methodology or references are offered.

Implications for practice:  This guidance provides a good review of nutrition and role and indication of transplantation, but please note that it is aimed at an American audience so treatment options may differ to those in the UK.

Publication history information:  The document was approved by the Clinical Practice Committee on August 5, 2002 and by the AGA Governing Board on November 1, 2002.

Access:  Available to the general public.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: American Society of Clinical Oncology guideline recommendations for sentinel lymph node biopsy in early-stage breast cancer
document.body:
Aims: to develop a guideline for sentinel node biopsy (SNB) in early stage breast cancer

Recommendations: the recommendations and summary are presented for each clinical question:
  • Can full axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) be avoided in patients with negative findings on SNB?
  • Is full ALND necessary for all patients with positive findings on SNB?
  • What is the role of SNB in special circumstances in clinical practice?
  • What factors affect the success of SNB (including low rates of complications and false-negative findings)?
  • What are the potential benefits and harms of SNB
Intended audience: clinicians and patients

Methodology and Development: An American Society for Clinical Oncology (ASCO) expert panel conducted a systematic review of the literature published up to February 2004 on the use of sentinel lymph node identification and sampling procedure (SNB) in early-stage breast cancer. The panel developed a guideline for clinicians and patients regarding the appropriate use of SNB. The guideline was reviewed by selected experts in the field and the ASCO Health Services Committee and approved by the ASCO board of directors.

Implications for practice: SNB is an appropriate initial alternative to routine staging ALND for patients with early-stage breast cancer with clinically negative axillary nodes. Completion ALND remains standard treatment for patients with axillary metastases identified on SNB. Appropriately identified patients with negative results of SNB, when done under the direction of an experienced surgeon, need not have completion ALND. Isolated cancer cells detected by pathologic examination of the SLN with use of specialised techniques are currently of unknown clinical significance. Although such specialised techniques are often used, they are not a required part of SLN evaluation for breast cancer at this time. Data suggest that SNB is associated with less morbidity than ALND, but the comparative effects of these two approaches on tumour recurrence or patient survival are unknown.

Publication history information: Journal of Clinical Oncology vol. 23 (30) October 2005

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader 

 

]]>

Part of a collection of eBooks available from the National Library for Health to NHS Athens users. 

Publication date: 14 December 2007

 



Description: Written and edited by an internationally known team of experts, this work is a 360-degree view of the field, covering all of the anesthetic considerations, preparations, and procedures for the surgical patient, the pain patient or the critical care patient. The key features: a unique balance between clinical information, practical clinical procedures, and the molecular and basic scientific underpinnings of anesthesiology practice; the first resource to feature a detailed look at the subspecialty of regional anesthesia; a focus on the clinical applications of anesthesiology; complex concepts explained by graphics and illustrations, not equations and formulas; and, full-color format and illustrations CD that allows readers to download illustrations and images to PowerPoint presentations.

document.body:
The NLH Specialist Library for ENT and audiology has conducted an extensive literature search for guidelines, systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs) on hyperthyroidism to provide an evidence update for 2008. Full details of guidelines, systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials are available here.

For the category of surgery, four randomised controlled trials were deemed relevant:

1. Gal I, Solymosi T, Szabo Z, Balint A, Bolgar G. Minimally invasive video-assisted thyroidectomy and conventional thyroidectomy: a prospective randomized study. Surg Endosc. 2008 Mar 6. [Epub ahead of print]. [abstract]

2. Hallgrimsson P, Loven L, Westerdahl J, Bergenfelz A. Use of the harmonic scalpel versus conventional haemostatic techniques in patients with Grave disease undergoing total thyroidectomy: a prospective randomised controlled trial. Langenbecks Arch Surg. 2008 Sep;393(5):675-80. [abstract]

3. Morrissey AT, Chau J, Yunker WK, Mechor B, Seikaly H, Harris JR. Comparison of drain versus no drain thyroidectomy: randomized prospective clinical trial. J Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2008 Feb;37(1):43-7. [abstract]

4. Tunca F, Giles Y, Terzioglu T et al. Does intraoperative radioguided surgery influence the complication rates and completeness of completion thyroidectomy? Am J Surg. 2008 Jul;196(1):40-6. [abstract]
