document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Annual Evidence Update 2008: Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,COLON & RECTUM,FAECAL INCONTINENCE,SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,ANAL CANAL & PERIANAL,ANAL INCONTINENCE]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 2008: Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence

(Please note that the 2009 version of this Annual Evidence Update is available here.)


Introduction


Annual Evidence Updates (AEU) produced by the National Library for Health attempt to draw together recently published, high quality evidence – focusing particularly on systematic reviews and published guidelines - which it is hoped will inform and enhance the decision making and planning of clinicians, commissioners and others involved in the process of health care.


NICE issued guidance on the management of faecal incontinence in adults in June 2007 based on literature published prior to October 2006. This AEU highlights relevant, good quality evidence published between October 2006 and July 2008 focusing specifically on surgical management (including sacral nerve modulation, biofeedback and implants as advised by our surgical reviewers). For more information on conservative management of faecal incontinence, please refer to the relevant pages on the gastroenterology & liver diseases specialist collection.


 

A detailed literature review was undertaken to retrieve systematic reviews, randomised controlled trials and other quality studies relevant to the surgical management of faecal incontinence including sacral nerve modulation, biofeedback and implants. A total of 61 articles were selected for review and appraised by a team of general and colorectal surgeons led by the specialist collection's external reference panel member for The Association of Coloproctology of Great Britain and Ireland, Mr Paul Hainsworth.

 

It is imperative that those involved in commissioning and delivering care are apprised of the best available evidence and guidelines against which to review their service. We hope that the AEU on the surgical management of faecal incontinence will provide a prime source of such evidence.

 

Evidence report and methodology:

  • Evidence on the surgical management of faecal incontinence - including including sacral nerve modulation, biofeedback and implants
  • Methods for retrieving and evaluating the evidence

With thanks to the Annual Evidence Update reviewers:

Mr Paul J Hainsworth MD FRCS - Consultant Colorectal Surgeon, Freeman Hospital, Newcastle upon Tyne and External Reference Panel Member for NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care

Mr Douglas G Aitken FRCS - Consultant General and Colorectal Surgeon, James Cook University Hospital, Middlesbrough

Mr Ian Daniels FRCS - Consultant General & Colorectal Surgeon, Royal Devon & Exeter Hospital

Ms Susan Green MD FRCS - Consultant in General Surgery, University Hospital of North Durham, Durham

Mr Jon Hanson MD FRCS - Consultant Colorectal Surgeon, Royal Victoria Infirmary, Newcastle upon Tyne

Ms Lalitha Mahadavan MRCS - Colorectal Research Fellow, Royal Devon & Exeter NHS Foundation Trust and Topic Advisor for the Specialist Library

Ms Karen Nugent FRCS - Senior Lecturer, Southampton University Hospital

Mr Graham O'Dair FRCS - Freeman Hospital, Newcastle upon Tyne

Mr Olagunju A Ogunbiyi MD FRCS - Senior Lecturer/Consultant Colorectal Surgeon, Royal Free & University College Medical School, London

 

Thanks also to the information specialists at the gastroenterology & liver diseases specialist collection for all their help and support.


]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Annual Evidence Update 2008: Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence - Methods for retrieving and evaluating the evidence
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 2008: Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence - Methods for retrieving and evaluating the evidence

(Please note that the 2009 version of this Annual Evidence Update is available here.)



Methods for retrieving and evaluating the evidence


NICE issued guidance on the management of faecal incontinence in adults in June 2007 based on literature published prior to October 2006. This update aimed to search for good quality evidence published between October 2006 and July 2008 focusing on the surgical management of faecal incontinence including sacral nerve modulation, biofeedback and implants (as advised by our surgical reviewers).

The search aimed to identify guidelines, systematic reviews, randomised controlled trials and other high quality studies published in English.

 

Search strategies

Searches were conducted in Medline and Embase (both Dialog and Ovid versions). The search strategies for Medline and Embase were based on those used in the NICE guideline, Faecal Incontinence. Please refer to Appendix C (pages 11 and 31-32) of the guideline appendices for full details.

Search strategy for Medline

  1. Fecal Incontinence/
  2. ((faecal or fecal or faeces or feces or fecally or faecally or anal or anally or stool or stools or bowel or double or defecat$ or defaecat$) adj (incontinence or incontinent or urge$ or leak or leaking or leakage or soiling or seeping or seepage or impacted or impaction)).tw.
  3. ((direct adj apposition adj sphincter adj repair) or (sphincter adj reconstruction) or (external adj anal adj sphincter adj placation) or (neoanal adj sphincter) or (colonic adj conduit) or (gracilis adj muscle adj augmentation)).tw.
  4. ((gracilis adj neosphincter) or (perineal adj puborectalis adj sling adj operation) or (pelvic adj floor adj repair) or (SECCA adj procedure) or (SECCA adj device) or (radio adj frequency adj energy adj delivery) or bioinjectibles).tw.
  5. (collagen or teflon or silicone or durasphere or macroplastique or PTP or bioplastique or colostomy or (stoma adj creation) or (temporary adj stoma) or (permanent adj stoma) or (perioperative adj management adj regimes) or (post adj surgical adj regimes)).tw.
  6. or/1-4

The search was repeated in Embase with the appropriate adjustments.

We also searched DARE, HTA, NEED, the NLH Guidelines Finder, the Cochrane Library, NICE, and SIGN.

61 articles were considered for appraisal

 

Inclusion criteria

Publication types - guidelines, systematic reviews, health technology assessments, economic evaluations, meta-analyses
Publication dates - October 2006 – July 2008
Treatments considered – surgical procedures; sacral nerve modulation; biofeedback; injectible implants
Publication language - English only


Back to Introduction

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Annual Evidence Update 2008: Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence - Reviews
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 2008: Surgical Management of Faecal Incontinence - Reviews

(Please note that the 2009 version of this Annual Evidence Update is available here.)



Evidence on the surgical management of faecal incontinence - including sacral nerve stimulation, biofeedback and implants. (A portable document file [pdf] version of this page is available under 'Related files' for easy printing.)

 

Surgical Management

Sacral Nerve Stimulation

Biofeedback

Implants

Other studies of interest




Articles selected on the surgical management of faecal incontinence:

Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewer's Commentary
Surgery for faecal incontinence in adults Brown SR; Nelson RL1 This Cochrane Collaborative review article presents a data overview from randomised or quasi randomised controlled trials of surgical treatments for faecal incontinence in adults only. Patients with rectal prolapse are excluded and sacral nerve stimulation is the subject of another Cochrane review. Technologies appraised include anal sphincter repair, pelvic floor repair, stimulated and unstimulated neosphincter creation and antegrade colonic irrigation.

Nine trials with 264 subjects were included and only one comparison had more than one trial in it. Some of the procedures assessed are of historical interest such as post-anal repair. Lack of randomised controlled trials comparing mainstream surgical procedures for faecal incontinence and methodological weaknesses of existing trials limit the clinical relevance of many of the these comparisons. Nevertheless this is a comprehensive and thorough review of trials to date. Most comparisons showed no differences in outcome.

Clinically relevant but already well-rehearsed conclusions were: faecal diversion after sphincter repair did not improve outcome but did increase morbidity and hospital stay; artificial bowel sphincter was better than conservative management; overlapping or end-to-end sphincter repair outcomes were equivalent (acute obstetric trials excluded).
Overlapping anal sphincter repair and anterior levatorplasty: effect of patient's age and duration of follow-up Evans C; Kumar D; Davis K2 This is a retrospective study of 66 patients who had an overlapping anal sphincter repair and anterior levatorplasty for faecal incontinence. Although post surgical physiological data did not show a statistical improvement when compared to pre-surgical data, functional outcome of patients has improved. The surgery has been performed by a single surgeon and the surgical technique is an established and standardised technique in this study. An interesting point highlighted by this study is that anorectal physiology does not predict the functional improvements in patients with faecal incontinence following surgery.

Conclusion: Overlapping anal sphincter repair with anterior levatorplasty is an effective surgical treatment for faecal incontinence. The success of clinical outcome bears no correlations with the age of the patient and there is no significant deterioration in patient symptoms with increase duration of follow-up.
Methods of repair for obstetric anal sphincter injury Fernando R; Sultan AH; Kettle C; Thakar R; Radley S3 This Cochrane Collaborative review article looks at overlap repair versus the end-to-end repair following obstetric anal sphincter injuries (OASIS) in reducing anal incontinence, perineal pain, dyspareunia and improving quality of life. Three randomised controlled trials were reviewed of grade A quality data that included 279 women. One study was excluded from this review as the anal sphincter repair performed was not immediately after OASIS but regarded as a secondary repair. Only two surgical techniques for the repair of obstetric anal sphincter injuries were reviewed in this article.

Conclusion: Early primary overlap repair appears to be associated with a lower risk for faecal urgency, anal incontinence score and reduced deterioration of anal incontinence symptoms when compared to the immediate primary end-to-end repair of OASIS. However, this review is not recommending one repair in favour of another as the issue of the surgeon’s experience has not been addressed in any of these papers.
Anterior anal sphincter repair for fecal incontinence: Good longterm results are possible Maslekar S; Gardiner AB; Duthie GS4 This is a retrospective study on 72 patients with faecal incontinence resulting from obstetric damage. All patients underwent physiological tests and completed symptom questionnaires. The surgical technique employed is also interesting as patients are placed in the jack knife position unlike the usual lithotomy position. Both anal sphincters were repaired separately, with EAS being repaired in an overlap fashion and IAS being repaired end-to-end. Patients were followed up for average of 7 years with a higher proportion of patients remaining continent and higher satisfaction levels.

Conclusion: This study retrospectively reviewed 72 patients with faecal incontinence following obstetric damage. Patients had an anterior overlap repair of the external anal sphincter and an end-to-end repair of the internal anal sphincter where indicated in the prone jack knife position. Following 7 years of follow up, the surgery was considered a success in 80% of patients. A higher proportion of patients remained fully continent with lower numbers of patients with urge incontinence and higher satisfaction levels with surgery when compared to other studies.
The artificial bowel sphincter for faecal incontinence: a single centre study Melenhorst J, Koch SM, van Gemert WG, Baeten CG.5 This prospective non-consecutive case series of 34 patients undergoing Artificial Bowel Sphincter (ABS) implantation is notable on account of emanating from the stable of Dynamic Graciloplasty (DGP). Between 1997 and 2006, patients with persistent or recurrent end-stage faecal incontinence were offered the choice of DGP or ABS. A sufficiently long perineum was a pre-requisite for ABS: aetiologies were mixed and 3 had undergone prior DGP. After 17 months mean follow-up, the infection rate in this series was high (7/34). Symptom scores improved significantly as did activated sphincter pressure. A relatively high rate of ‘constipation’ was noted (13/34). Twenty-six reinterventions (including explantations) were performed (0.79 per patient). Despite this, the authors conclude that ABS is an effective treatment option for severe faecal incontinence.
Rectal augmentation: short- and mid-term evaluation of a novel procedure for severe fecal urgency with associated incontinence Murphy J, Chan CL, Scott SM, Vasudevan SP, Lunniss PJ, Williams NS6 Rectal Augmentation is a new surgical operation designed to treat refractory urge faecal incontinence in patients with documented rectal hypersensitivity and poor rectal compliance. Between 1998 and 2001, 11 patients underwent the procedure, 6 of whom received a concomitant stimulated gracilis neosphincter. The procedure involves insertion of a 10cm ileal patch into the anterior rectal wall with temporary defunctioning ileostomy. This paper presents medium term follow-up. There were no major or late surgical complications and at 4.5 years, 4 patients had permanent stomas. Seven evaluable patients demonstrated generally favourable results with statistically significant improvements in symptoms and rectal sensory thresholds, but not rectal compliance (except at one year).
Surgical strategies for faecal incontinence: a decision analysis between dynamic graciloplasty, artificial bowel sphincter and end stoma Tan EK; Vaizey C; Cornish J; Darzi A; Tekkis PP7 Decision analysis study comparing cost-effectiveness of three surgical procedures available for the management of end-stage faecal incontinence. In the absence of good quality RCT’s on the subject, this probably represents the best available evidence despite its reliance on limited case series reports and expert opinion. It provides a basis for making rational clinical decisions in patient management.
Practice parameters for the treatment of fecal incontinence. Tjandra JJ, Dykes SL, Kumar RR, Ellis CN, Gregorcyk SG, Hyman NH, Buie WD; Standards Practice Task Force of The American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons.8 This is part of the excellent series of Clinical Practice Guidelines produced for and on behalf of the American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons. It comprises a review based on a Medline search of articles from 1966-2006 and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. Evidence and clinical recommendations are graded along familiar lines. There are no surprises in the recommendations made but this is undoubtedly the best detailed review of the available evidence for the component parts of surgical practice that this reviewer has read. Essential reading.



Articles selected on sacral nerve stimulation:


Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewer's Commentary
Sacral nerve stimulation for fecal incontinence: external anal sphincter defect vs. intact anal sphincter Chan MK; Tjandra JJ9 This observational study of 53 consecutive patients undergoing permanent sacral nerve stimulation considers whether the presence or absence of an external sphincter defect influences outcome up to 12 months. Patients with defects >120 deg were excluded. The study groups were heterogeneous with respect to the proportion that had undergone prior sphincter repair (81% v 38%). Clinical benefit was similar among those with and with out sphincter defects, irrespective of size of defect.
Predictive factors for successful sacral nerve stimulation in the treatment of faecal incontinence: a 10-year cohort analysis Dudding TC; Pares D; Vaizy CJ; Kamm MA10 This is a retrospective cohort analysis but it is a fairly large series from a single institution. It reflects significant experience with sacral nerve stimulation (SNS). SNS is now established as an effective treatment for FI. Appropriate patient selection, as for any treatment, is important but particularly so for SNS as it is expensive. This paper provides useful clinical data to help identify/select patients most likely to benefit (or not) from permanent sacral nerve stimulation. In the discussion they offer some suggestions as to the mechanism of action of SNS (currently not fully understood) which are supported by their findings in this study . Not high level evidence but robust data which shares the authors experiences in a rapidly developing field.
Outcome and cost analysis of sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence Hetzer FH; Bieler A; Hahnloser D; Löhlein F; Clavien PA; Demartines N11 This paper clearly sets out the costs of SNS in comparison to other established treatments for FI. The data supports SNS as a highly cost effective treatment for FI. The paper gives details of the 2 stage procedure as performed by the authors but this doesn’t reflect current practice in the UK, where the procedures are usually performed under GA (more expensive) and a temporary test electrode is used for the first stage (much cheaper) rather than a tined lead. This is acknowledged by the authors and argued as cost effective due to the significantly higher screening success rate with the tined lead: SNS for the treatment of FI has been relatively slow to take off partly because of costs. This paper provides useful data to support a business case for the development of SNS and supports it as a cost effective treatment for FI.
Sacral nerve stimulation for neurogenic faecal incontinence Holzer B; Rosen HR; Novi G; Ausch C; Hölbling N; Schiessel R12 Another relatively large case series on SNS in the management of faecal incontinence. Long-term follow up (three years) and QOL analysis provided support the clinical use of this technique.
Sacral neuromodulation in patients with faecal incontinence: results of the first 100 permanent implantations. Melenhorst J; Koch SM; Uludag O; van Gemert WG; Baeten CG13 This is a prospective study of 100 patients who underwent sacral neuromodulation with an intact sphincter mechanism (either with/without preceding anal sphincter repair). Following a definitive SNM implant, patients were found to have significant reduction in the number of incontinent episodes with a significant increase in the mean squeeze pressure on anal manometry. Furthermore, there was adequate follow up on all these patients. However, there is 20% later failure rate among these patients and no reason for this has yet been established.

Conclusion: Sacral neuromodulation has been shown to be an effective treatment for faecal incontinence in patients with an intact sphincter mechanism. However, further neurophysiological research is still needed as suggested by this paper to determine the reason for long term failure of this procedure.
Sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence alters colorectal transport Michelsen HB; Christensen P; Krogh K; Rosenkilde M; Buntzen S; Theil J; Laurberg S14 This study prospectively assessed the mechanism that causes the reduced number of bowel movements in 20 patients with faecal incontinence treated with sacral nerve stimulation. Following the implantation of the permanent electrode and neurostimulator, postimplantation scintigram was performed to assess the antegrade and retrograde transport within the colon during defaecation when treatment with the SNS had been optimised. However, the sample size was small and inter- and intraindividual variations are large. Therefore, this needs to be borne in mind when interpreting the results. This is a very interesting paper that has looked deeper into the physiological changes behind the success of SNS treatment in patient with faecal incontinence.

Conclusion: Sacral nerve stimulation in patients with faecal incontinence is successful in decreasing the frequency of defaecation by reducing the antegrade transport from the ascending colon and increasing the retrograde transport in the descending and transverse colon. Colonix transit times are also increase perhaps reflecting the improved storage capacity of the colon.
Sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence and constipation in adults Mowatt G; Glazener C; Jarrett M15 The usefulness of sacral nerve stimulation (SNS) in adults with functional bowel disease (incontinence and constipation) is topical and valid. The Cochrane Systematic Review process is a robust and globally accepted method of demonstrating the evidence for and against the effectiveness and appropriateness of treatments. The objectives of the review are clearly defined. The selection criteria was to identify randomised or quasi-randomised studies assessing the effects of SNS. SNS is a relatively new technology and therefore it is not surprising that that only a small number of studies were identified (2 related to incontinence). Both studies were crossover studies one with 34 patients (Leroi) the other with 2 patients (Vasey). There were two reviewers. Allocation for the larger Leroi study was with random number tables. Patient and outcome assessors were blinded. There were 10 withdrawals in the Leroi study. Intention to treat analysis was observed. The follow up period for each study was short, at most 3 months for the Leroi study. Incontinence scores improved in the Vasey study. The reporting of improved incontinence scores in the Leroi study was questionable given the subset analyses at the end of crossover period. The report highlights the very limited high quality studies addressing the effectiveness of SNS for incontinence in adults. The studies included have limited evidence that permanent SNS can lead to improvement in incontinence in selected patients with severe faecal incontinence. However a proportion of patients suitable for permanent SNS develop worse symptoms. The rate of adverse events leading to devise removal was high 15%. Further research is required to assess the effect of SNS.
Clinical and cost effectiveness of sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence Muñoz-Duyos A; Navarro-Luna A; Brosa M; Pando JA; Sitges-Serra A; Marco-Molina C16 Similar to Holzer et al with inclusion of cost effectiveness. It provides further evidence for the efficacy of SNS in the management of neurogenic faecal incontinence. It is I feel the best of the three case series.
Sacral nerve stimulation is more effective than optimal medical therapy for severe fecal incontinence: a randomized, controlled study Tjandra JJ; Chan MK; Yeh CH; Murray-Green C17 A well constructed randomised controlled study (RCT) from a colorectal unit of good reputation. The objective was to compare sacral nerve stimulation (SNS) with optimal medical therapy within a RCT. The study is of relevance and contributes to the evidence supporting use of SNS. There were appropriate study groups and randomisation process. Patient recruitment was good with sixty patients in each group. A power calculation was not performed to determine the numbers in each group required to any detect differences the intervention my make. Follow up period reasonable 12 months and drops outs for the intervention arm was fairly low (7) 11%. Results demonstrate SNS improved incontinence scores and quality of lifestyle parameters significantly in patients with incontinence of variable aetiology. However the follow up period of only 12 month is a limitation. Complications were rare and minor. The study also indicates a role for SNS in patients with functional evacuatory problems following rectal resection indicating a useful avenue for future research.



Resources selected on biofeedback / electrical stimulation:

Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewer's Commentary
Biofeedback for fecal incontinence: short-term outcomes of 513 consecutive patients and predictors of successful treatment. Byrne CM, Solomon MJ, Young JM, Rex J, Merlino CL.18 Of the 513 patients included in this retrospective analysis of biofeedback for faecal incontinence, 120 were enrolled in a RCT published in 2003. The addition of 395 subsequently treated patients makes this the largest reported case series to date, according to the authors. A Cochrane systematic review (2003) found that it was not possible to recommend biofeedback in the treatment of faecal incontinence based on 5 studies with 109 patients. Only very short term outcomes are presented (at end of the last and 6th monthly treatment session). Patients reported better improvement (75%) than surgeon assessors (58%) but lack of follow up limits the value of this study.
The effects of low-frequency endo-anal electrical stimulation on faecal incontinence: a prospective study Healy CF, Brannigan AE, Connolly EM, Eng M, O'Sullivan MJ, McNamara DA, Cusack C, Deasy JM.19 This un-blinded prospective RCT looked at the effectiveness of endo-anal electrical stimulation in 58 female patients with faecal incontinence deemed unsuitable for surgical repair, 48 of whom completed treatment. Group 1 patients underwent daily 1 hour stimulation at home with a portable device. Group 2 patients received physiotherapist directed once weekly treatment in hospital comprising alternating biofeedback/electrical stimulation utilising a different regimen. Those treated on the home protocol seemed to do better but the study lacks direct comparisons between the two groups.
Electrical stimulation for faecal incontinence in adults Hosker G; Cody JD; Norton CC20 This Cochrane Collaborative review of electrical stimulation (ES) for faecal incontinence in adults found only four eligible randomised controlled trials up to March 2007, involving 260 participants. In this context, ES means direct electrical stimulation of the muscles (intra-anal, intra-vaginal, implanted electrodes, etc.). None of the papers considered sacral nerve stimulation. Limited comparisons were possible: ES v other therapy (1 study) - surgery (levatorplasty) was marginally better; ES as an adjunct to other therapies v any other treatment (2 papers) – ES was better in one, with no additional benefit in the other; ES v another ES protocol which was equivalent to ‘sham’ stimulation (1 paper) – no benefit. The authors rightly conclude that there are insufficient data to allow reliable conclusions to be drawn on the effects of electrical stimulation in the management of faecal incontinence but there is a suggestion that there may be a small therapeutic benefit.



Resources selected on implants:

Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewer's Commentary
Injectable bulking agents for faecal incontinence NICE21 Limitation as only papers published by mid 2006 are considered. However puts a balanced view about sacral nerve stimulator, artificial anal sphincter and graciloplasty, urethral bulking agents. Includes a good review of all types of bulking agents used up until 2006.
Intersphinteric injection of silicone biomaterial for severe passive faecal incontinence Medical Services Advisory Committee, Australia22 Limitations: - only papers until 2006 and continuing evidence although small numbers in more up to date papers. Also: Only looks at silicone as a biomaterial not the many other different injectables. As a result the numbers are even smaller than if the other injectables had been included. However, of interest is the cost analysis of implant versus stoma and conservative treatment.



Other studies of interest:


Title Author(s) Clinical Reviewer's Commentary
Evolving therapy for fecal incontinence Tan JJ; Chan M; Tjandra JJ23 This is a well written, up to date and readable overview of current medical and surgical treatment of faecal incontinence by an author of good reputation. It ultimately proposes a useful treatment algorithm for faecal incontinence. The evidence supporting the use of the various treatment options are well referenced with good tabulated representations of follow up and results of the studies of the particular interventions. It is not, however, a formal meta-analysis or systematic review and therefore in its own right cannot be considered to be high level evidence. For the reader wishing to update knowledge about current practice concerning faecal incontinence or focus on certain treatments and their evidence base for future reading– this paper is very useful.

References:

1. Brown SR, Nelson RL. Surgery for faecal incontinence in adults. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2007, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD001757 [full text]

2. Evans C, Davis K, Kumar D, Overlapping anal sphincter repair and anterior levatorplasty: effect of patient's age and duration of follow-up. Int J Colorectal Dis. 2006 Dec;21(8):795-801. [abstract]

3. Fernando R, Sultan AH, Kettle C, Thakar R, Radley S. Methods of repair for obstetric anal sphincter injury. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD002866 [full text]

4. Maslekar S, Gardiner AB, Duthie GS. Anterior anal sphincter repair for fecal incontinence: Good longterm results are possible. J Am Coll Surg. 2007 Jan;204(1):40-6. [abstract]

5. Melenhorst J, Koch SM, van Gemert WG, Baeten CG, The artificial bowel sphincter for faecal incontinence: a single centre study. Int J Colorectal Dis. 2008 Jan;23(1):107-11 [full text]

6. Murphy J, Chan CL, Scott SM, Vasudevan SP, Lunniss PJ, Williams NS, Rectal augmentation: short- and mid-term evaluation of a novel procedure for severe fecal urgency with associated incontinence. Ann Surg. 2008 Mar;247(3):421-7. [abstract]

7. Tan EK, Vaizey C, Cornish J, Darzi A, Tekkis PP, Surgical strategies for faecal incontinence: a decision analysis between dynamic graciloplasty, artificial bowel sphincter and end stoma. Colorectal Dis. 2008 Jul;10(6):577-86. [abstract]

8. Tjandra JJ, Dykes SL, Kumar RR, Ellis CN, Gregorcyk SG, Hyman NH, Buie WD; Standards Practice Task Force of The American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons. Practice parameters for the treatment of fecal incontinence. Dis Colon Rectum. 2007 Oct;50(10):1497-507. [abstract]

9. Chan MK, Tjandra JJ, Sacral nerve stimulation for fecal incontinence: external anal sphincter defect vs. intact anal sphincter. Dis Colon Rectum. 2008 Jul;51(7):1015-24 [abstract]

10. Dudding TC, Pares D, Vaizy CJ, Kamm MA. Predictive factors for successful sacral nerve stimulation in the treatment of faecal incontinence: a 10-year cohort analysis. Colorectal Dis. 2008 Mar;10(3):249-56. [abstract]

11. Hetzer FH, Bieler A, Hahnloser D, Löhlein F, Clavien PA, Demartines N. Outcome and cost analysis of sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence. Br J Surg. 2006 Nov;93(11):1411-7. [abstract]

12. Holzer B, Rosen HR, Novi G, Ausch C, Hölbling N, Schiessel R, Sacral nerve stimulation for neurogenic faecal incontinence. Br J Surg. 2007 Jun;94(6):749-53. [abstract]

13. Melenhorst J, Koch SM, Uludag O, van Gemert WG, Baeten CG. Sacral neuromodulation in patients with faecal incontinence: results of the first 100 permanent implantations. Colorectal Dis. 2007 Oct;9(8):725-30. [abstract]

14. Michelsen HB, Christensen P, Krogh K, Rosenkilde M, Buntzen S, Theil J, Laurberg S. Sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence alters colorectal transport. Br J Surg. 2008 Jun;95(6):779-84. [abstract]

15. Mowatt G, Glazener C, Jarrett M, Sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence and constipation in adults: a short version Cochrane Review Neurourol Urodyn. 2008;27(3):155-61 [abstract]

16. Muñoz-Duyos A, Navarro-Luna A, Brosa M, Pando JA, Sirges-Serra A, Marco-Molina C, Clinical and cost effectiveness of sacral nerve stimulation for faecal incontinence. Br J Surg. 2008 Aug;95(8):1037-43. [abstract]

17. Tjandra JJ, Chan MK, Yeh CH, Murray-Green C, Sacral nerve stimulation is more effective than optimal medical therapy for severe fecal incontinence: a randomized, controlled study, Dis Colon Rectum. 2008 May;51(5):494-502. [abstract]

18. Byrne CM, Solomon MJ, Young JM, Rex J, Merlino CL. Biofeedback for fecal incontinence: short-term outcomes of 513 consecutive patients and predictors of successful treatment. Dis Colon Rectum. 2007 Apr;50(4):417-27. [abstract]

19. Healy CF, Brannigan AE, Connolly EM, Eng M, O'Sullivan MJ, McNamara DA, Cusack C, Deasy JM, The effects of low-frequency endo-anal electrical stimulation on faecal incontinence: a prospective study. Int J Colorectal Dis. 2006 Dec;21(8):802-6. [abstract]

20. Hosker G, Cody JD, Norton CC, Electrical stimulation for faecal incontinence in adults. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007 Jul 18;(3):CD001310. [full text]

21. National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE) 2007, Injectable bulking agents for faecal incontinence, [full text]

22. Medical Services Advisory Committee, Australia 2006. Intersphincteric injection of silicone biomaerial for severe passive faecal incontinence. [full text]

23. Tan JJ, Chan M, Tjandra JJ, Evolving therapy for fecal incontinence. Dis Colon Rectum. 2007 Nov;50(11):1950-67. [abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery: part I duration
document.description: A guideline to examine the evidence for the principles of antibiotic prophylaxis based on the choice of the antimicrobial agent, the timing of the first administered dose, and the duration of the prophylactic regimen.
document.body:
Aims: To examine the evidence for the principles of antibiotic prophylaxis based on the choice of the antimicrobial agent, the timing of the first administered dose, and the duration of the prophylactic regimen.

Recommendations: evidence and recommendations are presented for the following sections:

  • Antimicrobial resistance
  • Surgical site infection
    • Chest tubes and antibiotic prophylaxis
    • Single-dose prophylaxis
    • Prophylaxis for 48 hours
Intended audience:
The guidelines are designed to assist physicians and other health care providers in clinical decision-making by describing a range of generally acceptable approaches for disease management. They are not intended to be inclusive of all proper methods of care.

Methodology and development:
The Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) Workforce on Evidence-based Surgery has presented the conclusions supported by the evidence with a statement regarding the ideal clinical practice associated with the practice, and designated the classification and level of evidence using criteria used to classify evidence presented in Appendix A.
Note: there are no details about the literature search strategy or search dates.

Implications for practice:
NOTE: This article covers practice in various countries and should therefore be read with local guidelines regarding specific antibiotics.

Publication history information:
Published in 2005 on the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) website

 

]]>

document.title: Antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery: part II antibiotic choice
document.description: Following on from first set of guidelines from the STS, these guidelines cover antibiotic choice for different circumstances
document.body:
Aims: This guideline follows from the previously published ‘Antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery’ and examines choice of antibiotic, dose and frequency

Recommendations: evidence and recommendations are presented for the following sections:

  • Choice of primary prophylactic antibiotic
    • Cephalosporin or glycopeptides
    • Distinguishing between cephalosporins
  • Issues surrounding Staphylococcal infection
    • Reasons for concern in cardiac surgical patients
    • Potential (non-allergic) indications for primary or adjuvant glycopeptide (vancomycin) prophylaxis
    • Vancomycin as the sole prophylactic antibiotic
    • Mupirocin for preoperative therapy to eliminate Staphylococcal nasal colonization
  • Guidelines for appropriate dosing of prophylactic antibiotics
  • Guidelines for prophylactic antibiotics in special circumstances
    • Allergy to penicillin
    • Specific Issues regarding Gram Negative infections
    • Topical Application of Antibiotics
Intended audience: The guidelines are designed to assist physicians and other health care providers in clinical decision-making by describing a range of generally acceptable approaches for disease management. They are not intended to be inclusive of all proper methods of care.

Methodology and development: The Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) Workforce on Evidence-based Surgery has presented the conclusions supported by the evidence with a statement regarding the ideal clinical practice associated with the practice, and designated the classification and level of evidence using criteria used to classify evidence presented in Appendix A.
Note: there are no details about the literature search strategy or search dates.

Implications for practice: This article covers practice in the USA and should therefore be read with local guidelines regarding specific antibiotics.

Publication history information:
Published in 2007 on the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) website. 

Access:  Available to the general public.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: AORN guidance statement: sharps injury prevention in the perioperative setting
document.description: AORN practice guidance on sharps injuries
document.body:
Occupational exposure to blood borne pathogens via percutaneous injuries is one of the most serious dangers perioperative team members face on a daily basis. The risk of sustaining a percutaneous injury can be decreased through employee education, clear communication, device engineering, and focused work practice controls.
This guidance statement has been prepared by the Association of periOperative Registered Nurses in the US (AORN) and the suggested risk reduction strategies are intended to be adaptable to any setting where surgical or other invasive procedures are performed.
The guidance covers: specific perioperative risk reduction strategies, individual perioperative nursing staff responsibilities, employer responsibilities and overcoming obstacles to compliance.

Publication history information:
First published in the AORN Journal 2005; 81 (3): 662 – 667

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: AORN position statement: statement on fire prevention
document.description: AORN position statement on fire safety in the operating theatre.
document.body:
Fire is an ever-present danger and poses a real hazard to patient and health care worker safety. Fires occur when the elements that support combustion - an ignition source, a fuel source, and an oxidiser - come together. These three elements are referred to as the "fire triangle” and all three elements are present in abundance during operative and invasive procedures.
This guidance statement has been prepared by the Association of periOperative Registered Nurses in the US (AORN) and is a multidisciplinary approach involving all professionals who provide patient care. It includes strategies to manage ignition sources such as lasers and electrosurgical units; strategies to manage fuel sources including staff and patient linens and preparatory solutions; and strategies to manage oxidisers such as oxygen itself and anaesthetic gases.
It also covers evacuation plans and actions for each member of the perioperative team.

Please note: perioperative staff in the UK should know the colour coding scheme for fire extinguishers.

See: Colour Coding Guide 

Publication history information:
First published in the AORN Journal 2005; 81 (5): 1067 – 1075

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: AORN position statement: surgical smoke and bio-aerosols
document.body:
Exposure to surgical smoke and bio-aerosols poses a hazard to patients and perioperative professionals. Smoke and bio-aerosols are routinely produced by surgical instruments; eg, lasers, electrosurgical units, radiofrequency devices, ultrasonic devices, power tools. Research studies have confirmed that plume and bio-aerosols contain odor-causing and odorless toxic gases, vapors, dead and live cellular debris (including blood fragments), and viruses. These airborne contaminants can pose respiratory, ocular, dermatological and other health-related risks, including mutagenic and carcinogenic potential, to patients and operating room personnel.

This guidance statement has been prepared by the Association of periOperative Registered Nurses in the US (AORN) and contains recommendations to reduce risk from exposure.

Access:  Available to the general public.

 

]]>

document.body:
Best Evidence Topics or BETs are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

document.title: Artificial lumbar disc replacement
document.body:
Author’s objectives:
This Assessment aims to review the available evidence to determine if artificial lumbar disc replacement is an effective treatment for chronic degenerative disc disease.

Author’s conclusions:
The evidence is insufficient to determine whether the use of artificial lumbar discs improves the net health outcome or whether they are as beneficial as any established alternatives.

Publication history: Blue Cross Blue Shield Association, June 2007. TEC Assessment Vol. 22(2)

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Aspirin and other anti-platelet agents during operative coronary revascularization
document.description: A guideline to provide specific recommendations for managing anti-platelet medications, especially aspirin, in patients who require operative intervention.
document.body:
Aims: to provide specific recommendations for managing anti-platelet medications, especially aspirin, in patients who require operative intervention. Aspirin has been shown to be beneficial in improving post-MI survival and improving graft patency, but other studies suggest that it has detrimental effects in patients who require on-pump CABG causing increased postoperative blood loss. This is known as the ‘aspirin paradox’.

Recommendations: evidence and recommendations are presented for the following sections:

  • Beneficial effects of aspirin in the perioperative setting
    • Effect on graft patency
    • Effect on event reduction in patients with known coronary artery disease
  • Harmful effects of aspirin in the perioperative setting
    • Does preoperative aspirin cause increased postoperative blood loss?
    • Should aspirin be stopped before operation?
    • Are there high-risk patients who are made worse by giving aspirin before operation?
    • How should high-risk patients be managed if aspirin cannot be stopped before CABG?
Intended audience:
The guidelines are designed to assist physicians and other health care providers in clinical decision-making by describing a range of generally acceptable approaches for disease management. They are not intended to be inclusive of all proper methods of care.

Methodology and development:
The Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) Workforce on Evidence-based Surgery has presented the conclusions supported by the evidence with a statement regarding the ideal clinical practice associated with the practice. This evidence was classified according to the system used by the Joint Taskforce for Guidelines of the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (http://circ.ahajournals.org/manual/manual_IIstep6.shtml).
Note: there are no details about the literature search strategy or search dates.

Implications for practice:
The consensus recommendations from the evidence may prove useful to thoracic surgeons and cardiologists confronted with the ‘aspirin paradox’.

Publication history information:
Published in 2003 on the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) website. An Executive Summary of the STS Aspirin Guideline was published in the April 2005 issue of The Annals of Thoracic Surgery.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Bariatric surgery in women of reproductive age: special concerns for pregnancy
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,COMMON CLINICAL PRESENTATIONS,STOMACH,SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,STOMACH & DUODENUM,OBESITY,OBESITY SURGERY,RECENT ADDITIONS,MAY 2010]]>
document.body:
Background: The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), through its Evidence-Based Practice Centers (EPCs), sponsors the development of evidence reports and technology assessments to assist public- and private-sector organizations in their efforts to improve the quality of health care in the United States. The EPCs systematically review the relevant scientific literature on topics assigned to them by AHRQ and conduct additional analyses when appropriate prior to developing their reports and assessments.

Aims: The use of bariatric surgery for treating severe obesity has increased dramatically over the past 10 years; about half of patients who undergo these procedures are women of reproductive age. This report was commissioned to measure the incidence of contemporary bariatric surgery procedures in women age 18-45 and to assess its impact on fertility, contraception, pre-pregnancy risk factors, and pregnancy outcomes, including those of neonates.

Methodology: For details of the methodology used please refer to the original report.

Results: For details of the results obtained please refer to the original report.

Conclusions: Weight loss procedures are being performed more frequently to treat morbid obesity, with a six-fold increase over a recent 7-year time span; almost half of all patients are women of reproductive age. The level of evidence on fertility, contraception, and pregnancy outcomes is limited to observational studies. Data suggest that fertility improves after bariatric surgical procedures, nutritional deficiencies for mother and child are minimal, and maternal and neonatal outcomes are acceptable with laparoscopic adjustable band and gastric bypass as long as adequate maternal nutrition and vitamin supplementation are maintained. There is no evidence that delivery complications are higher in post-surgery pregnancies.

Publication history: First published on the AHRQ website in November 2008

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.description: A report from the Hospital Infection Society Working Group on Infection Control in Operating Theatres
document.body:
This comprehensive paper from the Hospital Infection Society explores issues that continually reoccur within the perioperative environment. Included are rituals in patient preparation, rituals at the operating table, rituals perpetuated by theatre staff and departmental rituals. It reviews the evidence relating to such rituals, and makes recommendations as to their use in practice.
This paper provides a useful overview for practitioners and references for more advanced research.

Publication history information: June 2004

document.title: Behind the headlines - Cosmetic surgery 'needs regulation'
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,PROFESSIONS & SPECIALTIES,SURGICAL,PLASTIC SURGERY,DERMATOLOGICAL SURGERY,SKIN DISORDERS,SURGERY,SERVICE DELIVERY,FACE,HEAD & NECK,AESTHETIC BREAST CORRECTIONS,PLASTIC,BREAST,SURGERY,RELATED SPECIALTY SERVICES,COSMETIC TREATMENTS & IMPLANTS,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Several newspapers have reported the dangers associated with cosmetic surgery, including a lack of regulation in some areas of the industry. The reports also feature warnings from Nigel Mercer, the president of the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons, who voiced his views as part of a series of medical articles on cosmetic surgery. Mr Mercer called for tighter regulation and testing of drugs, procedures and implants to offer more protection to patients.

The Times reported that the number of cosmetic surgical operations conducted by “audited members of the profession” has more than tripled to 34,000 since 2003, but that many additional procedures are being carried out illegally on the black market. The newspaper says that these are “fuelled by internet promotions, magazine advertising and aggressive discounting”. 

See the entire NHS Choices commentary on this news item.

Citation of original studies

Mercer N. Clinical risk in aesthetic surgery. Clin Risk 15(6): 215-217

Slack R. Aesthetic surgery and regulatory risk for doctors. Clin Risk 15(6): 218-220

Boyd M. Managing risk to reputation. Clin Risk 15(6): 221-223

Fogli A. France sets standards for practice of aesthetic surgery. Clin Risk 15(6): 224-226

Bradbury E. Clinical risk in cosmetic surgery. Clin Risk 15(6): 227-231

Nahai F. Minimizing risk in aesthetic surgery. Clin Risk 15(6): 232-236

Khoo C. Risk reduction in cosmetic surgery. Clin Risk 15(6): 237-240

Grover R. Improving the safety of aesthetic surgery: Recommendations following a 14-year review of cases referred to the Medical Defence Union from across the United Kingdom (1990–2004). Clin Risk 15(6): 241-243

'Behind the headlines' provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. The service is intended for both the public and health professionals and endeavours to:

  • explain the facts behind the headlines and give a better understanding of the science that makes the news
  • provide an authoritative resource for GPs which they can rely on when talking to patients
  • and become a trusted resource for journalists and others involved in the dissemination of health news
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Behind the headlines - Risk of clots 'months' after surgery
document.body:
“Patients recovering from surgery are at a high risk of fatal blood clots for much longer than thought,” the Daily Mail reported. It said researchers had found that the risk continues for up to three months after surgery.

This report is based on a large study in 947,454 middle aged women, which examined the risks of developing blood clots after having different types of surgery. It found that there was an increased risk of blood clots up to 12 weeks after surgery.

Conclusion

In this large and well-conducted study, the researchers determined that the risk for blood clots after surgery could last up to 12 weeks after the procedure. They also calculated the different risks for different types of surgery.

They warn that the incidence of blood clots after surgery may actually be higher than their figures indicate. This is because it’s likely that women were given treatments to prevent blood clots after surgery, and because the reported number based on hospital records may be an underestimation as some types of blood clot do not have symptoms.

It is worth noting that the researchers had no data on how many of the participants were taking preventive measures, such as wearing stockings or taking blood-thinning drugs around the time of their surgery. They say, quite reasonably, that if such data had been taken into account, the increased risk might have been even greater for people who had surgery and were not taking any preventive measures.

However, despite these uncertainties, and due to its size, these findings appear to be reliable. While it was already known that the risks were greatest in the few weeks following surgery, this study suggests that the risk may continue for a substantial time beyond this period. These findings may have implications for the use of blood clot treatments after surgery.

See the entire NHS Choices commentary on this news item.

Citation of original study

Cohen TA. Prevention of postoperative venous thromboembolism. BMJ 2009; 339: b4477

Sweetland S, Green J, Liu B. et al. Duration and magnitude of the postoperative risk of venous thromboembolism in middle aged women: prospective cohort study. BMJ 2009; 339: b4583

'Behind the headlines' provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. The service is intended for both the public and health professionals and endeavours to:

  • explain the facts behind the headlines and give a better understanding of the science that makes the news
  • provide an authoritative resource for GPs which they can rely on when talking to patients
  • and become a trusted resource for journalists and others involved in the dissemination of health news
]]>

document.title: Behind the headlines - Skin grafts from stem cells
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COLD & HEAT,PROFESSIONS & SPECIALTIES,SURGERY,SKIN DISORDERS,SKIN,SURGERY,SURGERY,DISORDERS,PHYSICAL & SUN DAMAGE,BURNS & HEAT DAMAGE]]>
document.body:
"Stem cells could create new skin to help burn victims,” BBC News reported. It said that French researchers have duplicated the biological steps that occur during skin formation in embryos. This could potentially provide an unlimited source of temporary skin replacements for burn victims while they wait for grafts from their own skin.

Conclusion

If it can be demonstrated that it works in humans, this technology could improve outcomes for burns patients. The researchers report that the first human trial is currently underway.

At present, skin from deceased donors is used to treat burns patients while they wait for their own skin transplant, but there are often problems with rejection. The researchers highlight several potential benefits of an epidermis reconstructed using K-hESCs, including:

  • The potential to make large quantities as it can be developed fully in the laboratory. The researchers say that industrialisation of the manufacturing process would reduce the risk of infection.
  • Less chance of rejection by the host because K-hESCs are in an early developmental stage and, therefore, don’t produce much antigen (the substance which causes an immune response).

It is important to note that, at present, the researchers are only investigating this technology for providing temporary grafts. They say that whether it can be used for permanent grafts for patients who can’t use their own cells needs further investigation. They say that for temporary use, the grafts would only be used for the three-week period while the patients’ permanent graft is grown.

This is a good study and the findings are exciting in this field, but only human research will tell whether it will have a wider application in the treatment of burns patients.

See the entire NHS Choices commentary on this news item.

Citation of original study

Guenou H, Nissan X, Larcher F et al. Human embryonic stem-cell derivatives for full reconstruction of the pluristratified epidermis: a preclinical study. The Lancet 2009; 374: 1745-1753

'Behind the headlines' provides an unbiased and evidence-based analysis of health stories that make the news. The service is intended for both the public and health professionals and endeavours to:

  • explain the facts behind the headlines and give a better understanding of the science that makes the news
  • provide an authoritative resource for GPs which they can rely on when talking to patients
  • and become a trusted resource for journalists and others involved in the dissemination of health news

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Best practice policy statement on: urologic surgery antimicrobial prophylaxis
document.body:
Purpose: Antimicrobial prophylaxis is the periprocedural systemic administration of an antimicrobial agent intended to reduce the risk of postprocedural local and systemic infections. The American Urological Association (AUA) convened a Best Practice Policy Panel to formulate recommendations on the use of antimicrobial prophylaxis during urologic surgery.

Methods: Recommendations are based on a review of the literature and the Panel members' expert opinions.

Results: The potential benefit of antimicrobial prophylaxis is determined by patient factors, procedure factors, and the potential morbidity of infection. Antimicrobial prophylaxis is recommended only when the potential benefit outweighs the risks and anticipated costs (including expense of agent and administration, risk of allergic reactions or other adverse effects, and induction of bacterial resistance). The prophylactic agent should be effective against organisms characteristic of the operative site. Cost, convenience, and safety of the agent also should be considered. The duration of antimicrobial prophylaxis should extend throughout the period when bacterial invasion is facilitated and/or likely to establish an infection. Prophylaxis should begin within 60 minutes of the surgical incision (120 minutes for intravenous fluoroquinolines and vancomycin) and generally should be discontinued within 24 hours. The American Heart Association no longer recommends antimicrobial prophylaxis for genitourinary surgery solely to prevent infectious endocarditis. Justifications and recommendations for specific antimicrobial prophylactic regimens for specific categories of urologic procedures are provided.

Intended audience: Healthcare professionals. 

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Bioengineered skin substitutes for the management of burns: a systematic review
document.description: A systematic review on the safety and efficacy of bioengineered skin substitutes for the management of burns
document.body:
Bottom–line conclusion:
The ASERNIP-S Review Group agreed on the following classifications and recommendations concerning the safety and efficacy of bioengineered skin substitutes for the management of burns. All products under consideration are available in the UK.
Note: The evidence-base in this review was rated as average.
Safety: The evidence suggests that bioengineered skin substitutes, autologous cultured skin, and allogeneic cultured skin, are at least as safe as biological skin replacements or topical agents/wound dressings. The long-term safety of the use of bioengineered skin substitutes, with respect to viral infection and prion disease, could not be determined.
Efficacy: For the management of partial thickness burns, the evidence suggests that bioengineered skin substitutes and allogeneic cultured skin, are at least as efficacious as topical agents/wound dressings or allograft. For the management of full thickness burns, the efficacy of autologous cultured skin could not be determined based on the available evidence.
Recommendations: More Randomised Controlled Trials (RCTs) are needed for bioengineered skin substitutes on patients with small burns and there is a need for RCTs on cultured epithelial autograft as its use largely based on anecdote.

Method:
Only RCTs in humans were included for review. Efficacy outcomes included wound infection, wound closure, wound healing time, and wound exudate. Patient-related outcomes included pain and cosmesis. Safety outcomes included complications and mortality.
Literature searches were conducted to April 2006 on MEDLINE, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, Science Citation Index, Current Contents, The Clinical Trials Database (US), NHS CRD, NHS HTA, National Research Register, National Institute of Health (US) and Meta Register of Controlled Trials.
Data from the included studies were extracted by an ASERNIP-S researcher using standardised data extraction tables developed a priori and checked by a second researcher. Statistical pooling was not appropriate due to the study and result heterogeneity.

Results: see executive summary and full report for details

Citation: prepared by the Australian Safety and Efficacy Register of New Interventional Procedures – Surgical (ASERNIP-S) August 2006

Publication history information: Published on the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons website in August 2006.

Note: there is also a patient/consumer version available.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.description: Health Protection Agency webpage for BBVs
document.body:
Many organisms are potentially transmissible in the occupational setting via percutaneous (sharp) or mucocutaneous (mucous membrane/broken skin) routes.
This webpage provides information and guidance for the occupational setting on the three most recognised bloodborne viruses in the United Kingdom:
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C
  • HIV

Aimed at healthcare professionals, it features an online journal including case studies and expert opinions, and an online manual for breast cancer diagnosis and treatment produced by the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC).
It also includes information on current clinical trials and features a section for nursing resources.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Breastfeeding promotion for infants in neonatal units: a systematic review and economic analysis
document.body:
Objectives: To evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of interventions that promote or inhibit breastfeeding or feeding with breastmilk for infants admitted to neonatal units, and to identify an agenda for future research.

Data sources: Electronic databases were searched (including MEDLINE and MEDLINE In-Process Citations, EMBASE, CINAHL, Maternity and Infant Care, PsycINFO, British Nursing Index and Archive, Health Management Information Consortium, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Science Citation Index, Pascal, Latin American and Caribbean Health Sciences, MetaRegister of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effectiveness, Health Technology Assessment Database, National Research Register) from inception to February 2008. Advisors identified further published or unpublished material.

Review methods: All papers fulfilled eligibility criteria covering participants, interventions, study design and outcomes. Results from primary studies were assessed and summarised in a qualitative synthesis for each type of intervention and across types of intervention. To estimate long-term cost utility, a decision tree was developed to synthesise data on enhanced staff contact, breastmilk effectiveness, incidence of necrotising enterocolitis (NEC) and sepsis, resource use, survival and utilities.

Results: Forty-eight studies met the selection criteria for the effectiveness review, of which 65% (31/48) were RCTs, and 17% (8/48) were conducted in the UK. Seven were rated as good quality and 28 as moderate quality. No studies met the selection criteria for the health economics review. There is strong evidence that short periods of kangaroo skin-to-skin contact increased the duration of any breastfeeding for 1 month after discharge [risk ratio (RR) 4.76, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.19 to 19.10] and for more than 6 weeks (RR 1.95, 95% CI 1.03 to 3.70) among clinically stable infants in industrialised settings. There is strong evidence for the effectiveness of peer support at home (in Manila) for mothers of term, low birthweight infants on any breastfeeding up to 24 weeks (RR 2.18, 95% CI 1.45 to 3.29) and exclusive breastfeeding from birth to 6 months (RR 65.94, 95% CI 4.12 to 1055.70), and for the effectiveness of peer support in hospital and at home for mothers of infants in Special Care Baby Units on providing any breastmilk at 12 weeks [odds ratio (OR) 2.81, 95% CI 1.11 to 7.14; p = 0.01]. There is more limited evidence for the effectiveness of skilled professional support in a US Neonatal Intensive Care Unit on infants receiving any breastmilk at discharge (OR 2.0, 95% CI 1.2 to 3.2, p = 0.004). Multidisciplinary staff training may increase knowledge and can increase initiation rates and duration of breastfeeding, although evidence is limited. Lack of staff training is an important barrier to implementation of effective interventions. Baby Friendly accreditation of the associated maternity hospital results in improvements in several breastfeeding-related outcomes for infants in neonatal units. Limited evidence suggests that cup feeding (versus bottle feeding) may increase breastfeeding at discharge and reduce the frequency of oxygen desaturation. Breastmilk expression using simultaneous pumping with an electric pump has advantages in the first 2 weeks. Pharmaceutical galactagogues have little benefit among mothers who have recently given birth. Our economic analysis found that additional skilled professional support in hospital was more effective and less costly (due to reduced neonatal illness) than normal staff contact. Additional support ranged from 0.009 quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs) to 0.251 QALYs more beneficial per infant and ranged from £66 to £586 cheaper per infant across the birthweight subpopulations. Donor milk would become cost-effective given improved mechanisms for its provision.

Conclusions: Despite the limitations of the evidence base, kangaroo skin-to-skin contact, peer support, simultaneous breastmilk pumping, multidisciplinary staff training and the Baby Friendly accreditation of the associated maternity hospital have been shown to be effective, and skilled support from trained staff in hospital has been shown to be potentially cost-effective. All these point to future research priorities. Many of these interventions inter-relate: it is unlikely that specific clinical interventions will be effective if used alone. There is a need for national surveillance of feeding, health and cost outcomes for infants and mothers in neonatal units; to assist this goal, we propose consensus definitions of the initiation and duration of breastfeeding/breastmilk feeding with specific reference to infants admitted to neonatal units and their mothers.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.title: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction

Best Evidence Topics or BETs were developed in the Emergency Department of Manchester Royal Infirmary, UK, to provide rapid evidence-based answers to real-life clinical questions, using a systematic approach to reviewing the literature.

They are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.body:
This article reports results of a study which aimed "to determine the relevance and reliability of the ten-item Consultation and Relational Empathy (CARE) Measure as a tool for measuring patients' views of anaesthetists during preoperative assessment consultations".


The study was highlighted in the news section of the website of the Royal College of Anaesthetists. The CARE tool discussed may provide a measure that can be used in appraisal and revalidation.


Original article reference: Mercer SW, Hatch DJ, Murray A, Murphy DJ and Eva KW. Capturing patients' views on communication with anaesthetists: the CARE Measure. Clinical Governance: An International Journal 2008;13(2):128-37.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Cardiac surgery risk models
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,HEART,TESTS & RISK ASSESSMENT,ISCHAEMIC HEART DISEASE,REVASCULARISATION]]>
document.description: Aspects of risk model development and validation.
document.body:
Aims:
This position paper looks at some fundamental aspects of risk model development and validation, the current uses and limitations of such models in cardiac surgery (with special attention to coronary artery bypass grafting - CABG), and prospects for the future.

Summary: the paper explores

  • Data
  • Source
  • Core variables
  • Definitions
  • Quality
  • Model development
  • Model validity
  • Uses of risk models
  • Limitations and disadvantages of risk models
  • Current status and future direction
Methodology:
This paper was developed Society of Thoracic Surgeons Workforce on Evidence Based Medicine

Implications for practice:
Although the subject is of interest to many UK surgeons, the use of STS risk scores makes it more relevant to US surgeons. This may also not represent the most current literature as articles on risk scoring in cardiac surgery are published frequently.

Publication history information:
Published in the Annals of Thoracic Surgery 2004; 78(5):1868-77 and on Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) website

Access:  Available to the general public.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Changing the way we operate NCEPOD 2001
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,CLINICAL AUDIT,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,PERIOPERATIVE PRACTICE,COMPLICATIONS,UNEXPECTED OUTCOMES,PERIOPERATIVE DEATH]]>
document.description: The report looks at the influence of variations in quality of care on the causation of death and the contribution of post-mortem examinations to our understanding of perioperative deaths
document.body:
Aims:
This report begins with a series of editorials covering the influence of variations in quality of care on the causation of death, the contribution of post-mortem examinations to our understanding of perioperative deaths and the requirement for improved information systems.
Recommendations are summarised for each section:
  • Surgeons and anaesthetists should partake in multidisciplinary audit
  • All Trusts in the NHS should use information systems with a nationally agreed specification
  • Need to increase the skills of nurses and doctors on the wards in central venous pressure (CVP) management and interpretation
  • The service provision for cancer patients, presenting either as an emergency or urgently, requires review
  • Clinicians, pathologists and coroners should review their working relations and means of communication
  • There needs to be an education programme to re-establish public confidence in pathology services and the post-mortem examination
Intended audience:
Clinician, managers, coroners, perioperative practitioners
Methodology:
Data for the report was collected from 1st April 1999 until 31st March 2000. It was supplemented by HES from the Department of Health and HIS from Northern Ireland.

Publication history information: Published on the NCEPOD website in 2001 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

For this reason, it is essential to have a basic understanding of infectious processes and to keep abreast of new developments in the field. document.title: Coil embolization for intracranial aneurysms
document.publisher: Medical Advisory Secretariat (MAS), Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-term Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HAEMORRHAGIC,STROKE,RECENT ADDITIONS,NEUROLOGICAL CONDITIONS,SURGERY,BRAIN,HEAD & NECK,CEREBROVASCULAR CONDITIONS,SURGERY,SUBARACHNOID HAEMORRHAGE,CONDITIONS]]>
document.description: Systematic review to review "the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of endovascular coil embolization as a treatment for intracranial aneurysms" (ruptured and unruptured).
document.body:
Aims: Systematic review to review "the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of endovascular coil embolization as a treatment for intracranial aneurysms" (ruptured and unruptured). The review was originally completed by the Medical Advisory Secretariat of the Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee in 2004 and updated in 2006.

 

Bottom-line conclusion: The report provide comprehensive details of the findings for the safety and effectiveness of coil embolization for both ruptured and unruptured intracranial aneurysms.

 

Methods: The following databases were initially searched up to January 2004 and again in January 2006:

  • Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials and Database of Systematic Reviews
  • International Agency for Health Technology Assessment
  • MEDLINE
  • EMBASE
  • MEDLINE In-Process & Other Non-Indexed Citations
  • Internet searches of Medscape and manufacturers' databases

Results: Please set report for a full set of results.

 

Publication history: Prepared by the Medical Advisory Secretariat, Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care for the Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee in 2004 and updated in 2006.

 

Citation: Medical Advisory Secretariat, Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care. Coil Embolization for Intracranial Aneurysms. Ontario: Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care; 2006.

 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Color Atlas of Infective Endocarditis
document.body:
Part of a collection of eBooks available from the National Library for Health to those with an NHS Athens password. 

Publication date: 2006




Description: Infective endocarditis is a condition that still carries a high morbidity and mortality rate (20-30 per cent) despite modern antibiotics and surgical treatment. The infection, usually caused by bacteria, invades the innermost lining of the heart and can damage heart valves, connective tissue and the heart chambers themselves. Rapid diagnosis, effective treatment, and prompt recognition of complications are essential to good patient outcome. If untreated, mortality is extremely high. The prevalence of infective endocarditis is between 1.7 and 4 people per 100,000, and is most commonly found in people who have underlying heart disease. Symptoms can be as non-specific as fever, fatigue, weight loss, new rashes (either painful or painless), headaches, backaches, joint pains and confusion; hence the disease remains a diagnostic and therapeutic challenge. Effective therapy has become progressively more difficult to achieve because of the proliferation of implanted biomechanical devices and the rise in the number of resistant organisms.

Access:  Available to NHS Athens users. To find out if you are eligible and to register for an Athens password please go to the Athens registration page. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader
