document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Comparative effectiveness of management strategies for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.body:
Conclusions are presented according to the following questions:

  1. What is the evidence of the comparative effectiveness of medical, surgical, and endoscopic treatments for improving objective and subjective outcomes in patients with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)?
  2. Is there evidence that effectiveness of medical, surgical, and endoscopic treatments varies for specific patient subgroups?
  3. What are the short- and long-term adverse effects associated with specific medical, surgical, and endoscopic therapies for GERD?
Method:
Literature searches were conducted on Medline from 1966 to February 2005, and the Cochrane Library was searched in March 2005. Reference lists were followed and authors contacted along with supplemental evidence (unpublished or in process) recommended by the panel of experts. Comparative, randomized and non-randomized, and cohort studies of adults (=18 years) were selected according to clearly defined inclusion and exclusion criteria. QUOROM guidelines were used to assess methodological quality of meta-analyses and CONSORT guidelines used to assess RCTs.

Results: See results section in full report for details. But please note, as this is USA-based study, some of the treatment options may differ from UK practice.

Citation: Prepared by Tufts-New England Medical Center EPC, Boston, Massachusetts for the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. AHRQ Publication No. 06-EHC003-EF, December 2005

Publication history information: Published on the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, USA website in December 2005.

Note: there is also a patient/consumer guide available

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader. The full report to download is 2mb in size.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Comparative effectiveness of percutaneous coronary interventions and coronary artery bypass grafting for coronary artery disease
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.body:
Conclusions are presented according to the following questions:  

Key question 1: In patients with ischemic heart disease, and angiographically-proven single or multi-vessel disease, what is the comparative effectiveness of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) compared to coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG), in reducing the occurrence of adverse objective outcomes and improving subjective outcomes?

  1. PCI includes percutaneous coronary angioplasty (PTCA), with or without drug-eluting stents (DES) or bare metal stents (BMS). CABG includes traditional on-pump or off-pump bypass procedures; on-pump or off-pump minimally invasive procedures; and CABG with transmyocardial revascularization (TMR).
  2. Long-term and short-time objective outcomes refers to outcomes that impact patients' health, including, but not limited to, peri-procedural death or complications, non-fatal myocardial infarctions, congestive heart failure, stroke, nosocomial infections, respiratory failure or other pulmonary complications, acute or chronic renal failure, cardiac arrhythmias, and long-term survival and event-free survival (major adverse cardiac events) both all-cause and cardiac deaths.
  3. Long-term and short-term subjective outcomes refer to outcomes that impact patients’ perceived quality of life, functional health status, or general health status. Subjective outcomes may include, but are not limited to, freedom from angina, functional angina classification, cognitive impairment, productivity, and functional capacity.
  4. Intermediate outcomes may also be considered if available evidence clearly links such outcomes to long-term or short-term outcomes. These include completeness of revascularization, target lesion revascularization, restenosis following PCI, CABG graft closure, the need for secondary revascularizaton procedures, procedures, readmission within 30 days, readmission within 6 months, and post-procedure discharge to rehabilitation facilities.
  5. Over what period of time are the comparative benefits of PCI and CABG sustained?

Key question 2: Is there evidence that the comparative effectiveness of PCI and CABG varies based on:

  1. Age, sex, race, or other demographic risk factors?
  2. Coronary disease risk factors, diabetes, or other comorbid disease?
  3. PCI-specific factors including, but not limited to, number of diseased vessels amenable to bypass or stenting, vessel territory of stenoses (e.g., left main or anterior coronary arteries, right coronary artery, circumflex coronary artery), diffuse vs. focal stenoses, left ventricular function, or prior revascularization procedures?
  4. CABG-specific factors including, but not limited to, cardiopulmonary bypass mode (normothermic vs. hypothermic), type of cardioplegia used (blood vs. crystalloid, cold vs tepid), or use of saphenous vein graphs, single or bilateral internal mammary artery grafts, or other types of bypass grafts?
  5. Clinical presentation (e.g., stable angina or unstable angina, based on NYHA functional class I-IV, acute coronary syndrome, cardiogenic shock, acute myocardial infarction with or without ST elevation, or silent ischemia)?
  6. Adjunctive medical therapies, such as short-term intravenous or oral anti-platelet drugs, or long-term use of oral anti-platelet drugs, improve the effectiveness of PCI and CABG?
  7. Process characteristics such as provider volume, hospital volume, and setting (e.g., academic vs. community)?
  8. Prior PCI or CABG revascularization procedures?

Methods: See methods section in full report for details.

Results: See results section in full report for details. 

Citation: Bravata DM, McDonald KM, Gienger AL, Sundaram V, Perez MV, Varghese R, Kapoor JR, Ardehali R, McKinnon MC, Stave CD, Owens DK, Hlatky MA. Comparative Effectiveness of Percutaneous Coronary Interventions and Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting for Coronary Artery Disease. Comparative Effectiveness Review No. 9. (Prepared by Stanford-UCSF Evidence-based Practice Center under Contract No. 290-02-0017.) Rockville, MD: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. October 2007. 

Publication history: Published on the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, USA website in October 2007.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

      ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Comparative effectiveness of radiofraquency catheter ablation for atrial fibrillation
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.body:
Aims: To investigate the effectiveness and safety of radiofrequency catheter ablation for the management of atrial fibrillation.

Methods: The review outlines the literature search strategy, inclusion and exclusion criteria and critical appraisal.

Results and conclusions: The results highlight the evidence relevant to the key questions formulated on the short and long term effectiveness of the radiofrequency ablation and the complications and risks. The conclusions discuss the quality and level of the evidence.

Access: Available to the general public

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Comparison of endovascular (EVAR) and open surgical repairs (OSR) for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.body:
Bottom–line conclusion:
For AAA <5.5 cm in diameter, active surveillance with delayed OSR results in equivalent mortality but lesser morbidity and operative costs due to fewer interventions compared to immediate OSR. For AAA >5.5 cm, EVAR has not been shown to improve long-term survival or health status over OSR though perioperative outcomes are improved. EVAR does not improve survival in patients who are medically unfit for OSR. EVAR is associated with more complications, need for re-intervention, monitoring, and costs compared to OSR or no intervention. U.S. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are needed using approved EVAR devices to evaluate patient outcomes.

Method:
RCTs of OSR, EVAR, or active surveillance, systematic reviews, nonrandomized U.S. trials, and national registries were used to assess clinical outcomes. Outcomes were described as initial clinical success (=30 days), short-term (30 days to 6 months), midterm (6 months to 5 years), long term (>5 years), and adverse effects. These were based on recommendations by the Society for Vascular Surgery.
Literature searches were conducted from 1990 to October 2005 and included Medline, the Cochrane Library, the FDA (US Food & Drug Administration), NICE, the Society for Vascular Surgery as well as hand searching and contact with content experts. Exclusion/Inclusion criteria were defined.
The methods of Schulz et al. were used to assess the quality of RCTs. All data were extracted by trained data extractors onto standard forms.

Results: See structured abstract for details

Citation: Prepared by the University of Minnesota Evidence-based Practice Center, Minneapolis, Minnesota for the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. AHRQ Publication No. 06-E017, August 2006

Publication history information: Published on the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, USA website in August 2006.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Comprehensive critical care: a review of adult critical care services
document.body:
This review of adult critical care services in 2000 proposed a modernisation programme to develop a comprehensive critical care approach based on severity of illness. Patients' needs would be determined according to the level of care their condition requires. The report introduced the comprehensive critical care concept and then discussed its organisation within NHS Trusts and between them. Human resource aspects were considered and the use of standards and guidelines covering all aspects of care was discussed. Recommendations were summarised under the headings of those that could be implemented immediately and those for medium term implementation. An extensive bibliography was included.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,INFORMED CONSENT,CONSENT AND ASSENT]]>
document.description: Essential reading covering all aspects of consent
document.body:
The purpose of the Tool Kit is to act as a prompt to doctors when they are seeking consent by providing answers to common questions raised by this process. It consists of a series of cards relating to specific areas of consent. Separate cards have been produced identifying factors to be considered when assessing competence and determining “best interests”. Each card is intended to stand alone, although there are some areas of overlap.

document.title: Continuous subglottic suction is effective for prevention of ventilator associated pneumonia
document.body:
Best Evidence Topics or BETs were developed in the Emergency Department of Manchester Royal Infirmary, UK, to provide rapid evidence-based answers to real-life clinical questions, using a systematic approach to reviewing the literature.

They are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.title: COSHH Essentials
document.description: Online tool for producing risk assessments for hazardous substances
document.body:
COSHH (Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations) Essentials is an online interactive system developed by the Health & Safety Executive in collaboration with the TUC and CBI.
It is used to produce COSHH risk assessments for chemicals used in a range of common tasks. Material safety data sheets (MSDS) are required for the assessment (risk phrases and chemical properties) see Index for MSDS. The user is then taken through a series of questions which concludes in a risk assessment together with advice on general principles of risk reduction.

See also: COSHH: a brief guide to the regulations

Access:  Available to the general public.

 

]]>

document.description: Useful for safety representatives, health and safety professionals and anyone interested in health and safety issues.
document.body:
COSHH is a useful tool of good management which sets eight basic measures that employers, and sometimes employees, must take. These are set out in this leaflet with a simple step-by-step approach which will help to assess risks, implement any measures needed to control exposure and establish good working practices.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Critical to Success
document.body:
This report by the Audit Commission, published in 1999, aims to make explicit links between organisation, efficiency and quality of critical care services. To help fill the information gap, the Audit Commission’s study included a national survey of bed numbers and staffing resources in England and Wales that secured a 100 per cent response from trusts and 85 per cent response from general adult units.

Abstract: Critical care is of vital life-saving importance. But within this service the issues of quality, costs and lack of data pose challenges for management. Costs are high; the figure for England and Wales approaches 0.75 billion and is increasing at a rate of 5-10 per cent a year. Mortality rates and the rehabilitation of surviving patients are variable and there is a lack of useful management information about critical care resources and their use.

]]>

document.body:
CTSnet is a comprehensive portal to online educational resources, scientific research, news and innovations in cardiothoracic surgery.
It includes illustrated articles on cardiac and thoracic surgical techniques, videos of procedures, images, clinical case presentations and results of journal literature searches using PubMed.
CTSNet has members from a broad international community but is predominantly aimed at the American surgeon.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Curative catheter ablation in atrial fibrillation and typical atrial flutter: systematic review and economic evaluation
document.body:
Report from the Health Technology Assessment programme, part of the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR).  

Objectives: To determine the safety, clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of radio frequency catheter ablation (RCFA) for the curative treatment of atrial fibrillation (AF) and typical atrial flutter.

Methods: Please see full report for details of the search strategies and results and the review process for this investigation.  

Results: Please see full report for details of results.  

Conclusions: RFCA is a relatively safe and efficacious procedure for the therapeutic treatment of AF and typical atrial flutter. There is some randomised evidence to suggest that RFCA is superior to AADs in patients with drug-refractory paroxysmal AF in terms of freedom from arrhythmia at 12 months. RFCA appears to be cost-effective if the observed quality of life benefits are assumed to continue over a patient’s lifetime. However, there remain uncertainties around longer-term effects of the intervention and the extent to which published effectiveness findings can be generalised to ‘typical’ UK practice. All catheter ablation procedures for the treatment of AF or atrial flutter undertaken in the UK should be recorded prospectively and centrally and measures to increase compliance in recording RFCA procedures may be needed. This would be of particular value in establishing the long-term benefits of RFCA and the true incidence and impact of any complications. Collection of appropriate quality of life data within any such registry would also be of value to future clinical and cost-effectiveness research in this area. Any planned multicentre RCTs comparing RFCA against best medical therapy for the treatment of AF and/or atrial flutter should be conducted among ‘non-pioneering’ centres using the techniques and equipment typically employed in UK practice and should measure relevant outcomes.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.title: Death following a first time, isolated coronary artery bypass graft: the heart of the matter
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.description: Report from the National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD).
document.body:
Report from the National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD) on an investigation that aimed to "review all in-hospital deaths following first time isolated CABG surgery to identify the effect" that organisational factors have on patient outcome.

Contents include:

  • The principle recommendations for patient care
  • Study methods
  • A detailed overview of data with example case studies, key findings and recommendations for each main study question

The main study questions focused on:

  • The referral and admission process
  • The scheduling of operations
  • Multidisciplinary case planning
  • Patient investigations
  • Medical management
  • Non-elective, urgent, in-hospital cases
  • Comorbidities
  • Anaesthetic process
  • Peri-operative complications and postoperative care
  • Appropriateness of surgery
  • Communication, continuity of care and consent
  • Multidisciplinary review and audit

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Deaths in Acute Hospitals: Caring to the End?
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,ORGANISATIONAL AND OTHER ISSUES,ACUTE SERVICES,RECORD KEEPING,SERVICE SECTORS,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,SERVICE SECTORS,SPECIFIC HOSPITAL ISSUES,COMMISSIONING,ACUTE SERVICES,SERVICE PROVISION,SURGERY,SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,EVALUATION,OUTCOMES,EMERGENCY AND URGENT CARE,COMMISSIONING PROCESS,INNOVATION AND IMPROVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The NCEPOD report 'Deaths in Acute Hospitals: Caring to the End?' highlights the process of care of patients who died in acute hospitals within four days of admission. It takes a critical look at areas where the care of patients might have been improved. Remediable factors have been identified in the clinical and the organisational care of these patients.

Principal findings:

In 25% (407/1635) of cases there was, in the view of the advisors, a clinically important delay in the first review by a consultant.

Poor communication between and within clinical teams was identified by the advisors as an important issue in 13.5% (267/1983) of cases.

There was a lack of communication both between different grades of doctors within clinical teams, and between different clinical teams and other health care professionals.

There were instances of poor decision making and lack of senior input, particularly in the evenings and night time. 95.8% of these sick patients were anaesthetised by an anaesthetist of the appropriate grade for their condition. Access to CT scanning and MRI scanning is a substantial problem with many sites having no or limited (<24hours) on site provision.

Only 150/297 hospitals have on site angiography (noncardiac) and of these only 76 have 24 hour access.

District hospitals may have particular problems delivering a high standard of care when dealing with very sick children and it is recognised that a well co-ordinated team approach is required.

In 16.9% (219/1293) of patients who were not expected to survive on admission there was no evidence of any discussion between the health care team and either the patient or relatives on treatment limitation. In 21.8% of cases DNAR orders were signed by very junior trainee doctors.

There were examples of where health care professionals were judged not to have the skills required to care for patients nearing the end of their lives. This was particularly so in relation to a lack of the abilities to identify patients approaching the end of life, inadequate implementation of end of life care and the poor communication with patients, relatives and other health care professions.

Executive Summary: The Executive Summary of the report 'Deaths in Acute Hospitals: Caring to the End?' is available here.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.title: Delivering surgical services: options for maximising resources
document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,NURSING,EDUCATION AND REFERENCE RESOURCES,SURGERY,THEATRE MANAGEMENT,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,EFFICIENCY,SURGERY,UTILISATION]]>
document.description: An insight into ways in which surgical departments can maximise use of available resources
document.body:
This report provides some insight into ways in which surgical departments within hospitals can maximise the use of available resources by:
  • Considering extending the working day
  • Examining the way in which resources are used
  • Considering service design.
It aims to help Trusts and surgical departments to maximise the utilisation of staff and other resources, provide an extended timeframe for training and meet productivity and waiting list targets. The paper is intended for both surgeons and service managers, and administrators with responsibility for designing services.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.title: Diabetic children undergoing surgery
document.body:
This guideline has been prepared by the North Central London (NCL) Paediatric Diabetes Network. This protocol is intended for those children with diabetes mellitus undergoing surgery. It is important to avoid the immediate complications of diabetes peri-operatively, particularly hypoglycaemia and ketoacidosis.

The guideline provides information on the management of minor procedures, major elective procedures and emergency surgery on the diabetic child.  

Access:  Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Diabetic Foot Disorders Clinical Practice Guideline (2006 update)
document.publisher: American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons (ACFAS)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,BLOOD VESSELS & LYMPHATICS,PERIPHERAL ARTERIAL DISEASE,DIABETIC FOOT]]>
document.description: Clinical practice guideline developed by the Diabetes Panel of the American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons.
document.body:
Aims: taking a multidisciplinary approach to patient management, this guideline reviews the current evidence on diabetic foot ulcers, diabetic foot infections, and the diabetic Charcot foot with the aim of reducing the number of diabetic limb amputations.

Recommendations: care pathways are outlined for the following

  • Assessment of the diabetic foot
  • Diabetic foot ulcers
  • Diabetic foot infections
  • Diabetic Charcot foot (Neuropathic Osteoarthropathy)
  • Surgical management of the diabetic foot

Methodology: This guideline was developed by the Clinical Practice Guideline Diabetes Panel of the American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons (ACFAS). There is no mention of methods used for evidence-grading or literature search dates, but the reference list includes references from 2006.

Implications for practice: While it includes summary diagrams and some high quality images, the section of the guidance dealing with surgery is relatively small. The guidance focuses mainly on epidemiology, prevention and medical treatment of the disease. Although developed in the USA, the guidelines do include UK data.

Publication history information: Published in the Journal of Foot and Ankle Surgery 2006; 45 (5) Suppl: S1-66. It is also published on American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons (ACFAS) website.

 

]]>

document.body:
Best Evidence Topics or BETs are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Double-balloon enteroscopy
document.publisher: Medical Services Advisory Committee, Australian Government
document.body:
A team from Adelaide Health Technology Assessment (AHTA) at the Discipline of Public Health, University of Adelaide carried out a literature review on double-balloon enteroscopy for obscure gastrointestinal bleeding or suspected small bowel disease. The evaluation of the evidence was then used to advise the Medical Services Advisory Committee of the Australian Government on making an informed decision on the use of this procedure.

Aims: To assess the evidence on the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of double balloon enteroscopy "for patients with obscure gastrointestinal bleeding or suspected small bowel disease".

Methods: Medical literature on the use of DBE was searched between 2001 and May 2006 using various databases including MEDLINE and EMBASE, plus other online resources. Please see report for details on search strategies and inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Recommendations: The MSAC recommend that DBE is "is a safe, minimally invasive technique for examining endoscopically the whole of the small intestine, allowing biopsy and certain therapeutic procedures at the same time". Please see report for a detailed list of all recommendations regarding the practise of DBE.

Citation: Buckley E, Newton S, Hedayati H, Merlin T, Moss J, Hiller J. Double-balloon enteroscopy. Canberra: Medical Services Advisory Committee; 2007.

Publication history information: published in 2007

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.body:
'Drug Safety Update' is the monthly electronic bulletin of information and clinical advice from the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency and the Commission on Human Medicines, its independent advisor, about the safe use of medicines. It is intended for all healthcare professionals who work in the UK - doctors, pharmacists, nurses, dentists, allied health professionals, and coroners.

The bulletin includes regular updates on the Yellow Card Scheme, which remains a vital part of the Agency’s vigilance activities. A free email alerting service is also available.  

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.body:
The ebme (Electronic Biomedical Engineering) website provides a comprehensive portal to information about healthcare devices developed and maintained by medical engineers.
The site is of interest to budget holders who purchase equipment in the perioperative environment, and perioperative practitioners who use electronic and biomedical equipment.
It includes some background articles about equipment, a medical equipment dictionary, a forum, a supplier contact database and press releases about new products.
It also includes links to Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency incident alerts.

Access: freely available but registration is required for forum posting.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: e-Learning Anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,EDUCATION AND REFERENCE RESOURCES,ANAESTHESIA,SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,TRAINING,ANAESTHESIA]]>
document.body:
The e-Learning Anaesthesia project is an educational initiative that has been undertaken jointly by the Royal College of Anaesthetists and the Department of Health. The primary aim of the project is to support delivery of the ST1/2 curriculum and associated training. The curriculum has been organised into six educational blocks that are designed to accompany clinical units of training from the first three months of supernumerary attachment to the level of competence previously associated with the certificate of completion of SHO training. A seventh block, comprising basic science elements, underpins the other six blocks and covers knowledge that complements the more clinical aspects.

  • Block 1: An introduction to clinical anaesthesia
  • Block 2: Consolidating basic clinical practice
  • Block 3: Introduction to critical care
  • Block 4: Principles of obstetric, paediatric and geriatric anaesthesia
  • Block 5: Regional anaesthesia and pain management
  • Block 6: Criticial incident case scenarios and examination practice
  • Block 7: Basic sciences: anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, physics/clinical measurement, equipment

Access:  Available to all UK anaesthetists: trainees, consultants, SAS grades and acute common stem trainees. Generic elements of the e-LA project will also be made available to other acute medical specialties and foundation doctors.

 

]]>

document.title: Elective & emergency surgery in the elderly: an age old problem
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,SERVICE SECTORS,QUALITY AND MONITORING,ACUTE SERVICES,TRAUMA,SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,SURGERY,PATIENT SAFETY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,FRACTURE,HIP AND PELVIS,HIP FRACTURES,QUALITY IMPROVEMENT,CRITICAL CARE]]>
document.body:
This NCEPOD report highlights the process of care of elderly patients who died within 30 days of emergency or elective surgery. It examines pre- intra- and post-operative care including pain management. External factors such as hospital facilities are taken in to account alongside mitigating factors such as comorbidities. The report found that only 36% of patients received care that was classed as "good" by the report's advisors, citing a "one size fits all" approach.

Also included on the website is a toolkit to assist Trusts to replicate the good practice found in the report.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Electrosurgical vessel sealing in vaginal hysterectomy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,FEMALE REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS,SURGERY,BENIGN GYNAECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS,MALIGNANT GYNAECOLOGICAL TUMOURS,MENSTRUAL CYCLE DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This report by the Centre for Evidence-based Purchasing examines the potential for electrosurgical vessel sealing (ESVS) systems to facilitate vaginal hysterectomy in a larger proportion of cases and assesses the clinical and financial consequences. 

Author's verdict: Significant potential
ESVS enables surgeons to undertake difficult cases using vaginal hysterectomy, reduces operation time and patients report less pain. Fewer sutures are required and some surgeons have been able to reduce the length of stay for vaginal hysterectomy, typically by one day. ESVS equipment can be cost-effective due to savings accrued from reduced length of stay. Investing in this new technology has the potential to make the transition from abdominal to vaginal hysterectomy easier and economically viable. Further independent studies are needed to establish the clinical effectiveness of the newer ESVS systems and forceps for vaginal hysterectomy. 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Emergency general surgery: the future - a consensus statement
document.publisher: Association of Surgeons of Great Britain and Ireland (ASGBI)
document.description: A consensus statement collated by the Association of Surgeons of Great Britain and Ireland (ASGBI) on the provision of Emergency General Surgery.
document.body:
A consensus statement collated by the Association of Surgeons of Great Britain and Ireland (ASGBI) on the provision of Emergency General Surgery.

Contents: The document provides a background to the development of the consensus statement, which resulted from discussion and debate initiated at the ASGBI Consensus conference held in early 2007.

The resulting conclusions address:

  • The variation in quality of Emergency General Surgery (EGS)
  • The workload within EGS
  • Clinical leadership and management of EGS
  • Resources and personnel for EGS
  • Delivery of and service models for EGS
  • Access to diagnostic services and theatre facilities
  • Assessment, prioritisation and management of patients
  • Case-mix
  • Trauma centres
  • Changes in vascular surgical practice
  • Continuing medical education

Audience: Health care professionals and service managers.

Publication history: The consensus statement resulted from a need to "define clinical practice, service delivery and organisation" of Emergency General Surgery.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Endoscopic treatments for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD)
document.publisher: Australian Safety and Efficacy Register of New Interventional Procedures -Surgical (ASERNIP-S)
document.body:
Aims: The objective of the study was to investigate the efficacy and safety of certain endoscopic anti-reflux treatments that are currently being used to treat gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD).


Methods: The report outlines the search strategy including the databases searched, inclusion criteria for selection and methods of data extraction and synthesis.


Results: The results looked at study quality, efficacy, safety and cost considerations.


Conclusion: The conclusion states that:

"Due to the relatively recent genesis of endoscopic anti-reflux therapies for the treatment of GORD, their scope, applicability, efficacy and cost effectiveness have not been established".

Please see full conclusion for further detail.


Citation: McLoughlin P, Jamieson G, Maddern G. Endoscopic treatments for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD): an accelerated systematic review. ASERNIP-S review No 54. Adelaide, South Australia: ASERNIP-S; 2006. Available from: http://www.surgeons.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=ASERNIP_S_Publications&Template=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&ContentFileID=17346


Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.title: Enhanced recovery programme
document.publisher: NHS Institute for Innovation and Improvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,RECOVERY,OPTIMISING PATIENT HEALTH,POSTOPERATIVE PAIN MANAGEMENT,INNOVATION AND IMPROVEMENT,CHANGE MANAGEMENT,LEADING IMPROVEMENT,CRITICAL CARE,CLINICAL TOPICS,CRITICAL CARE MANAGEMENT,PAIN,REHABILITATION,EVALUATION,OUTCOMES]]>
document.body:
Aims: The enhanced recovery programme aims to improve patient outcomes and post-operative recovery. This document provides guidance on implementing the programme and building the programme in to existing integrated care pathways.

Outcomes:

  • Better outcomes and reduced length of stay
  • Increased numbers of patients being treated (if there is demand) or reduced level of resources necessary
  • Better staffing environment.

Elements to the enhanced recovery programme:

  1. Pre-operative assessment, planning and preparation before admission.
  2. Reducing the physical stress of the operation.
  3. A structured approach to immediate post-operative and during (peri-operative) management, including pain relief.
  4. Early mobilisation.

Intended audience: Surgeons, perioperative staff, critical care staff and service managers.

Publication history information: Published 2008.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.body:
Best Evidence Topics or BETs were developed in the Emergency Department of Manchester Royal Infirmary, UK, to provide rapid evidence-based answers to real-life clinical questions, using a systematic approach to reviewing the literature.

They are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,OESOPHAGUS,ACHALASIA OF THE CARDIA,OESOPHAGEAL MOTILITY DISORDERS,SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,OESOPHAGUS,OESOPHAGEAL MOTILITY DISORDERS,RECENT ADDITIONS]]>
document.description: A brief consensus-based overview of current management for achalasia
document.body:
These patient care guidelines have been prepared by the Society for Surgery of the Alimentary Tract (SSAT) in the US to assist the primary care physician in deciding when to refer a patient for surgical consultation.
They provide a brief consensus-based overview of current management for achalasia including diagnosis, treatment, risks and expected outcomes. It is recognised that there is a relative paucity of high-level evidence for this condition; as such these consensus guidelines address the range of practice rather than specifying a particular standard of care.

Please note: treatment options may be different for UK practice.

Publication history information:
Revised edition approved by the SSAT board in February 2006 and available from the SSAT website

Access:  Available to the general public.

 

]]>

document.body:

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: euroSCORE
document.description: European System for Cardiac Operative Risk Evaluation
document.body:
EuroSCORE stands for European System for Cardiac Operative Risk Evaluation. It has been developed using risk factor data collected from patients in eight European countries. The most important, reliable and objective risk factors are used to prepare a scoring system to predict outcome following surgery (mortality or survival).
There are 2 types of risk calculators available for doctors. Simple euroSCORE uses the simple addition of scores ascribed to different risk factors, and Logistic euroSCORE uses the same risk factors as the simple model but uses logistic regression to come up with a final score.
Logistic euroSCORE is now the formal scoring system to assess the risk of dying after a heart operation in the UK as used by the Healthcare Commission and the Society of Cardiothoracic Surgery of GB and I. See http://heartsurgery.healthcarecommission.org.uk/
There is also a Patient euroSCORE with questions designed specifically for patients to calculate their own risk. 

Access: freely available

 

]]>

document.publisher: National Coordinating Centre for the Service Delivery and Organisation (NCCSDO)
document.body:
In April 2003 the NHS Service Delivery and Organisation research and development programme called for an evaluation of CCOS and TT systems. This evaluation, by a group of collaborators led from ICNARC, comprised a number of sub-studies including:

  • a systematic review of evaluative studies
  • a national survey of the introduction, implementation and current models of CCOS across England
  • an interrupted time series to explore their impact
  • a matched cohort analysis to evaluate their impact
  • a qualitative evaluation.

Access: Available to the general public. This leaflet is in PDF format and requires Adobe Acrobat Reader which can be downloaded for free from the Adobe website.

document.title: e-VTE
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,EDUCATION AND RESEARCH,SELF-TESTS,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,PREOPERATIVE PREPARATIONS,THROMBOSIS PROPHYLAXIS,EDUCATION AND CPD,SURGERY]]>
document.body:
e-VTE is an e-learning resource for  Venous Thromboembolism developed by the Chief Medical Officer’s VTE Implementation Working Group (IWG) in partnership with e-Learning for Healthcare (e-LfH).

Available to anyone with an interest in VTE prevention, e-VTE is written and reviewed by senior practitioners and enables clinicians to take appropriate action in assessing the risk of VTE for an individual and then advise appropriate preventative measures.  e-VTE also explores the challenges and opportunities to prevent VTE in primary care. The e-learning will help clinicians with taking appropriate action in assessing the risk of VTE for an individual and advising appropriate preventative measures.

e-VTE consists of four sessions of e-learning with a pre-learning questionnaire and post learning assessment that can be accessed anywhere with an Internet connection, both in the UK and abroad.

 

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Exploring professional boundaries in anaesthetics
document.publisher: National Coordinating Centre for the Service Delivery and Organisation (NCCSDO)
document.body:
In the United Kingdom (UK), anaesthesia is administered only by doctors. In the United States of America (US) and some other European countries, nonphysicians also administer or monitor anaesthetics. In many developing nations, non-physicians are the sole anaesthetic practitioners. Worldwide, most nonphysician practitioners come from a nursing background.

This study was performed to allow potential practical developments in this area to proceed from a position of evidence.

Access: Available to the general public. This leaflet is in PDF format and requires Adobe Acrobat Reader which can be downloaded for free from the Adobe website.

 

]]>

document.body:

Its second report is the result of oral and written evidence submitted since May 2006; consideration of a number of developments since its first report in November 2003, including two partial facial transplants already undertaken outside the UK; the delivery of medium-term follow-up data on 24 hand and forearm transplants; and the study of a number of publications concerning the psychosocial and ethical issues involved in transplantation.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Fifth report of the mandatory surveillance of surgical site infection in orthopaedic surgery April 2004 to March 2009
document.description: This report presents data collected during the past five years of the mandatory surveillance of surgical site infections in orthopaedic surgery.
document.body:
Since 2004, all NHS Trusts where orthopaedic procedures are performed are required to undertake a minimum of three months' surveillance of surgical site infections in at least one of the following orthopaedic categories: hip replacement, knee replacement, repair of neck of femur or reduction of long bone fracture. This report is an analysis of the data collected in the five years since surveillance of surgical site infection in orthopaedic procedures became mandatory.

Contents:

  • The key points highlighted from the surveillance results
  • Introduction to the surveillance methods and analyses
  • Rates of surgical site infection in orthopaedic surgery
  • Characteristics of surgical site infections (SSI)
  • Variation of rates of SSI between trusts
  • Conclusions

Publication history: For information on previous reports please go to the Health Protection Agency website.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: First annual report of the national mastectomy and breast reconstruction audit 2008
document.publisher: NHS Information Centre for Health and Social Care
document.body:
This is the first annual report from the National Mastectomy and Breast Reconstruction Audit. The report presents the first year’s work on the project including a pre-audit qualitative study, Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) analysis and organisational audit. The National Mastectomy and Breast Reconstruction Audit collects information on all women (aged 16 and over) who undergo mastectomy and/or breast reconstruction between 1 January and 30 September 2008 in both the NHS and Independent sector. The results of the clinical data collection and patient reported outcomes study will be reported in subsequent reports starting in December 2008.

Aims: The aim of the audit is to describe provision of and access to breast reconstruction in England and Wales. Evaluate current clinical practice in mastectomy and breast reconstruction and measure outcomes following mastectomy with or without reconstruction and assess the quality of information provided to women undergoing mastectomy and their satisfaction with the reconstructive choices made.  

Second report

Third report

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

The report highlights several differences in approach which reflect differing philosophical approaches to some difficult diseases. The publication is intended to stimulate debate on agreeing the very best screening investigations before surgery as well as the ethics and philosophy of different approaches in order to improve the quality of care on offer.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Foresight Training Programme
document.body:
The Foresight Training Resource Pack has been produced by the National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) to improve the safety of patients treated in the NHS.

The Foresight Training Resource Pack has been developed to:

  • improve awareness in nursing and midwifery of the factors that combine to increase the likelihood of patient safety incidents
  • increase local learning through sharing experiences
  • improve understanding of “risk prone situations”
  • improve understanding of situations that could be considered as a “near miss”
The pack contains a range of training scenarios, paper and video based, and supporting materials for use by a facilitator.

Foresight Training has been specifically designed to be flexible, so that it can be used in team meetings, handovers, mandatory training sessions and stand alone sessions, facilitated by members of staff.  

Intended audience: Nurses and midwives, working in all care settings.  

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.title: Functioning as a team (2002)
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,PATIENT SAFETY,COMMUNICATIONS,INTRAOPERATIVE,STAFF RELATIONSHIPS,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,DRUG ERRORS,TEAM WORKING,MONITORING & SAFETY,COMPLICATIONS,UNEXPECTED OUTCOMES,PERIOPERATIVE DEATH]]>
document.description: A report looking at how far team working has developed and most particularly at weaknesses in the systems, which create barriers to change
document.body:
Aims: to look at how far team working has developed and most particularly at weaknesses in the systems, which create barriers to change. The report also highlights issues around medical record keeping.
Recommendations are summarised for each chapter:
  • Management should ensure appropriate funded consultant sessions for ICU
  • Guidelines on anaesthetic monitoring should be employed at all times
  • Need guidelines to reduce clinical prescribing error
  • Ensure availability of experienced clinicians to diagnose acute appendicitis
  • Theatre team should receive copy of discharge summary and autopsy report
  • Perioperative complications attributable to death should be recorded on death certificate
  • Autopsies should be formally audited
Intended audience:
Clinician, managers, coroners, perioperative practitioners
Methodology:
The report is based on a sample of deaths within three days of an intervention, following the patient’s journey through an illness and the delivery of hospital care. Only the first death for each surgeon was sampled. For each sample case, questionnaires were sent to the consultant surgeon or gynaecologist and consultant anaesthetist. The NCEPOD Clinical Co-ordinators, together with the Advisory Groups for anaesthesia and surgery, reviewed the completed questionnaires and the aggregated data.
Data for the report was collected from 1st April 2000 until 31st March 2001

Publication history information: Published on the NCEPOD website in 2002

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Gender-specific practice guidelines for coronary artery bypass surgery
document.description: Guidance from the US Society of Thoracic Surgeons
document.body:
Aims: To examine the evidence on gender issues in perioperative management (including operative risk and postoperative complications) of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)

Recommendations: these are presented with evidence grading for each of the following:

  1. Use of the Internal Mammary Artery
  2. Management of Hyperglycaemia
  3. Management of Anaemia
  4. Use of Off-Pump CABG (OPCAB)
  5. Adjustment of anaesthetic and sedation medications
  6. Optimization of thyroxine treatment for women with hypothyroidism
  7. Consideration of preoperative hormone replacement therapy (HRT)
Intended audience: the guidelines are designed to assist physicians and other health care providers in clinical decision-making by describing a range of generally acceptable approaches for disease management. They are not intended to be inclusive of all proper methods of care.

Methodology and development: the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) Workforce on Evidence-based Surgery has presented the conclusions supported by the evidence with a statement regarding the ideal clinical practice associated with the practice, and designated the classification and level of evidence using criteria used to classify evidence presented in Appendix A.
Note: there are no details about search strategy or search dates.

Implications for practice: many papers have been published on CABG in women and this guidance summarises them in a very useful way.

Publication history information:
Published in 2003 on the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) website

 

]]>

document.body:

The load may be either inanimate - such as a box or a trolley, or animate - a person or an animal. This guidance gives useful practical advice for employers, managers, safety representatives and individual employees on how to reduce the risk of injury from manual handling.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Guidance for nurse staffing in critical care
document.body:
Executive Summary: Every patient, nurse and care facility is different. So providing the right nursing care for critically ill patients is not simply a matter of applying standard nurse-topatient ratios. The skill of the nurse, the complexity of the patient’s needs and the physical environment of care will all influence nursing requirements.

Unit and ward managers need to recognise all the variables before they decide on appropriate staffing. The best people to decide on nursing staffing levels are senior critical care nurses themselves,who have the skills and experience in assessing patient need. As well as measuring individual patient dependency, other aspects of nursing care must be taken into account in determining nursing requirements - for example, the skill mix of nurses and other staff, the needs of patients’ relatives and friends, the number of patient transfers taking nurses away from the ward, risk management and patient safety.

Managers of clinical areas should work closely with the providers of pre- and post-registration education. This will ensure the current and future workforce is educated in response to the needs of the critical care service. Education provision should include appropriate support and assessment in clinical areas, and link lecturers and practice educators to facilitate better support for nursing students. For new staff in critical care,we recommend network-wide induction packages that incorporate core competencies. Health care providers should support their staff in developing personally and professionally, ensuring nurses are actively involved in continuing education, regular appraisal, clinical supervision and have personal development plans.

Health care assistants are now widely involved in the critical care workforce. New roles for any health care worker should only be developed where they can truly meet the needs of the patient - and not where the main purpose is to reduce the level of skilled care available to save costs. Registered nurses remain responsible for the assessment, planning and evaluation of patient care.

The effective use of experienced critical care nurses can greatly improve patient care, and reduce the incidence of complications for patients. Their observational skills can reduce the impact of sudden patient decline, for example, and their holistic approach to care can change the experience of care for both patients and their families.

Access: This leaflet is in PDF format and requires Adobe Acrobat Reader which can be downloaded for free from the Adobe website.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Guideline for the primary care management of male lower urinary tract symptoms
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,MALE REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS,PROSTATE,BENIGN PROSTATIC HYPERPLASIA,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,MALE URINARY INCONTINENCE,MALE BLADDER DISORDERS,PENILE DISORDERS,PROSTATE DISORDERS,TESTICULAR/ SCROTAL DISORDERS,MALE URETERIC DISORDERS,MALE URETHRAL DISORDERS,MALE SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS,FERTILITY,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.description: Diagnosis, treatment and monitoring of Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms (LUTS) in men.
document.body:
Aims: To help with the diagnosis, treatment and monitoring of Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms (LUTS) in men.

Recommendations: evidence is presented for each section:
Assessment and importance of prostate size
The value of flow-rate testing
The value of measuring the postvoid residual volume
Primary care treatment
Men with large prostates and no bothersome symptoms

Intended audience: GPs, nurse practitioners and urologists and patients

Methodology and development: the guideline was prepared by a group working with the advice of the AGREE collaboration. The group reviewed the existing major world guidelines, relevant literature on medical and urological guidelines, and then the background literature for each section.

Implications for practice: this BAUS guideline presents an approach that is in line with world opinions, but is aimed specifically at GPs, nurse practitioners and patients in the UK.

Publication history information:
Published in BJU International 2004; Vol.93 (7): 985-990

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.title: Guidelines for the transport of the critically ill adult
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,ORGANISATIONAL AND OTHER ISSUES,CLINICAL LIBRARY,TRANSFERS,SURGERY,CRITICAL CARE MANAGEMENT,TRANSPORT,INTRAHOSPITAL,INTERHOSPITAL]]>
document.body:
These guidelines apply to the transport of critically ill adult patients in the UK outside of the normal critical care environment. They apply both to patients transferred between hospitals, and to patients moved between departments within a hospital (e.g. from the intensive care unit to magnetic resonance or computed tomography scanner) since the same level of preparation, supervision and care is required for each. They are not intended however to apply to truly mobile intensive care units, as for example, operated by the military services. 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.title: Hand surgery in the UK (2007)
document.publisher: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMA,NURSING,OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY,PHYSIOTHERAPY,SURGERY,HAND AND WRIST,FRACTURE,SOFT TISSUE DISORDERS,HAND AND FOREARM FRACTURES,CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME,SURGERY,HAND & WRIST,SURGERY,LIMBS,SOFT TISSUE TRAUMA]]>
document.body:
The purpose of this report is to improve the quality of care for people who suffer from hand injuries and hand disorders. The report focuses on the future development of hand surgery from its parent specialties of orthopaedic surgery and plastic surgery towards a separate specialty.

The report examines the facilities and organisation required to provide hand surgery care at a high standard, and considers the education, training and careers of those who provide it. It aims to support all of those who deliver hand surgery care by realistically defining the time, manpower and facilities that they require. 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.title: Health Building Notes, Health Technical Memoranda and Model Engineering Specifications
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,THEATRE MANAGEMENT,INFECTION CONTROL,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,BUILDING REGULATIONS,PREVENTION,STAFF SAFETY,THEATRE DESIGN,DAY SURGERY,HANDLING BLOOD,HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES,SURGERY,SHARPS DISPOSAL,CLINICAL WASTE DISPOSAL,EQUIPMENT DECONTAMINATION]]>
document.body:
The Department of Health Estates and Facilities Division Knowledge & Information Portal provides a list of publications available relevant to the provision of the healthcare environment.

The Health Building Notes (HBN) relevant for operating theatres are:

HBN 26 Facilities for surgical procedures
HBN 13 Sterile services
HBN 52 Accommodation for day care Vol. 1 Day surgery unit
HBN 52 Accommodation for day care Vol. 2 Endoscopy unit
HBN 10-02 Day surgery facilities

The Health Technical Memoranda (HTM) relevant for operating theatres are:

HTM 07-01 Safe Management of Healthcare Waste (free from DOH)
HTM 02-10 Medical gas pipeline systems: Part B Operational management
HTM 2010 Sterilization Part 1 Management policy but this publication will be superseded by HTM 01-01 and HTM 01-02 in due course.

Note: More information about new HTM policies is available from the Health Facilities Management Association


Model Engineering Specifications (MES):


MES C15 Small steam sterilizers for surgical instruments
MES 30 Washer-disinfectors for surgical instruments
MES C31 Small washer-disinfectors for surgical instruments
MES C32 Automated endoscope reprocessors for flexible endoscopes

HBNs, HTMs and MESs can be purchased in hard copy from The Stationery Office Bookstore

Some HTM and HBN executive summaries are freely available from the Department of Health Knowledge & Information Portal but registration is required.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: High quality care for all: our journey so far
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,PATIENT SAFETY,INNOVATION,QUALITY IMPROVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,PRIMARY CARE SERVICES,ACUTE SERVICES,SERVICE SECTORS,QUALITY AND MONITORING,PUBLIC HEALTH,SERVICES,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,ORGANISATIONS,CHANGE MANAGEMENT,LEADING IMPROVEMENT,ORGANISATIONAL DEVELOPMENT,ORGANISATIONAL CULTURE,INNOVATION AND IMPROVEMENT,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,2009 JUNE]]>
document.body:
This report, published by Lord Darzi, examines the progress that has been made since "High Quality Care for All" was published in 2008. Across each dimension of quality - patient experience, patient safety and clinical effectiveness - Lord Darzi found that there has been real progress with patients already seeing the difference.

Major improvements highlighted in the report include the opening of 50 new GP led Health Centres, the introduction of personal care plan for 9.3 million patients with long term conditions and the growth in keyhole surgery. The focus on quality has moved up the agenda for staff and organisations, supported by the promotion of innovation through the introduction of tools and funds such as NHS Evidence, the Innovation Fund and the Challenge Prizes.

The report also outlines plans to drive up the quality agenda even further and free up clinicians time to do this. Proposals include:

  • Refining of targets based on evidence - we want to free up front line staff so they can focus on delivering high quality care. We will remove the obsolete 13 week outpatient and 26 week inpatient performance targets, as well as reviewing data collections across the board in order to reduce the burden on front line staff;
  • Clinician budget ownership - we will look at giving clinical teams in the acute sector ownership of their budget. Allowing clinical teams to manage their budgets will promote entrepreneurship and innovative delivery of services built around the needs of the patient.
  • Peer review accreditation system - we will create a new voluntary peer review system in which clinicians will judge the standard of their peers in order to drive up quality and achieve a 'gold standard' of care. The system will be developed through close collaboration and consultation with the relevant partners and stakeholders.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.title: How can nursing services increase day case rates for elective surgery?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,THEATRE MANAGEMENT,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,EFFICIENCY,DAY SURGERY,SURGERY]]>
document.body:
This issue of Policy+ examines the evidence to look at whether there is potential for increasing rates of day case surgery for procedures identified as suitable, but where reported uptake has been low. The briefing focuses on laparoscopic cholecystectomy (gall bladder removal) as an example of a procedure where there is great variation in day case rates.

Policy+ is a publication from the National Nursing Research Unit "which aims to deliver brief overviews of evidence related to current policies affecting the nursing workforce in England, the wider United Kingdom and the rest of the world."

The National Nursing Research Unit is part of the Division of Health and Social Care Research, King's College London.

document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England Patient Liaison Group
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,CLINICAL GOVERNANCE,CLINICAL AUDIT,SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,PERIOPERATIVE PRACTICE]]>
document.description: Questions from the Royal College of Surgeons of England Patient Liaison Group to help theatre teams check how patient-friendly their services are and to give ideas for audit.
document.body:
This guide from the Royal College of Surgeons of England Patient Liaison Group aims to help theatre teams make the most of the patient’s journey through elective surgery.
Questions have been devised to help teams check how patient-friendly their services are and to give ideas for audit. The guide has been trialled by surgical teams and found to be useful. All the questions are from the patient’s perspective
The stages used are:
  1. Access to the clinic
  2. Outpatient consultations
  3. Pre-operative investigations and tests
  4. Anaesthesia and pain relief
  5. Admission to ward or day surgery unit
  6. Surgery
  7. Post-operative period
  8. Discharge, rehabilitation and follow-up care

document.body:
Best Evidence Topics or BETs are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

Best Evidence Topics or BETs were developed in the Emergency Department of Manchester Royal Infirmary, UK, to provide rapid evidence-based answers to real-life clinical questions, using a systematic approach to reviewing the literature.

They are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

document.title: Infection control services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,THEATRE MANAGEMENT,INFECTION CONTROL,PREVENTION,INFECTIONS,STAFF SAFETY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,PREOPERATIVE PREPARATIONS,SITE & SKIN PREPARATION,ANTIBIOTIC PROPHYLAXIS,PRION DISEASE,NEEDLESTICK INJURY,HANDLING BLOOD,HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES,BACTERIAL,VIRAL,HAND HYGIENE,PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT,SHARPS DISPOSAL,CLINICAL WASTE DISPOSAL,EQUIPMENT DECONTAMINATION,ISOLATION AND COHORTING POLICIES,CLEANING,DISINFECTION,STERILISATION]]>
document.description: A group of consultant microbiologists providing expert infection control advice and information to both the NHS and private sector.
document.body:
Infection Control Services is a programme run by consultant microbiologists at University College London Hospitals working closely with infection control nurses who have local responsibility in their hospitals.
The aim is to maintain an effective programme for the prevention of hospital-acquired infection and the containment of infections brought into the hospitals by patients, staff or visitors by setting best-practice protocols agreed at a local level and monitoring performance.
The service provides a comprehensive online infection control manual, useful for both beginners and advanced practitioners, organised into the following topics:
  • Principles of infection control (including hand hygiene, uniforms, isolation policies and outbreak management)
  • Control of specific communicable diseases (including MRSA, bloodborne viruses and Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies)
  • Occupational health such as sharps injuries
  • Cleaning and disinfection
  • Policies for specialised areas including operating theatres
  • Clinical practice policies
  • Antibiotic guidelines

The website also features a section for forms, information sheets and protocols including downloadable precautionary patient isolation notices, a personal protective equipment information sheet and sharps injury forms.

Access: freely available

 

]]>

document.body:
This report has been written by a multidisciplinary (and multi-professional) group convened by the Intercollegiate Cancer Committee. It reviews the purpose of multidiscipliinary team working and takes account of the evidence on the effectiveness of teams and the factors which underpin effective team working. Importantly the report identifies the need for further work to develop measures to assess how team functioning can best be assessed. The need for health professionals to be trained in team working is also emphasised.
