document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Intravenous magnesium sulphate and sotalol for prevention of atrial fibrillation after coronary artery bypass surgery: a systematic review and economic evaluation
document.body:
Objectives: To assess the clinical and cost-effectiveness of magnesium sulphate compared with sotalol, and to assess the clinical effectiveness of magnesium sulphate compared with placebo in the prevention of atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients who have had a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG).

Data sources: Major electronic databases were searched from December 2003 to May 2007.

Review methods: Selected studies were assessed, subjected to data extraction using a standard template and quality assessment using published criteria. A simple short-term economic model was developed, informed by a systematic review of economic evaluations and populated with data from a review of costing/resource-use studies and other published studies. The cost-effectiveness of magnesium sulphate as prophylaxis was estimated for a set of base-case assumptions and the robustness of these results was assessed using deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analysis.

Results: Twenty-two papers met the inclusion criteria reporting 15 trials which all compared magnesium sulphate with placebo or control. They ranged in size from 15 to 176 patients randomised, and were conducted in Europe, the USA and Canada. The standard of reporting was generally poor, with details of key methodological attributes difficult to elucidate. No trials were identified that specifically aimed to compare magnesium sulphate with sotalol. Of 1070 patients in the pooled magnesium group, 230 (21%) developed postoperative AF, compared with 307 of 1031 (30%) patients in the placebo or (control) group. Meta-analysis using a fixed-effects model generated a pooled odds ratio (OR) that was significantly less than 1.0 [OR = 0.65, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.53 to 0.79, test for overall effect p < 0.0001], but with statistically significant heterogeneity (I2 = 63.4%, p = 0.0005). Two randomised controlled trials (RCTs) were notable as they had relatively lower ORs in favour of magnesium sulphate. When these were removed from the analyses the pooled OR remained statistically significant, but heterogeneity no longer remained significant. These two studies tended to impart a highly significant reduction in the odds of AF to whichever subgroup they were analysed in. When studies were ordered by total duration of prophylaxis, an apparent relationship between duration and odds of AF was evident, with decreasing odds of AF as duration of prophylaxis increased. This was confirmed by linear regression analysis (R2 = 0.743, p < 0.001). When the data were grouped into three classes according to duration, a statistically significant intervention effect was only present for the longest duration (OR = 0.12, 95% CI 0.06 to 0.23, p = 0.00001). Statistically significant intervention effects were associated with the initiation of prophylaxis 12 hours or more before surgery (OR 0.26; 95% CI 0.16 to 0.44, test for overall effect p = 0.00001, fixed-effects model) and less than 12 hours before surgery or during the surgery itself (OR = 0.73, 95% CI 0.56 to 0.97, test for overall effect p = 0.03, fixed-effects model), but not when prophylaxis was initiated at the end of surgery or postsurgery (OR = 0.85, 95% CI 0.59, 1.22, p = 0.37, fixed-effects model). When studies were ordered by total dose of intravenous magnesium sulphate (<25 g), the odds of AF were independent of the dose. A notable exception was that for a total dose of 9 g magnesium sulphate; here the odds of AF were significantly reduced relative to the control group, although this may be explained by the fact that these studies had excluded patients who were on antiarrhythmic drugs and so may have been at higher risk of AF. Sixty-three potentially relevant references about cost-effectiveness were identified, but no economic evaluations of intravenous magnesium alone as prophylaxis against AF following CABG, compared with sotalol as prophylaxis or no prophylaxis, were identified. Studies reporting resource use by patients with AF following CABG suggest that while AF significantly increased inpatient stays, by up to 2.3 days in the intensive care unit (ICU) and 3.4 days on the ward, differences in length of stay and costs between patients receiving prophylaxis and those not receiving prophylaxis were not statistically significant. In the base-case analysis, magnesium sulphate prophylaxis resulted in 0.081 fewer cases of AF at an incremental cost of £2.55. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) was £32 per AF case avoided. The estimated difference in average length of stay between the prophylaxis and no-prophylaxis strategies was only 0.24 days, despite a large assumed difference of 3 days for patients experiencing AF in each group (1 extra day in the ICU and 2 extra days on the ward). In a deterministic sensitivity analysis the greatest variation in ICERs was observed for input parameters relating to the baseline risk of AF following CABG and the effectiveness of prophylaxis, cost of prophylaxis and the resource consequences of postoperative AF. The largest ICER (£2092) in the sensitivity analysis was associated with increasing the length of patients' preoperative stay. In the base case it was assumed that admission routines would be identical under both strategies. However, patients receiving prophylaxis by intravenous infusion may have longer preoperative stays. In a probabilistic analysis the majority of the simulations were associated with improved outcomes (in this case fewer cases of AF), but also higher costs. Prophylaxis was the dominant strategy (better outcome at lower cost) in about 41% of the simulations using the base-case assumptions. Under an alternative scenario where patients receiving prophylaxis are admitted for longer before their operation, to receive their initial infusion, the proportion of simulations where prophylaxis dominates fell to around 5%. The probability of being cost-effective was 99% at a willingness to pay (WTP) threshold of £2000 per AF case avoided and 100% at a WTP threshold of £5000 per AF case avoided under the base-case assumptions. Under the alternative scenario of longer preoperative stays the probability of being cost-effective at these two threshold values fell to 48% and 93%, respectively. It is unclear what the appropriate decision threshold should be, given that this model used intermediate rather than final outcomes.

Conclusions: No RCTs were identified that specifically aimed to compare intravenous magnesium with sotalol as prophylaxis for AF in patients undergoing CABG. Intravenous magnesium, compared with placebo or control, is effective in preventing postoperative AF, as confirmed by a statistically significant intervention effect based on pooled analysis of 15 RCTs. It was also found that AF was less likely to occur when a longer duration of prophylaxis was used, and the earlier that prophylaxis is started; however, this finding was associated with two RCTs that had more favourable results than the other trials. No clear relationship between dose and AF was observed, although a lower constant dose rate was associated with the lowest odds of AF. Further research should investigate the relationship between dose, dose rate, duration of prophylaxis, timing of initiation of therapy and patient characteristics, such as degree of risk for AF. This will provide stronger evidence for the optimum delivery of intravenous magnesium in patients undergoing CABG. In the base-case analysis in the economic model, magnesium sulphate prophylaxis reduced the number of postoperative AF cases at a modest increase in cost. The results of the economic analysis are highly sensitive to variation in certain key parameters. Prophylaxis is less likely to be a cost-effective option if it requires changes in admission routines that result in longer preoperative stays than would be the case without prophylaxis.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Introduction to Vascular Surgery
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGICAL PROCEDURES,SURGERY,SURGERY,VARICOSE VEINS,VENOUS DISEASE,BLOOD VESSELS & LYMPHATICS,ANEURYSMS,CAROTID ARTERY DISEASE,PERIPHERAL ARTERIAL DISEASE,RENAL ARTERY STENOSIS,ABDOMINAL AORTIC,LIMB ISCHAEMIA,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction to Vascular Surgery

Welcome to the vascular surgery section of the Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia.

The Library goes live at a time of great change to both the delivery of surgical practice in general and training for the next generation of surgeons. There is no better example of this than the provision of specialist vascular surgery in the UK. 
There has been a wealth of information from multi-centre randomised controlled clinical trials over the past decade in virtually all major areas of vascular surgery. This has provided excellent evidence in certain areas of practice and suggested alternatives and modifications to practice in others.
New light has been shed on interventions for carotid atherosclerosis (including surgery for both symptomatic and asymptomatic disease); the role of endovascular repair for abdominal aortic aneurysms; and new treatments for varicose veins including endovenous laser, foam or radiofreqency ablation. In addition, rapid developments in the field of cardiovascular research have provided new indications for pharmacological intervention.
Such rapid development can be daunting for the surgeon and confusing for the patient, and this is why areas of the Library are extensively subdivided. ‘Guidance’ provides links to official publications for such as those from NICE; ‘Evidence’ links to scientific studies; ‘Reference’ provides general perioperative documentation, and importantly ‘Patient Information’ provides information free from specific medical terms.
In this manner it is hoped that not only members of the surgical team – surgeons, surgical assistants, anaesthetists, operating department practitioners and nurses - but also members of the public will find this a useful resource.
However, one word of caution: in sharing the very latest data from scientific studies one also shares their inherent uncertainty and the ‘correct’ intervention will therefore vary from patient to patient.
The aim of the information in the Library is not to determine surgical management, but to inform.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Investigation of the performance of the 3M Capital Hip System
document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,TRAUMA,PROSTHETICS,ARTHROPLASTY,SURGERY,SURGERY,LIMBS,PELVIS & HIP,HIP REPLACEMENT,HIP AND PELVIS]]>
document.description: A report describing an investigation into the performance of the 3M Capital Cemented Hip System.
document.body:
This report describes an investigation into the performance of the 3M Capital Cemented Hip System. The investigation was commissioned by the Department of Health and 3M Healthcare and lead by the Clinical Effectiveness Unit of The Royal College of Surgeons of England.

Contents

Aims and objectives: there were three main objectives to the study-

  • "to describe the 'survival' curve for the femoral component of the Capital Hip System in the entire cohort of patients in the UK who received this prosthesis.
  • to describe survival separately for modular and monobloc femoral prostheses.
  • to identify 'risk factors' associated with failure."

Methods: a description of the methodology, using a retrospective case series design, sets out how information was extracted from four main sources-

  • details from case notes
  • patient X-rays
  • responses from patient questionnaires
  • responses from surgeon questionnaires

Results: see full report for a detailed description of the observations.

Discussion and conclusions: see full report for a summary of results, lessons learnt and conclusions.

Recommendations: the key recommendations related to-

  • the design and clinical evaluation of hip prostheses
  • aspects of orthopaedic practice
  • lessons learnt during the investigation relevant to future investigations

Related documents: a companion leaflet for patients complements this report.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Islet transplantation in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.body:
Conclusions:
Evidence on outcomes of islet transplant is limited by small patient numbers, short followup, and lack of standardised reporting. (These issues are being addressed by the National Institute of Health (NIH) funded Collaborative Islet Transplant Registry.) Data are lacking on long-term durability of the procedure, effects on diabetic complications, or long-term consequences of immunosuppression. Evidence is insufficient for comparison with whole-organ pancreas transplant.

Methods:
Prospective trials of allogeneic islet transplant for treatment of type 1 diabetes were selected that reported glycemic outcomes and/or adverse events at least 3 months post-procedure, and used the Edmonton or a subsequently developed islet transplant protocol.

Results: See structured abstract for details.

Citation: Prepared by the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association Technology Evaluation Center for the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. AHRQ Publication No. 04-E017-1, August 2004

Publication history information: Published on the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, USA website in August 2004.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Joint Declaration of CPME – Eucomed on cooperation between physicians and the medical technology industry
document.publisher: Standing Committee of European Doctors (CPME) and Eucomed
document.body:
The medical profession, represented by the Standing Committee of European Doctors (CPME), and the medical technology industry, represented by Eucomed, aware of their responsibilities vis-à-vis patients and society, consider it essential to establish guidelines on the relationship between the medical profession and the medical technology industry.

Cooperation between the medical profession and the medical technology industry is both important and necessary in the development of medical technology and for the appropriate use of medical devices in healthcare. Collaboration is required at all stages of medical device development, as well as when they become available for use. The medical technology industry should make product training available to the physicians. Use of medical devices must be safe, efficient and useful for the patient.

It is of vital importance that the collaboration between physicians and the medical technology industry is based on respect for ethical principles, the rights of patients and the expectations of society, and is transparent whilst ensuring the independence of both parties when conducting their activities.

Access: Available to the general public. 

]]>

document.body:
The Multimedia Manual of Cardiothoracic Surgery (MMCTS) is an online open-access manual of cardiovascular and thoracic surgical procedures. Authored by experts in the field, MMCTS includes how-to descriptions along with informative videos (view with RealPlayer) and drawings illustrating all the vital aspects. Peer-reviewed comments are also posted about new alternative techniques.

Access: Available to the general public

This resource does not give a comprehensive overview of the procedure discussed but provides an insight into an individual surgeon's approach.

Access:  Available to the general public. Flash Player required.

Part of this educational programme is the freely available SAGES Educational Video Library. All videos were submitted to or presented at past SAGES annual meetings and cover the following categories:

  • Bariatric Surgery
  • Diagnosis and Staging
  • Endocrine Surgery
  • Esophagus
  • Flexible Endoscopy
  • Hernia and Abdomen
  • Large Intestine
  • Liver, Biliary Tract and Pancreas
  • NOTES
  • Pediatric Surgery
  • Retroperitoneal Surgery: Spine and Vascular
  • Small Intestine
  • Spleen
  • Stomach
  • Techniques and Research
  • Thoracic
  • Urology

Access: Available to the general public.

    ]]>

document.body:
The information in this leaflet is relevant to any health care worker who may be exposed to latex in the course of their work, but it does not cover risks to patients. 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Learn cell salvage
document.body:
This course helps nurses, operating department practitioners (ODPs), perfusionists and laboratory staff learn the background to Intra-operative Cell Salvage (ICS), prior to attending a classroom course.

It is also valuable for surgeons and anaesthetists as information essential to the prescription and application of ICS.

The course was developed in conformity with standards developed by Queens Medical Centre NHS Trust and Skills for Health.

 

]]>

document.title: Left laparoscopic partial nephrectomy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ URINARY TRACT,SURGERY,SURGERY,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,TRANSPLANTATION]]>
document.body:
Uro Today provides an education library of urological surgical interventions. The library contains slide shows of specific procedures with incorporated video clips showing specific steps of the operation performed.

This resource does not give a comprehensive overview of the procedure discussed but provides an insight into an individual surgeon's approach.

Access:  Available to the general public. Flash Player required.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Levels of critical care for adult patients
document.body:
This document describes the levels of care required by critically ill patients. It specifically does not comment on, or recommend, staffing establishments or skill mix in relation to each level. It follows the approach of allocating levels of care to patients according to clinical need alone and disregards location or the prevailing nurse to patient ratio. 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.body:
Online access to the lung cancer handbook is provided by The Clifton F. Mountain Foundation for Education and Research in Lung Cancer. The manual provides a comprehensive resource for classification and staging of lung cancer, adhering to international consensus.

Access: freely available

 

]]>

document.body:
Part of the Annual Evidence Update of the 2008 Lung Cancer National Knowledge Week. Part 2 focuses on the treatment and disease management of lung cancer. document.body:
Framework for practice from the British Association of Perinatal Medicine about the management of acute in-utero transfers, to be used as a guide for local guidelines. Please note this refers only to acute cases, not elective transfer.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Management of continence - national audit of continence care (NACC) 2010 report
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,URINARY TRACT,BLADDER,ANAL CANAL & PERIANAL,ANAL INCONTINENCE,URINARY INCONTINENCE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,MALE URINARY INCONTINENCE,URGE INCONTINENCE,STRESS INCONTINENCE,OTHER INCONTINENCE,MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This audit is a two year project covering multiple care settings including primary and acute care. Urinary and faecal incontinence affect many people, especially those who are older and in long-term care. The audit aims to improve continence care by monitoring the implementation of relevant NICE guidelines and providing evidence-based criteria for care providers to compare the quality of their continence care against. It also provides examples of high quality care to aid commissioners.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Management of erectile dysfunction
document.body:
Aims: to update the 1996 Report on the Treatment of Organic Erectile Dysfunction by the Erectile Dysfunction Clinical Guideline Panel. The report is intended to provide medical practitioners with a consensus of principles and strategies for the management of erectile dysfunction.

Recommendations: evidence is presented for each of the following chapters including:
Non invasive therapies
  • Phosphodiesterase Type 5 (PDE5) Inhibitors
  • Alprostadil Intra-uretheral Suppositories
  • Intracavernous Vascoactive Drug Injection Therapy
  • Vacuum Constriction Devices
  • Herbal therapies
Surgical therapies
  • Penile Prosthesis Implantation
  • Vascular Surgery

Intended audience: clinicians and patients

Methodology and development: The guideline was prepared by the Erectile Dysfunction Clinical Guideline Update Panel of the American Urological Association convened in 2000. A literature search of MEDLINE was conducted from 2000 to February 2004 and references were evaluated to provide evidence for selected outcomes.

Implications for practice:
These AUA guidelines provide a comprehensive review of treatment guidelines as well as guidance on initial management and discussion of treatment options with patients and managing erectile dysfunction in the presence of co-morbidities such as cardiovascular disease.

Publication history information:
Latest update published in May 2006, reviewed and validity confirmed 2009.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Management of grown-up congenital heart disease
document.description: Cardiology guidelines including a section on surgical treatment
document.body:
Aims: to discuss the special healthcare needs of grown-ups with congenital heart disease including common principles of management, the need for specialist centres, models of network care delivery and training requirements for medical staff. The second part of the report provides structured guides for the management of common lesions.

Recommendations: recommendations for surgical management are presented in section 5 and cover:

  • General planning of the operation
  • Specific surgical challenges
  • Preservation of myocardial function
  • Blood salvage techniques
  • Redo sternotomy incision
  • Pulmonary vascular bed abnormalities
  • Aortopulmonary collateral circulation
  • Anaesthesia and post operative care
Intended audience:
The guidelines are designed to assist the practicing clinician in a ‘user friendly’ manner and to promote collaboration between the various professional groups involved in the care of adolescents and adults with congenital heart disease.

Methodology and development:
Developed by the Task Force on the Management of Grown Up Congenital Heart Disease of the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) and supervised and endorsed by the ESC Committee for Practice Guidelines.

Implications for practice:
Though the majority of the guidelines relate to cardiology, the section on surgical treatment is important.

Publication history information:
Published in the European Heart Journal 2003; 24 (11): 1035-1084

Access:  Available to the general public as HTML or Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Management of priapism
document.description: A consensus of principles and strategies for the care of priapism
document.body:
Aims: to provide medical practitioners with a consensus of principles and strategies for the care of priapism based on professional literature, clinical experience and expert opinion.

Publication history information: latest update published in 2003 on the AUA website, reviewed and validated in 2008.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Manual Handling Assessment Charts (MAC)
document.description: A tool designed to help health and safety inspectors assess the most common risk factors in lifting, carrying and team handling operations.
document.body:
The Manual Handling Assessment Charts (MAC) is a tool designed to help health and safety inspectors assess the most common risk factors in lifting (and lowering), carrying and team handling operations. Employers, safety officers, safety representatives and others may also find the MAC useful to identify highrisk manual handling operations and help them complete their risk assessments.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Matching Michigan - Minimising central venous catheter associated bloodstream infections
document.body:
Matching Michigan is a two-year quality improvement project based on a model developed in the United States which, over 18 months, saved around 1,500 patient lives. It took place at Intensive Care Units (ICUs) in Michigan and introduced data definitions, technical interventions - changes in clinical practice - and non-technical interventions - linked to leadership, teamwork and culture change. When these interventions are applied together these have been shown to reduce Central Venous Catheter Bloodstream Infections (CVC-BSIs).


]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Measuring and Using Outcomes from Surgery
document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England
document.body:
The Royal College of Surgeons of England is leading on publishing information about the success of individual operations. Called outcome data, this information can be used by surgeons, patients and hospitals to ultimately improve safety and quality. This briefing outlines the background and views of the College on how success in surgery should be measured and how outcome data should be used to improve surgical care. 

 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.body:
This medical device alert relates to DePuy ASR hip replacement implants.

Action: do not implant DePuy ASR hip replacement, return all unused implants to the manufacturer, inform relevant patients about the recall and schedule follow-up visit.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Medical Device Alert: Diathermy (electrosurgical) cables manufactured by Unomedical
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.body:
This medical device alert relates to certain batches of cables, used to connect Unomedical electrosurgical instruments to generators, which have been supplied in mislabelled boxes.

Boxes labelled with the code 3508M may contain a cable with the code 3405M, or vice versa. The cables can be distinguished from each other because they are colour coded:

  • green for product code 3405M
  • red for product code 3508M.

Action: do not use affected devices, follow manufacturer's Field Notice and contact the manufacturer for compensation or replacements.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Medical Device Alert: LIFEPAK 20/20e defibrillator/monitor, manufactured by Medtronic/Physio-Control (MDA/2010/070)
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.body:
This device alert relates to problems with the power source in the LIFEPAK 20/20e defibrillator/monitor, affecting its performance.

Action: assess the need for back-up/alternative device, read the manufacturer's Field Safety Notice, connect device to AC mains power and continuously charge DC battery. The manufacturer has contacted affected customers.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.body:
This medical devices alert requires immediate action. It relates to all models and lot numbers of silicone gel filled breast implants manufactured by the French company Poly Implant Prothese (PIP). The alert is due to a recent inspection which found that a different silicone composition to that which is allowed. Further information on patient management will be produced as soon as possible.

This medical device alert relates to lots WO 25700 – WO 25702 which may delaminate on the patient side with the possibility of fibres entering the tracheal stoma.

Medline Plus is a service from the US National Library of Medicine. The videos are supplied to the US National Library of Medicine by OR-Live.com and therefore direct links from NHS Evidence to individual videos are not permitted. You will be able to access all videos through the 'Link to website' above.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Metal-on-metal total hip resurfacing
document.body:
Author’s objectives:
This assessment by the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association aims to evaluate available evidence on the benefits and harms of hip resurfacing (HR) as an alternative to total hip arthroplasty (THA) in comparable patients.

Author’s conclusions:
A substantial body of evidence shows HR is associated with consistent and strong symptomatic and functional improvements at follow-up times up to 5 years. HR results are comparable to those obtained with current generation THA at similar time points in patients younger than 65 years of age. HR differs procedurally from total THA in conserving a patient's native femoral bone neck. When HR patients subsequently require revision to THA, the operation is technically similar to primary THA and likely avoids the complications of revision of a primary THA. Thus, the benefits comprise initial HR results as good as THA and a simpler revision to THA when needed. Although longer-term (i.e., greater than 5 years) data on the relative durability of HR compared to THA are unavailable, current evidence is sufficient to conclude that HR is a safe and effective means for initial surgical treatment in younger, properly selected patients who require a total hip replacement. Primary use of HR in the indicated patient subpopulation thus defers standard THA.

Publication history:
Blue Cross Blue Shield Association, June 2007. TEC Assessment Vol. 22(3)

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: MHRA medical device alerts (MDAs)
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.description: MDAs replace the previous types of safety warnings (Hazard Notice, Safety Notice, Device Alert, Advice Notice, Safety Notices and Pacemaker Technical Notes).
document.body:
Medical Devices Alerts (MDAs) were introduced on 1 January 2003, to replace the previous types of safety warnings (Hazard Notice, Safety Notice, Device Alert, Advice Notice, Safety Notices and Pacemaker Technical Notes).

MDAs are distributed to the NHS via the Department of Health's Safety Alert Broadcast System (SABS). MDAs remain valid unless they are updated or withdrawn. They are reviewed once they are five years old (and subsequently every five years) and the lists on this website are amended accordingly.

 

]]>

This section of the MHRA provides access to information on how to report suspected safety problems with medicines, medical devices, blood and blood components:

Medicines - suspected adverse drug reactions and suspected defects in medicinal products

Devices - any adverse incident involving a medical device or its instructions for use especially if it led to, or could have led to, death, life-threatening illness or injury 

Blood - Serious Adverse Blood Reactions & Events (SABRE)

Please note: registration is required to use some of the online reporting forms

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Anaesthesia and fast track cardiac surgery
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Anaesthesia and fast track cardiac surgeryBy Dr Bharathi Varadarajan, Topic Advisor, NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care and Consultant Cardiac Anaesthetist, Royal Victoria Hospitals, Belfast Health and Social Care Trust, Belfast

Cite this resource


Introduction

Fast track cardiac surgery (FTCS) has been practised since 19741,2,3,4,5,6,. In FTCS the perioperative care pathway swiftly progresses from admission through surgery to discharge home whilst at all times promoting the health and safety of the patient7,8,9. Early discontinuation of respiratory support and sedation, coupled with return to the awake state and normal breathing after FTCS is crucial. The combination of optimal anaesthetic technique (amnesia, analgesia and haemodynamic stability), adequate myocardial protection, short cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) time and safe surgical procedure allows almost all groups of patients to be extubated safely. In FTCS, patients are woken up after cardiac surgery as soon as near-normothermia, normal pulmonary function and haemodynamic stability are achieved in the absence of any surgical or coagulopathic bleeding. This results in stepping down of nursing care from intensive (Level 3) to high dependency (Level 2) care. At the time of extubation, patients should be comfortable, pain-free and have good muscle power without shivering and agitation. Among other benefits, this enables them to establish oral feeding and early ambulation.

Fast-tracking of cardiac surgery is based on physiological variables; hence ventilator support may be discontinued at the earliest postoperative time when near-normal pre-operative physiological variables are regained7. Many centres have criteria, guidelines and protocols for patient selection, early extubation, and transfer to step down care (Level 2) and discharge from hospital to suit their institutional practice; some of these have been set up since 19742,4,7,8. All patients who are healthy, young, male, have good left ventricular function, who undergo elective cardiac surgery that is uncomplicated with short CPB time and are warmed adequately during the operative time are suitable to undergo the fast-track procedure. Addition of heparin-bonded CPB circuits, cell savers, warming blankets and fluid warmers might accelerate the process2,3,4,5,6,32,33.


Anaesthesia for FTCS

There is no single best technique, but there are certain consistent principles when delivering anaesthesia for FTCS. Short-acting drugs with the least accumulation in blood are used to facilitate early extubation. Propofol has been shown to be the safest anaesthetic induction agent in many studies6,10,11. Benzodiazepines like midazolam, temazepam, and opioid drugs like fentanyl, sufentanyl, alfentanyl and the ultra-fast acting opioid remifentanil with shorter onset and offset time have been used for amnesia and to attenuate the stress response to anaesthesia and surgery with good outcome. Drugs have been used in boluses or as continuous infusions with or without inhalational agents and regional techniques have also been described12,13,14,15. Muscle relaxants like pancuronium, vecuronium and rocuronium have all been used in FTCS14. Morphine is the standard drug used for postoperative pain relief, and single dose NSAIDS like ketorolac, parecoxib16 have also been used to produce opioid-sparing effects immediately after cardiac surgery. Regional techniques like intrathecal opioids and high thoracic epidural techniques have been used successfully as well17,18,19. However, the side effects of opioids and NSAIDS20,21 and complications associated with regional techniques in the setting of anticoagulation and cardiopulmonary bypass22,23,24,25,27 remain unresolved posing a danger to patients’ smooth progress after cardiac surgery. Postoperative nausea and vomiting should be addressed and avoided aggressively to avert the problems of aspiration in the immediate postoperative period, which may break the smooth chain of events in FTCS.


Outcomes

FTCS may be beneficial both to patients and to healthcare organisations. Early extubation after cardiac surgery hastens the return of normal ciliary function of the respiratory mucosa, and decreases the incidence of nosocomial infections26. Cheng et al5 showed a reduction in intrapulmonary shunt in patients who were extubated early. Fast-tracking permits early return to normal physiology including normothermia, spontaneous breathing with intact cough reflex, early oral intake and mobilisation, return to ward atmosphere and early hospital discharge. This reduces anxiety and stress for both patient and family. Advantages to healthcare organisations include increased availability of intensive care bed time, improved turnover of patients through cardiac surgery, efficient utilisation of resources and cost containment. Postoperative infections and complications are minimised, providing huge cost savings in terms of both expenditure and litigation. However, any risks involved with FTCS that might endanger the health or safety of patients should be highlighted and reviewed. Potential adverse outcomes include myocardial ischaemia, agitation, reduced mental alertness and aspiration of stomach contents, premature extubation causing respiratory compromise and re-intubation.

Stumbling blocks to FTCS include the systemic inflammatory response provoked by CPB and the side effects of short-acting anaesthetic agents, but perhaps the most frequently encountered obstacle remains a lack of awareness of the fast-track procedure among multidisciplinary teams working in cardiac surgery4,5. A built-in, multidisciplinary, coordinated approach after extubation at different levels of care is essential if one is to see the benefit of FTCS5. Differences in clinical practice and the organisation of intensive care units and centres have a subtle but significant impact on this approach28. Overnight Intensive Recovery (OIR) for cardiac surgical patients has been in practice since 1983; it is worth a try and outcomes may be rewarding both to patients and to the healthcare organisation 29,30.

The term ‘ultra’ is used in reference to fast track surgery, when patients are woken up almost immediately after cardiac surgery, and this is gaining popularity over FTCS30,31. The drive to contain resources and cost, ever-changing technology, and progress in research has popularised this technique.


Protocol-led early extubation after cardiac surgery
This applies to adult cardiac surgical patients Grade I & II intubations. Anaesthetist must be present for grade III and at the time of extubation.

On arrival in CSICU
  • Head up position at 30°
  • Start morphine infusion at 1-2 mg.hr-1 unless contraindicated
  • Administer morphine 5-10 mg as 2 mg boluses at a time without altering haemodynamics
  • Check with anaesthetist and wean remifentanil and stop after 1 hour
  • Warm patient actively to >36.5° with Bair hugger set at 40°C
  • Check blood gas and wean ventilation (Pressure support and Peep) and FiO2 as required to achieve CPAP mode, Tidal volume of 7-10ml.kg-1, PaO2>10 Kpa with FiO2 <50% and PaCO2 ~ 4.5-6.0 Kpa 
  • Wean inotropes maintaining adequate blood pressure MAP>60 and <90, HR >60 and <110 mm.Hg
  • Treat dysrhythmias as appropriate
  • After 1 hour if chest tube drainage is < 100 ml.hr-1, then reverse the muscle relaxant with Neostigmine 2.5 mgs with glycopyrrolate 0.5 mgs. Check with the anaesthetist in charge
Stage 1
  • MAP >60 and <90 mmHg, HR >60 and <100 mm. Hg without significant dysrhythmia
  • Inotropic support static or reducing; Urine output > 0.5 ml.kg-1.hr-1
  • Chest tube drainage <100 mg/hr-1 ; Temperature >36.5º C and <37.5º C Pressure support =15 cmH2O, and a TV ~7 mls.kg-1
  • ABG PaO2 >10 KPa on FiO2 50% and PaCO2 4.5-6.0 Kpa, BE > -5, lactate <3 mmol.l-1
  • CXR taken and examined by doctor
Stage 2
Decision to extubate: Decision to wait and review:
  1. Adequate handgrip and leg movements
  2. Position the patient upright and suction the throat and lungs
  3. Wean propofol sedation; ensure adequate analgesia
  4. Inform doctor in charge and extubate applying face-mask
  5. O2 concentration adjust to keep SPO2 >95%
  6. Assess ABG in 30 mins
  1. Reassess on an hourly basis
  2. Check with the anaesthetist in charge
Pearls of fast-track extubation
  • Try switching to other modes of ventilation when patients are ready and/or stimulate the patient to breathe
  • Shivering should be stopped with pethidine 25-50 mgs I.V.
  • Don’t administer muscle relaxant boluses without informing the anaesthetist
  • Earlier weaning of remifentanil facilitates early extubation
  • If in doubt discuss with the doctor at any time of the protocol

M Doherty, Jan Gordon, B Varadarajan, RVH, Belfast. UK



ICU discharge criteria5
  • Alert and cooperative patient
  • No inotropic support and no significant arrhythmia
  • Adequate ventilation (arterial oxygen tension >80 mm Hg (10.5Kpa), arterial carbon dioxide tension <60 mm Hg (8.0Kpa), arterial oxygen saturation >90%, inspired oxygen fraction equal or lesser than 0.5 by face mask)
  • Chest tube drainage <50 ml/hour in 2 hours
  • Urine output >0.5 ml • kg-1 • hour-1
  • No active seizure
Hospital discharge criteria5
  • Haemodynamically stable
  • Stable cardiac rhythm
  • Non-infected incisions and afebrile patient
  • Ability to void, bowel movements
  • Independent ambulation and feeding

Current Evidence

  1. Myles P S, Daly D J, Djaiani G, Lee A, Cheng D C. A systematic review of the safety and effectiveness of fast-track cardiac anesthesia. Centre for Reviews and Dissemination. Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE). [Link to CRD record]

  2. Hawkes CA, Dhileepan S, Foxcroft D, Imberger G. Early extubation for adult cardiac surgical patients (Review). The Cochrane Library [Link to full text]

  3. Dalzel K (2001). Postoperative management in the recovery room compared to ICU for cardiac surgical patients. Centre for Clinical Effectiveness, Monash Institute of Health Services Research [Link to full text]

  4. BestBETs: In patients undergoing cardiac surgery, thoracic epidural analgesia combined general anaesthesia results in faster recovery and fewer complications but does not affect length of hospital stay. [Link to full text]

  5. Maureen O.Meade, Gordon Guyatt, Ron Butler, Brad Elms, Lori Hand, Andie Ingram and Laureen Griffith. Trials Comparing Early Vs Late Extubation Following Cardiovascular Surgery. Chest 2001; 120; 445S-453S. [Link to full text]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Anaesthesia for day case surgery
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.description: An introduction to anaesthetic techniques for day case surgery.
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Anaesthesia for day case surgeryBy Dr Navneet Narula, Topic Advisor for the Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia and Consultant Anaesthetist, Derby City General Hospital, Uttoxeter Road, Derby DE22 3NE

Cite this resource


Introduction

Day case anaesthesia aims to provide rapid and safe anaesthetic conditions for surgical procedures with a rapid and predictable recovery associated with minimal untoward sequelae. Day case surgery has advantages for both patients and healthcare providers. It assumes even greater importance in the current environment of 18-week delivery targets and payment by results, wherein more and more surgical procedures are being done in a day case setting[1] [2]. Anaesthesia for day case surgery uses general, regional and local anaesthetic techniques to provide optimal anaesthetic care with surgical and patient factors influencing anaesthetic techniques.

In the United States up to 90% of surgical procedures are done as day cases[3], while in France it represents only 27 percent[4]. The Scandinavian countries are far more advanced in this field[5].


General anaesthesia and day case surgery

The pharmacokinetics of the newer generation of drugs used in anaesthesia (sedatives, anaesthetic agents, analgesics and muscle relaxants) enable rapid onset of anaesthesia with a short duration of action and predictable effects without accumulation and with minimal side effects. Rapid and short-acting drugs and the increasing use of intravenous anaesthetic techniques facilitate the early recovery process. Drugs like desflurane and remifentanil and devices like bispectral index (BIS) monitors or entropy monitors allow fast turnover of patients recovering from general anaesthesia for day case procedures[6]. Prophylactic use of non-opioid analgesics and antiemetic drugs reduce postoperative side effects and enhance recovery while reducing hospital stay. Advances in anaesthetic techniques make brief surgical procedures safe for outpatient care and increasingly allow longer procedures to be performed on a day case basis.


Role of regional anaesthesia

Regional anaesthetic techniques have so far remained underutilized in the day case setting[7]. Advantages of regional anaesthesia include decreased incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting and better control of postoperative pain[8]. However studies have revealed that these factors on their own may not necessarily translate into reduced time on day case units[9]. There have been many studies comparing different regional and general anaesthetic techniques for day case surgeries. Most have concluded that total intravenous anaesthesia can provide just as safe and effective anaesthesia as regional techniques with the added advantage of earlier home readiness[10] [11] [12].


Postoperative pain in day case surgery

Pain after surgery remains a major limiting factor to the expansion of many surgical procedures that may be performed as day cases. Incidence of moderate to severe postoperative pain in the day case setting has been reported to be 40-70% in different surveys[13] [14]. Postoperative pain with or without nausea is also the most frequent cause of readmission[15] [16] or prolonged stay[17]. Both central neuraxial blocks and peripheral nerve blocks offer better control of postoperative pain compared to general anaesthetic techniques[18]. Developments in regional anaesthesia techniques represent a major contribution to increasing the indications for day surgery especially if the procedures are known to be painful.

Advances in anaesthetic techniques, better control of postoperative pain and of postoperative nausea and vomiting and the use of careful selection criteria continue to increase the number of patients who are likely to benefit from day case surgery.


Guidelines

Patient information

References


Guidelines

Selection criteria and suitable procedures:

  • Day Surgery information: selection criteria and suitable procedures
    Royal College of Nursing
    Link to guideline

  • BADS directory of procedures
    British Association of Day Surgery
    Email bads@bads.co.uk

Discharge criteria

  • Guidelines about the discharge process and the assessment of fitness for discharge
    British Association of Day Surgery
    Link to guidelines

Integrated care pathway for day cases:

  • Integrated care pathways for day surgery patients
    British Association of Day Surgery
    Link to pathways

Patient information

  • Spinal anaesthesia: a practical guide
    British Association of Day Surgery
    Link to guide

  • Day surgery and the diabetic patient
    British Association of Day Surgery
    Link to guide

  • Day case laparoscopic cholecystectomy
    British Association of Day Surgery
    Link to guide

References

Link to presentation


2. Aylin P, Williams S, Jarman B, Bottle A. Trends in day surgery rates. British Medical Journal. 2005;331 (7520):803.
Access to abstract or full text not freely available online

Link to full text

Abstract and full text unavailable online.


5. Vaghadia H. Outcomes in outpatients - what occurs outside? Canadian Journal of Anesthesia. 1998;45(7):603-6.
Link to full text


6. Casati A, Cappelleri G, Berti M, Fanelli G, Di Benedetto P, Torri G. Randomised comparison of remifentanil-propofol with a sciatic-femoral nerve block for out-patient knee arthroscopy. European Journal of Anaesthesiology. 2002;19(2):109-14.
Link to abstract


7. Dexter F, Macario A. What is the relative frequency of uncommon ambulatory surgery procedures performed in the United States with an anesthesia provider? Anesthesia and Analgesia. 2000;90(6):1343-7.
Link to full text


8. Neal JM, McDonald SB, Larkin KL, Polissar NL. Suprascapular nerve block prolongs analgesia after nonarthroscopic shoulder surgery but does not improve outcome. Anesthesia and Analgesia. 2003;96(4):982-6.

Link to full text

Link to full text


13. Chung F, Ritchie E, Su J. Postoperative pain in ambulatory surgery. Anesthesia and Analgesia. 1997;85(4):808-16.
Link to full text

Link to abstract

Link to abstract

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents: regional anaesthesia
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CLINICAL LIBRARY,EMERGENCY CARE,ANAESTHESIA AND ANALGESIA,SURGERY,THROMBOSIS PROPHYLAXIS,PREOPERATIVE PREPARATIONS,ANAESTHESIA,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,ANAESTHESIA / SEDATION]]>
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents: regional anaesthesia

Dr. Umakanth Panchagnula, Consultant in Anaesthesia and Honorary Clinical Lecturer, Central Manchester and Manchester Childrens University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust and
Dr. Saravanavel Sagadai, Consultant Anaesthetist, James Paget University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.

Cite this resource

 

Introduction

An increasing number of patients are prescribed anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents. When patients in this category require surgery, anaesthetic management is challenging, as the risk of a thromboembolic event during interruption of these drugs needs to be balanced against the risk of bleeding. It is a specific challenge for the anesthetist when considering a regional anaesthetic technique. Due to the risks associated with stopping these medications, the anaesthetist should have a clear understanding of the pharmacokinetics of these drugs, not only when timing the insertion of neuraxial blocks but also in the removal of indwelling catheters.

NICE (the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence) in conjunction with the Royal College of Surgeons of England has issued guidelines for the prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism[1].

 

Anticoagulation and anaesthetic implications

When administered with background anticoagulation, neuraxial blocks can result in spinal or epidural haematoma. Unless surgically decompressed as early as possible, irreversible neurological deficit may occur. Diagnosis and treatment of this serious complication are not always easy.

Anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents may be classified in many different ways [2-5]. Table 1 below shows the commonly used antiplatelet drugs and anticoagulants:

Group of drug Example(s) Monitoring of anticoagulation
1. Antiplatelet drugs aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), ticlopidine (Ticlid), abciximab, tirofiban, eptifibatide None recommended
2. Unfractionated heparin heparin solution APTT (activated partial thromboplastintime)
3. Fractionated heparin (Low molecular weight heparin) enoxaparin (Clexane®), dalteparin (Fragmin®) Anti-Xa levels TEG (thrombo-elastography)
4. Oral anticoagulants Warfarin INR (international normalised ratio)
5. Fibrinolytic agents alteplase (Actilyse®) Coagulation screen including fibrinogen levels and TEG
6. Direct factor Xa inhibitors fondaparinux (Arixtra®) None recommended
7. Direct thrombin inhibitors Hirudins: bivalirudin (Angiox®), lepirudin (Refludan®) None recommended

Table 1 - Commonly used antiplatelet drugs and anti-coagulants

 

Antiplatelet drugs

Thienopyridine compounds – clopidogrel, ticlopidine

The antiplatelet effect of these drugs is mediated by inhibition of adenosine-diphosphate (ADP)-induced platelet inhibition. Ticlopidine and clopidogrel also affect platelet to fibrinogen binding and subsequent platelet to platelet interactions. They affect both primary and secondary platelet aggregation. Peak activity is usually achieved in 3-5 days and their action may last up to 7 – 10 days.

Neuraxial blocks can be safely performed after discontinuation of clopidogrel (7 days later) and ticlopidine (10 days later). They should be reintroduced as soon as possible after the regional anaesthetic technique.

Platelet Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor antagonists - Abciximab, tirofiban and eptifibatide.

These drugs inhibit platelet aggregation by interfering with platelet-fibrinogen and platelet-von Willebrand factor. Time to normal platelet aggregation once discontinued may vary from eight hours (eptifibatide, tirofiban) to 24–48 hours (abciximab).

Non-sterooidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (e.g. aspirin)

These act by irreversibly inhibiting COX1 enzyme. NSAIDs differ in their capacity to inhibit COX1. They do not form an absolute contraindication, on their own, for performing a neuraxial block. Withholding aspirin for seven days before surgery may put at risk patients who are suffering from cardiovascular and/or neurological complications. It is highly recommended that aspirin and other antiplatelet agents should be restarted in the immediate postoperative period (6-24 hours).

 

Oral anticoagulants

Oral anticoagulants act by inhibiting the gamma-carboxylation of the vitamin-K dependent factors (II, VII, IX and X) and Protein C and Protein S. Coagulation may be restored to normal in about five days once warfarin is stopped. The anticoagulation should be monitored with International Normalised Ratio (INR). Neuraxial block (including catheter insertion) can be carried out provided INR is less than or equal to 1.5. It should be noted that warfarin should be re-commenced in the early postoperative period.

It is recommended that oral anticoagulants should be withheld prior to surgery and, where appropriate, a substitute anticoagulation regimen instituted using parenteral anticoagulant (usually low molecular weight heparin).

 

Unfractionated Heparin

This acts by promoting the inhibitory action of the antithrombin III (AT III) enzyme on the IIa, Xa and IXa factors mainly and to a lesser degree on XIa, XIIa and kallikrein. It has a bioavailability of 22-40% after intravenous or subcutaneous administration. It binds strongly to plasma proteins and in particular to endothelial cells.

When given intravenously, unfractionated heparin should be stopped at least four hours before regional technique or removal of epidural catheter. It can be recommenced one hour after any intervention (neuraxial block or catheter removal). If given subcutaneously, it is not a contraindication for neuraxial block, provided coagulation tests and platelet counts are within acceptable limits [6].

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)

LMWH activates anti-thrombin III is a naturally-occurring inhibitor of activated coagulation factors XII, XI, X, IX and thrombin [6-9]. The average molecular weight of LMWH may range from 4000 to 6500 Daltons, as opposed to unfractionated heparins which have a molecular weight of 15000 Daltons. The different LMWH have different ratio of anti-Xa/anti-IIa inhibition, ranging from 2:1 to 8:1. Their peak plasma levels are seen about four hours after subcutaneous administration and action may last up to 24 hours or even longer.

LMWH are eliminated primarily through the kidneys. Under normal circumstances, their anticoagulant effect is not routinely monitored. In certain patients (renal failure, morbid obesity or extreme age), specific anti-Xa assays are recommended to measure their therapeutic levels. Lim et al, [8] in their meta analysis conclude that non-dialysis-dependent patients with a creatinine clearance of 30 mL/min or less who are treated with standard therapeutic doses of enoxaparin have elevated levels of anti-Xa and are at an increased risk of bleeding.

A 12-hour interval is usually recommended between last dose of LMWH and any regional technique, either single shot or using catheter. This period should be increased to 24 hours in case of therapeutic anticoagulation using LMWH.

LMWH are usually recommenced 2-6 hours after neuraxial block, depending upon the patient and whether or not the neuraxial technique was atraumatic procedure. A greater number of spinal hematomas (more than 60%) was found to occur after the removal of the catheter [6] and hence caution should be exercised in administration of LMWH after catheter removal. Therefore, catheter removal should be considered as a neuraxial intervention and should preferably be delayed until 12 hours from the last dose of LMWH.

 

Direct Factor Xa inhibitors (Fondaparinux)

Fondaparinux is a newer class of selective inhibitors of factor Xa and its effects on Xa are reversible. It is a synthetic pentasaccharide with 100% bioavailability after subcutaneous administration. Maximum plasma levels are reached at 1.7 +/- 0.4 hours and the elimination half-life is 17–21 hours. It has a favourable pharmacokinetic profile and its effect is predictable. The drug does not need platelet monitoring and does not affect fibrinolytic activity or bleeding time.

Safety of conduct of a central neuraxial block in the presence of this drug remains to be established [2]. It is mainly used for thromboprophylaxis in the postoperative period on a once-daily regimen. After single-shot neuraxial block, its administration should be delayed for 6-8 hours. One has to wait for at least 36 hours after the last dose catheter removal and the subsequent dose should be delayed by another 12 hours. This practically amounts to skipping one dose of fondaparinux before catheter removal [10].

 

Fibrinolytics

Neuraxial blocks with or without catheter should be considered only under exceptional circumstances with patients on fibrinolytics within a 10-day period. Full coagulation screen including fibrinogen and thromboelastography should be performed on these patients.

 

Direct thrombin inhibitors

Hirudins – a four-hour interval is needed for its administration after neuraxial block and a 10-hour window is needed for the safe performance of neuraxial block after its administration.

Neuraxial block is contraindicated once danaparoid is administered (which should be two hours before surgery), since peak plasma levels would have been reached at the time of start of anaesthetic.

 

Discussion

Despite remarkable progress in the use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents, these drugs still remain a challenge to anaesthetists and surgeons. Brull et al [11] suggest that the rate of neurological complications after central nerve blockade is 0.04%; neuropathy after peripheral nerve block is less than 3%. However, permanent neurological injury after regional anaesthesia is rare in contemporary anaesthetic practice.

Although spinal hematoma is rare in patients with normal coagulation status, it can have a grave prognosis. In a patient receiving preoperative antiplatelet medications the risk of spinal haematoma following spinal or epidural anaesthesia remains a subject of debate. The decision whether or not to perform regional anaesthesia should be made on an individual basis, considering the risks and benefits. Patients regarded as high risk should be closely monitored postoperatively. In the event of suspicion of a spinal haematoma, immediate radiological and neurological evaluation should be undertaken.

There are significant pharmacokinetic differences between anticoagulants that will affect the timing of neuraxial needle insertion or catheter removal [2], [12].

The optimal dose of aspirin to balance clinical benefits and toxicity is again a matter of debate. Aspirin is an effective antithrombotic agent in doses between 50 and 1,500 mg per day. There is no significant evidence to prove that low dose aspirin (50 to 100mg per day) is not as effective as high dose aspirin (650 to 1,500mg per day) [13-15].

Unlike clopidogrel, aspirin does not affect the adenosine diphosphate or thrombin pathways (aspirin resistance). Therefore a combination therapy with aspirin may offer benefits over either of the drugs alone. Clopidogrel has been found to be useful in the treatment of acute coronary syndromes [16-18]. With a view to preventing the adverse gastroinstestinal effects of aspirin, Coxibs were developed [19].

When considering interruption of antithrombotic or anticoagulant therapy, an assessment of the risks associated with stopping the treatment should take place and the risk of bleeding associated with subsequent invasive procedures should be considered. A balance between clinical indication for the therapy and risk of bleeding must be achieved. Brief interruption of antithrombotic or anticoagulant therapy may be needed during the perioperative period. Under such circumstances a therapeutic dose of short-acting anticoagulant may be administered, usually 8-10 days during the period of interruption. This is described as bridging anticoagulation therapy [13], [20].

Longterm use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents reduces the occurrence of thromboembolic events in patients with atrial fibrillation and atherosclerotic disease. Patients with coronary stents or prosthetic heart valves are at an increased risk of thromboembolic event if their medication is stopped [21-22].

Surgery that takes place soon after coronary stent placement, either bare-metal or drug-eluting stents, may be associated with a significantly increased risk of adverse cardiac events. The majority of these patients are usually on dual anti-platelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel). The risk is high if antiplatelet therapy is discontinued. Therefore, if possible, elective surgery should be delayed by up to 12 months after placement of a drug eluting stent. Bridging anticoagulation therapy should be considered in consultation with the surgeon, cardiologist and haematologist. Only life-saving operations should be undertaken within 6-12 weeks of placement of a stent [23].

At present there is no pharmacological agent that can completely antagonize clopidogrel or aspirin. Platelet transfusion during the perioperative period has been recommended. Tranexamic acid and epsilon–aminocaproic acid have been used [25].

Different therapeutic options have been advocated for emergency surgery on patients on oral anticoagulants such as warfarin. Immediate reversal is achieved with a prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) and fresh frozen plasma (FFP). Vitamin K1 is essential for maintaining the reversal achieved by PCC and FFP.[26] Platelet factor 4 has been proposed to reverse the effects of LMWH. In a more urgent situation protamine sulphate may be used; however, it may provide only partial reversal.

 

Conclusion

Numerous studies have documented the safety of neuraxial blockade in the patient on antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants. Patient management is based on appropriate timing of needle or catheter placement and catheter removal, relative to the timing of anticoagulant or antiplatelet administration. Knowledge of the pharmacology of these agents is essential for the clinician making the relevant decisions. The consensus statements from different societies are designed to promote safe and quality patient care. We recommend referral to these [27] for further information.

Guideline

Reducing the risk of venous thromboembolism (deep vein thrombosis and Pulmonary embolism) in inpatients undergoing surgery – methods, evidence and guidance. NICE Clinical Guideline 46. April 2007. [Link to guideline]

document.title: Mini topic review: Cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,HEART,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY,MANAGEMENT,CAUSES AND RISK FACTORS,CRITICAL CARE,CLINICAL TOPICS,RENAL AND UROLOGICAL,PROCEDURES AND INTERVENTIONS,ORGAN SUPPORT,RENAL,DRUGS AND THERAPEUTICS,KIDNEY DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury

Dr Amit Srivastava MB BS FRCA Clinical Fellow in Cardiothoracic Anaesthesia, Papworth Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, Papworth Everard, Cambridge and Dr Stephen T Webb MB BCh BAO FRCA EDIC Consultant in Anaesthesia & Intensive Care Medicine, Papworth Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, Papworth Everard, Cambridge

Cite this resource

Acute kidney injury (AKI) related to cardiac surgery is a serious complication associated with prolonged intensive care and hospital length of stay and increased mortality.

 

Epidemiology

The incidence of cardiac surgery-associated AKI varies from 1 to 30% depending on how this disorder is defined. There is a wide spectrum of severity ranging from sub-clinical renal injury to acute renal failure requiring renal replacement therapy. Approximately 1-5% of cardiac surgical patients require renal replacement therapy and mortality may be as high as 60-70% in this subset of patients. Even small rises in serum creatinine following cardiac surgery are associated with increased mortality.1 Moreover those who develop AKI have higher one year mortality irrespective of whether the serum creatinine returned to the baseline values.2

 

Classification

The Acute Dialysis Quality Initiative (ADQI) group developed the first consensus definition of acute renal dysfunction in critically ill patients based on the changes in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and urine output and described by the acronym RIFLE (Risk of renal dysfunction, Injury to the kidney, Failure of kidney function, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease).3 Subsequently, the Acute Kidney Injury Network (AKIN) proposed the term acute kidney injury to encompass the full spectrum of altered renal function and suggested its diagnostic criteria as:

an abrupt (within 48 hours) reduction in kidney function defined as an absolute increase in serum creatinine of more than or equal to 0.3mg/dl (= 26.4 µmol/l), a percentage increase in serum creatinine of more than or equal to 50% (1.5-fold from baseline), or a reduction in urine output (less than 0.5 ml/kg per hour for more than six hours.4

Table 1. Classification/staging system for acute kidney injury.

Stage Serum creatinine criteria Urine output criteria
1 Increase in serum creatinine of more than or equal to 0.3 mg/dl (more than or equal to 26.4 µmol/l) or increase to more than or equal to 150% to 200% (1.5- to 2-fold) from baseline Less than 0.5ml/kg/hour for more than 6 hours
2 Increase in serum creatinine to more than 200% to 300% (more than 2 to 2 fold) from baseline Less than 0.5ml/kg/hour for more than 12 hours
3 Increase in serum creatinine to more than 300% (more than 3 fold) from baseline (or serum creatinine of more than or equal to 4.0 mg/dl [more than or equal to 354 umol/l] with an acute increase of a least 0.5mg/dl [44 µmol/l]) Less than 0.3ml.kg/hour for 24 hours or anuria for 12 hours

Risk factors

Risk factors for cardiac surgery-associated AKI (CSA-AKI) are shown in Table 2. Risk stratification tools for AKI following cardiac surgery have recently been tested and validated.6,7

 

Table 2. Risk factors for cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury.5

Pre-operative factors Intra-operative factors Post-operative factors
  • Advanced age
  • Female sex
  • Chronic renal disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Chronic cardiac failure
  • Aortic & peripheral vascular disease
  • Chronic liver disease
  • Genetic predisposition
  • Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation
  • Drug nephrotoxicity
  • Preoperative radiocontrast administration
  • Prolonged CPB time
  • Combined surgical procedures
  • Emergency surgery
  • Previous cardiac surgery
  • Aortic clamp placement
  • Low cardiac output syndrome
  • Acute cardiac dysfunction
  • Mediastinal haemorrhage
  • Hypovolaemia
  • Sepsis
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Intra-abdominal hypertension
  • Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome
  • Drug nephrotoxicity

Pathophysiology

A key mechanism in the pathophysiology of AKI is the alteration of renal blood flow resulting in renal hypoperfusion, ischaemic injury and acute tubular necrosis.8 The renal cortex receives a large proportion of renal blood flow and has a low oxygen extraction. In comparison, the renal medulla receives a lower proportion of renal blood flow and has higher oxygen consumption. The heterogenous physiology within the kidneys renders the renal medulla particularly vunerable to hypoperfusion and hypoxia which may lead to acute tubular necrosis. Endogenous mechanisms that operate to regulate medullary blood flow in response to ischaemic injury include local vasoactive mediators, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and tubulo-glomerular feedback.

 

Aetiology

The aetiology of cardiac-surgery associated AKI is multifactorial: ischaemia-reperfusion injury, systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), embolic injury, red cell pigment-induced injury and drug nephrotoxicity are believed to contribute to its development.9 Perioperative renal hypoperfusion outside the limits of autoregulatory reserve, particularly during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), contributes to renal ischaemia-reperfusion injury. Cardiac surgery triggers SIRS resulting in cell-mediated and cytotoxic injury. Renal atheroembolism from the ascending aorta may result in AKI. Thrombus, air, lipid and tissue may also contribute to the embolic load during cardiac surgery. Prolonged CPB produces haemolysis and renal excretion of red cell pigment derivatives may result in renal tubular injury. Perioperative drug-induced nephrotoxicity, related to exposure to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers or radiocontrast agents, may be an additional aetiological factor in the development of AKI. The use of the antifibrinolytic agent aprotinin in cardiac surgery may be associated with an increased risk of AKI requiring renal replacement therapy.

Thus there are several factors that can possibly contribute to cardiac surgery associated AKI, but the most significant of them is generally believed to be perioperative haemodynamic dysfunction.

 

Early diagnosis

Several biomarkers have been studied in the past decade that can potentially identify renal tubular injury up to 72 hours before an increase in serum creatinine. These biomarkers include cystatin C, kidney injury molecule-1, neutrophil gelatinase associated lipocalin (NGAL), urine glutathione S-transferase, N-acetyl Beta-D-glucosidase, microglobulin, neutral endopeptidase and retinol-binding proteins.10,11

 

Prevention

Both non-pharmacological and pharmacological interventions aimed at preventing cardiac surgery associated-AKI may be considered.


Non-pharmacological strategies

The most important non-pharmacological renoprotective strategy seems to be optimal haemodynamic management, including appropriate intravascular volume expansion, optimisation of cardiac output and maintenance of renal blood flow and renal perfusion pressure.

Renoprotective strategies related to the conduct of CPB may reduce AKI.12 Limiting the duration of CPB and maintaining adequate flow and perfusion pressure are of primary importance. Maintaining a normal mean arterial pressure may be beneficial in patients at risk of AKI. Avoidance of both severe haemodilutional anaemia and red cell transfusion may reduce AKI. The use of a miniaturised extracorporeal circulation system may also be beneficial.13 The evidence that off-pump coronary artery bypass graft surgery (OPCAB) reduces renal morbidity is conflicting.

Avoiding perioperative exposure to nephrotoxic drugs, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors, intravenous radiocontrast agents and aminoglycoside antibiotics, prevents drug-induced AKI. There are concerns regarding the risk of renal injury associated with the antifibrinolytic agent aprotinin. Recent evidence suggests that the use of aprotinin during coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) may be associated with an increased risk of acute renal failure requiring dialysis.


Pharmacological strategies

Table 3. Postulated pharmacological perioperative renal protection strategies

Drug
Vasodilators
  • Dopamine agonists
  • Adenosine antagonists
  • Calcium-channel antagonists
  • Sodium nitroprusside
Diuretics
  • Loop diuretics
  • Osmotic diuretics
Natriuretic peptides
  • Atrial natriuretic peptide
  • Urodilatin
  • B-type natriuretic peptide
Antioxidants
  • N-acetylcysteine
  • Corticosteroids
Other agents
  • Volatile anaesthetic agents
  • Insulin-like growth factor-1
  • Erythropoietin
  • Mesenchymal stem cells


Although dopamine may increase renal blood flow and urine output, there is no evidence that it is beneficial in AKI after cardiac surgery. A recent meta-analysis showed only transient improvement in renal physiology but no clinical benefits in terms of mortality, requirement for dialysis or adverse effects.14 The effect of fenoldopam, a selective dopaminergic receptor agonist, in the prevention of AKI after cardiac surgery is conflicting. A recent meta-analysis concluded that fenoldopam may confer significant benefits in preventing renal replacement therapy and reducing mortality in patients undergoing cardiovascular surgery and thus, the need for a large multicentre randomised controlled trial.15

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) increases glomerular filtration rate and inhibits sodium reabsorption in the medullary collecting duct thus resulting in natriuresis. A recent review concluded that low dose ANP may be associated with improved outcomes when used for preventing and treating AKI related to cardiac surgery.16

Diuretics are commonly used to treat oliguria postoperatively and may reduce the severity of AKI. The perioperative use of neither loop diuretics nor osmotic diuretics demonstrates significant renal protection in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.17 A recent meta-analysis concluded that loop diuretics do not decrease mortality in patients with AKI.18 Erythropoietin has shown promising anti- inflammatory and tissue protective effects in numerous experimental studies. The effect of EPO on CSA-AKI has shown conflicting results in 2 recent studies.19,20 Another promising agent is sodium bicarbonate. A recent trial demonstrated that a 24-hour infusion of sodium bicarbonate was associated with a significantly lower incidence of AKI after cardiac surgery using CPB.21 Several clinical trials are ongoing to confirm the beneficial effect of sodium bicarboanate.

Thus despite extensive studies on various pharmacological agents, at present, there is no firm evidence to suggest that the use of any specific pharmacological intervention is clinically beneficial to prevent AKI associated with cardiac surgery and hence none can be recommended.

Several studies have evaluated the timing of initiation of renal replacement therapy (RRT) in CSA-AKI. There may be a potential survival benefit with early initiation. However the current evidence regarding the timing, modality and dose of RRT in CSA-AKI remains inconclusive.

 

Conclusion

AKI post-cardiac surgery significantly increases morbidity and mortality. Consensus definitions and staging classifications as per RIFLE and AKIN have been well studied and validated.22 Several factors are known to contribute to its pathophysiology, the most significant of which is deranged perioperative haemodynamics. At present, there is no conclusive evidence to support a role for any pharmacologic agent in the prevention of AKI. However, the most widely accepted measures for preventing AKI include appropriate intravascular volume expansion, optimisiation of cardiac output and maintenance of renal blood flow and renal perfusion pressure.



References

2. Loef BG, Epema AH, Smilde TB et al. Immediate postoperative renal function deterioration in cardiac surgical patients predicts in-hospital mortality and long-term survival. J Am Soc Nephrol 2005; 16: 195-200. [Link to free full text]

3. Bellomo R, Ronco C, Kellum JA, Mehta RL, Palevsky P. Crit Care. 2004; 8:R204–R212. [Link to abstract]

4. Mehta RL, Kellum JA, Shah SV et al: Acute Kidney Injury Network: Report of an initiative to improve outcomes in acute kidney injury. Crit Care. 2007; 11:R31 [Link to free full text]

5. Rosner MH, Portilla D and Okusa MD. Cardiac surgery as a cause of acute kidney injury: Pathogenesis and potential Therapies. J Intensive Care Med 2008; 23: 3-18. [Link to abstract]

6. Thakar CV, Arrigain S, Worley S et al. A clinical score to predict acute renal failure after cardiac surgery. J Am Soc Nephrol 2005; 16: 162-8 [Link to free full text]

16. Nigwekar SU, Navaneethan SD, Parikh CR, Hix JK. Atrial natriuretic peptide for preventing and treating acute kidney injury. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 4 Art No: CD006028. [Link to free full text]
