document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Doctor-patient communication skills
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,COMMUNICATIONS,PATIENT COMMUNICATIONS,INFORMED CONSENT,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,CONSENT AND ASSENT]]>
document.description: Effective communications have been demonstrated to enhance patient satisfaction, improve compliance with treatment and assist the taking of informed consent.
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Doctor-patient communication skills

By Jo Church, Lay Member of the Royal College of Surgeons of England Patient Liaison Group


Cite this resource


Introduction

Communicating with patients remains an area of difficulty for many clinicians. Surgeons are often those who relay the bad news of life threatening disease to patients. Where patients may be at high risk, this requires particular communications skills, compared with other less serious illness. Effective communications have been demonstrated to enhance patient satisfaction, improve compliance with treatment and assist the taking of informed consent, whilst poor communications is often implicated when disputes arise. Despite a consensus on the importance of communication skills in medical training, its teaching in medical schools in the UK shows considerable variation in emphasis and assessment methodology.

Despite greater clinical experience during the course of a career, many clinicians tend to remain disease focussed rather than patient focussed, and miss empathetic cues emanating from patients. They may therefore fail to address the social and emotional impact of illness on individual patients, and their particular fears and hopes. They may also fail to check that patients have understood the information provided. There is therefore a clear need for ongoing communications training.
Resource intensive training appears to offer the best opportunity of maintaining newly learnt skills for at least 18 months following the training course.

Communications skills are equally important for the whole of the extended surgical team. Nurses are now more involved in day surgery and need to be good communicators as part of the multidisciplinary surgical team. There is also a need for simple clear information to back up the patient consultation.

Literature searches were undertaken up to September 2006 for English language papers using Medline, Embase, the National Library for Health, the Cochrane Library and the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination. Much of the evidence based research overlaps on common ground, which acknowledges the importance of patient focussed communications. The literature cited under each heading is particularly strong in that area, although it may include other more wide ranging research topics.

Communication Skills Training

Breaking Bad News

Patient-Centred Approach

Benefits of Good communication

Discontent and Litigation

Communication Skills Training

There is a need for communication skills education and assessment in medical schools, as well as the maintenance of learning after resource intensive training.

References

Sise M, Sise C, Sack D, Goerhing M. Surgeons’ attitudes about communicating with patients and their families. Current Surgery 2006; 63(3):213-8. (link to abstract here)

Raftery A, Scowen P, Survey of communication skills teaching at medical school Bulletin of the Royal College of Surgeons of England 2006; 88 (3):84-86 (link to full text here)

Levinson W, Gorawara-Bhat R, Lamb J. A study of patient clues and physician responses in primary care and surgical settings. Journal of the American Medical Association 2000; 284 (8):1021-7. (link to full text here)
Additional References

Travaline J, Ruchinskas R, D’Alonzo G. Patient-Physician Communication: Why and How. Journal of the American Osteopathic Association 2005; 105:13-18 (link to full text here) – includes a 5 step checklist for busy clinicians

Saunders S. Why good communication skills are important for theatre nurses. Nursing Times 2004; 100(14):42-4. (link to abstract here)

Foy C, Timmins F. Improving communication in day surgery settings. Nursing Standard 2004; 19(7):37-42. (link to abstract here or full text via NHS Athens)

Maquire P, Pitceathly C. Key communication skills and how to acquire them. British Medical Journal 2002; 325:697-700 (link to full text here) – includes a 5 step checklist

Garg A, Buckman R, Kason Y. Teaching medical students how to break bad news, Canadian Medical Association Journal 1997; 156 (8): 1159–1164 (link to full text here)

Learning Resource

Transcultural Communication and Health Care Practice – online courseware from the Royal College of Nursing

Breaking Bad News

There may be particular difficulties for the terminally ill, cancer or high risk patient, and the need to focus on the patient’s quality of life and not just the disease process.

References

Sise M, Sise C, Sack D, Goerhing M. Surgeons’ attitudes about communicating with patients and their families. Current Surgery 2006; 63(3):213-8. (link to abstract here)

Corke C, Stow P, Green D, Agar J, Henry M. How doctors discuss major interventions with high risk patients: an observational study. British Medical Journal 2005; 330(7484):182. (link to full text here)

Fellowes D, Wilkinson S, Moore P. Communication skills training for health care professionals working with cancer patients, their families and/or careers. The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2004; Issue 2. (link to full text here)

Easter D.W. Beach W. Competent patient care is dependent upon attending to empathetic opportunities presented during interview sessions, Current Surgery 2004; 61:313–318 (link to full text here)
Additional references

Barnett M. Effect of breaking bad news on patients' perceptions of doctors. Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine 2002; 95(7):343–347. (link to full text here)

Walsh R, Girgis A, Sanson-Fisher R. Breaking bad news 2: what evidence is available to guide clinicians? Behavioral Medicine 1998; 24(2):61-72. (link to DARE abstract here)

Other Resources

Breaking Bad News PatientUK – PatientPlus Guide. Last updated Jan 2008.
Breaking bad news to patients. Bandolier July 2000
Breaking Bad News Regional Guidelines. Department of Health, Social Sciences & Public Safety (Northern Ireland). February 2003.
Communicating risk to patients. British Heart Foundation. April 2005.

Patient-Centred Approach

What patients expect from the communication process.

References

McJannett M, Butow P, Tattersall M, Thompson J. Asking questions can help: development of a question prompt list for cancer patients seeing a surgeon. European Journal of Cancer Prevention 2003; 12(5):397-405. (link to abstract here)

Swiss Lyles J, Dwamena F, Lein C, Smith R. Evidence-Based Patient-Centered Interviewing. Journal of Clinical Outcomes Management 2001; 8(7):28-34. (link to full text here)

Little P, Everitt H, Williamson I, Warner G, Moore M, Gould C, et al. Preferences of patients for patient centred approach to consultation in primary care: observational study. British Medical Journal 2001; 322(468):1-7. (link to full text here)

Westwood F. Are we truly patient focused? British Journal of Perioperative Nursing 2001; 11(5):218 – 221 (no abstract or full text)
Other resources

Question prompt list derived from the above paper by McJannett et al. Available from the Medical Psychology Research Unit at the University of Sydney. (link to question list here)

Benefits of Good Patient Communication

Include a reduction in diagnostic tests and referrals and therapeutic effect for patient.

References

Sise M, Sise C, Sack D, Goerhing M. Surgeons’ attitudes about communicating with patients and their families. Current Surgery 2006; 63(3):213-8. (link to abstract here)

Travaline J, Ruchinskas R, D’Alonzo G. Patient-Physician Communication: Why and How. Journal of the American Osteopathic Association 2005; 105:13-18 (link to full text here) – includes a 5 step checklist for busy clinicians

Fellowes D, Wilkinson S, Moore P. Communication skills training for health care professionals working with cancer patients, their families and/or careers. The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2004; Issue 2. (link to full text here)

Fallowfield L, Jenkins V, Farewell V, Solis-Trapala I. Enduring impact of communications skills training results of a 12-month follow-up, British Journal of Cancer 2003; 89: 1445–1449 (link to full text here)

Discontent and Litigation

References

McLafferty R, Williams R, Lambert A, Dunnington G. Surgeon communication behaviors that lead patients to not recommend the surgeon to family members or friends. Analysis and impact. Surgery 2006; 140(4):616-624. (link to abstract here)

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Inadvertent Perioperative Hypothermia
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Inadvertent Perioperative Hypothermia

By Dr Paul S. Theron, Anaesthetic Registrar, Royal Sussex County Hospital, Brighton and Dr C. Mark Harper, Anaesthetic Consultant, Royal Sussex County Hospital, Brighton

Cite this resource


Introduction

Inadvertent perioperative hypothermia is known negatively to influence patient outcome1,2,3,4,5,6 but unfortunately remains a common occurrence in present day practice7. The aim of this review is to discuss the definition of inadvertent perioperative hypothermia, the considerations when measuring temperature, the effect of hypothermia on patient outcome, the methods of preventing inadvertent hypothermia and the cost implications.


Definition

The 2008 NICE guidelines define inadvertent perioperative hypothermia as a core temperature below 36ºC at any time from one hour before the start of anaesthesia to 24 hours after entering recovery8. This gives us a clear standard to achieve which should be audited regularly to ensure that patient outcome is improved.


Considerations when measuring temperature

NICE guidelines refer to core body temperature because it is the best indicator of the thermal status of the body. Obtaining a reliable measurement of core temperature can be difficult when non-invasive monitoring is used and there are particulars of core temperature measurement sites to consider.


Reliable sites for core temperature measurement are the lower oesphagus, nasopharynx, tympanic membrane and pulmonary artery9. Lower oesophageal monitoring can be unreliable if the probe is just posterior to the trachea, therefore blind insertion of a probe is not adequate. An oesphageal stethoscope is a reliable way of positioning such a probe. Nasopharyngeal monitoring is only reliable when no cool air is passing near the probe and is therefore best used in patients with a supraglotic airway or endotracheal tube in situ. The tympanic membrane does give a reliable measurement of core temperature, but current infrared "tympanic" monitors have been shown to be inadequate for clinical use10,11. Thermocouple tympanic monitors are reliable, but they need to be inserted to touch the tympanic membrane which may be difficult. Pulmonary artery monitoring is accurate, but is unlikely to be undertaken solely for core temperature measurement. The temporal artery infrared scanner has shown some promise and appears to be more reliable than infrared tympanic monitors12,13. It is, however, considered by some to be too inaccurate for clinical use8.


Further sites that can be used are the bladder, rectum, mouth and the axilla but these are all subject to artifact9. Bladder temperature is dependent on urine flow, which makes interpretation difficult, while rectal temperature has a significant lag period before equalising with core temperature. Oral temperature is considered by some to be the standard by which to compare other non-invasive thermometers but it may be affected by recent hot/cold drinks or breathing. Accurate axillary measurement is reliant on good technique with placement over the axillary artery. These thermometers are not measuring core temperature. The MRHA stated in 2005 in its review of intermittent-use thermometers that rectal temperature is on average 1.25°C below core temperature, axillary temperature 1.1°C below, ear temperature 0.85°C below, forehead temperature 0.7°C below and oral temperature 0.55°C below8.


To complicate matters further, many of the newer temperature measurement devices use an algorithm to output a core temperature but this is not always entirely clear to the user. NICE recognises the wide variety of devices and sites used within the NHS and states that staff should be trained in the use of the thermometers and must "carry out any adjustments that need to be made in order to obtain an estimate of core temperature” or be aware of whether these adjustments are made automatically8. NICE does not advise on best methods or device but rather states that “Choice of body site and selection of instrumentation for monitoring and detection are equally important, and local decisions within NHS Trusts should form local policy in this area”8.


Effect of hypothermia

It is well documented that hypothermia negatively influences patient outcome. There is published evidence that inadvertent perioperative hypothermia results in an increased rate of morbid cardiac events (6.3% vs 1.4%)1, increased blood loss (16%)2 and increased relative risk for blood transfusion (22%)2. Evidence shows increased rate of wound infection (19% vs 6%)3, prolonged hospital stay (by 2.6 days)3 and recovery stay (94 vs 53 min)4. Patient satisfaction is reduced due to increased shivering, subjective discomfort and wound pain. The temperature differences that result in these different outcomes are in the region of 0.85°C2. The smallest difference to influence outcome was 0.4°C6. This strongly supports NICE guidance to keep core temperature above 36°C.


Prevention of perioperative hypothermia

The 2008 NICE guideline considers the patient pathway in three stages: pre-, intra- and post-anaesthetic. Before surgery the patient should be informed that keeping warm preoperatively can lower their risk of complications and that should they feel cold to inform staff. In the preoperative phase, formal risk assessment should be conducted to determine those at a higher risk. These are patients to whom any two of the following apply:

  • ASA grade II to V
  • preoperative temperature <36°C
  • undergoing combined general and regional anaesthesia
  • undergoing major or intermediate surgery
  • at risk of cardiovascular complications

Forced air warming should commence if the temperature is below 36°C and non-life-or-limb-saving surgery should be postponed until the patient’s temperature is greater than 36°C. Intraoperative guidance states that if more than 500ml of fluid is to be given it must be warmed to 37°C. For procedures lasting more than 30 minutes or for patients at higher risk of hypothermia forced-air warming devices should be used. Core temperature should be measured every 30 minutes aiming to maintain a temperature of at least 36.5°C. Ambient temperature should be kept at 21°C, patient exposure should be kept to a minimum and irrigation fluids should be warmed. Postoperatively patients should not be discharged from recovery if their temperature is less than 36°C and temperature should be measured every four hours on the ward and acted upon if less than 36°C.


Financial implications

Warmed fluid and forced-air warming for a majority of patients is unlikely to be opposed on clinical grounds but naturally comes at a cost that needs to be weighed against the cost of increased complications. There is no direct evidence of the cost-effectiveness of forced-air warming for short procedures. However, economic benefits remain even if they are significantly less than the extrapolated data would suggest. Furthermore, although not cited in the guideline due to lack of evidence, there are other methods of warming, such as electric mattresses14,15 and circulating water devices16 that appear to be similarly effective yet may prove to be cheaper due to the fact that they are re-usable.

NICE’s analysis of cost effectiveness also concluded that warming IV fluids (if more than 500ml is to be given) was cost-effective and therefore should be implemented throughout the NHS. There is no doubt that inadvertent hypothermia is bad for patients. NICE has completed an extensive review on the subject and published a clear guideline indicating the expected standard of care. The aim of this mini topic review is to increase awareness of the guideline and the considerable benefits to be gained from adhering to its advice. To help with its effective implementation, an audit ‘recipe’ based on the guideline has just been published by the Royal College of Anaesthetists.



Guideline

  • Perioperative hypothermia (inadvertent)
    National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE), April 2008
    Link to guideline


The Royal College of Anaesthetists Audit Recipe

  • Raising the Standard: a compendium of audit recipes, Section 2: Intraoperative care (please refer to section 2.7 on perioperative temperature management.)
    Link to document


References

1. Frank SM, Fleisher LA, Breslow MJ, et al. Perioperative maintenance of normothermia reduces the incidence of morbid cardiac events. A randomized clinical trail. J Am Med Assoc 1997; 227:1127-34 Link to abstract

2. Rajagopalan S, Masch E, Na J, Sessler DI. The effect of mild perioperative hypothermia on blood loss and transfusion requirement. Anesthesiology 2008;108:71-7 Link to abstract

3. Kurz A, Sessler DI, Lenhardt R. Perioperative normothermia to reduce the incidence of surgical wound infection and shorten hospitalization. Study of Wound Infection and Temperature Group. N Engl J Med 1996;334:120-15 Link to abstract

4. Lenhart R, Marker E, Goll V, et al. Mild hypothermia prolongs postanesthetic recovery. Anesthesiology 1997;87:1318-23 Link to abstract

5. Scott EM, Leaper DJ, Clark M, Kelly PJ. Effects of warming therapy on pressure ulcers-a randomized trial. Aorn J 2001;73:921-7 Link to abstract

6. Winkler M, Akca O, Birkenberg B, et al. Aggressive warming reduces blood loss during hip arthroplasty. Anest Analg 2000;91:978-84 Link to abstract

7. Harper CM. Editorial II: NICE and warm. Br J Anaesth 2008;101:293-5 Link to publisher's extract

8. NICE. Perioperative hypothermia (inadvertent): the management of inadvertent perioperative hypothermia in adults. NICE Clinical Guideline 29. London: National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence, 2008. Link to guideline

9. Sessler DI. Temperature monitoring and perioperative thermoregulation. Anesthesiology 2008;109:318-38 Link to abstract

10. Frommelt T, Ott C, Hays V. Accuracy of different devices to measure temperature. Medsurg Nurs. 2008;17:171-182 Link to abstract

11. Imamura M, Matsukawa T, Ozaki M, Sessler DI, Nishiyama T, Kumazawa T. The accuracy and precision of four infrared aural canal thermometers during cardiac surgery. Acta Anaesthiol Scand 1998;42:1222-6 Link to abstract

12. Greenes DS, Fleisher GR. Accuracy of a noninvasive temporal artery thermometer for use in infants. Arch Pediatr Adolesc Med 2001;155:376-81 Link to abstract

13. Lawson L, Bridges EJ, Ballou I et al. Accuracy and Precision of Noninvasive Temperature Measurement in Adult Intensive Care Patients. Am J Crit Care 2007;16:485-96 Link to full text

14. Wong PF, Kumar S, Bohra A, Whetter D, Leaper DJ. Randomized clinical trial of perioperative systemic warming in major elective abdominal surgery. Br J Surg 2007;94:421-6 Link to abstract

15. Harper CM. Is warming mattress as effective as forced-air warming in preventing peri-operative hypothermia. Anesthesiology 2007;107:A92 No abstract available

16. Wadhwa A, Komastsu R, Orhan-Sungur M, et al. New circulating-water devices warm more quickly than forced-air in volunteers. Anesth Analg 2007;105:1681 Link to abstract

Cite this resource:

document.title: Mini topic review: Informed consent
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,COMMUNICATIONS,PATIENT COMMUNICATIONS,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,INFORMED CONSENT,CONSENT AND ASSENT]]>
document.description: A review looking at good practice in consent, patient perspectives, the communication of risk and effect of information presentation on patient recall
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Informed consent

By Jo Church, Lay Member of the Royal College of Surgeons of England Patient Liaison Group


Cite this resource


Introduction

Valid informed consent represents the culmination of good patient-clinician communication. It is underpinned by the patient’s trust in medical professionalism. Patients must trust that their tests are error free, that their diagnosis is correctly made, and that the advice they are given is based on objective clinical judgement, in their best interests. This deeper definition goes beyond, and is in addition to, the accepted notion of valid consent being given by a competent person, voluntarily and with full information. Coercion (threats) or manipulation (misrepresentation of the fact) must not be used, but persuasion is permissible where it provides the patient with the rational argument in favour of a particular treatment. In addition, patients rely on an upward referral to the highest level of expertise available, commonly referred to as Consultant-led Care. They expect junior members of staff to be adequately supervised to ensure their safety, and these elements are implicit when giving consent.

Surveys have shown that patients feel that they do not always receive a clear explanation of treatment risks. The paternalistic approach provides patients with information which the clinician thinks the patient ought to know, rather than responding to the differing needs and aims of individual patients. A more patient-centred method, advocated by Bridson, suggests that clinicians should ask patients their goals for treatment, even before treatment options are discussed. Patient information needs can then be gauged from the start, and the information tailored to fit the context of that particular patient’s objectives.

However, the provision of information to patients remains highly problematic, as recent legal precedent has shifted the balance in divulging risk. The previous test for revealing risk to patients was established by the Bolam case, and based on what a consensus of medical opinion would consider should be told to the patient. The Chester v Afshar case in 2004 established the ruling that all material risk, which a reasonable patient would want to know, must be told to them. This creates a tension between responding to patients’ individual requirements for information and the onus on the clinician to ensure that all relevant risks are stated and legal requirements met. Some patients may not want to be informed of the risks and complications of treatment and may prefer to leave the decision entirely to their surgeon, in which case clinicians are advised to document these situations in order to safeguard their position

In addition, it has been demonstrated that there is variation among clinicians as to what constitutes a significant risk or complication which should be conveyed to the patient, so that the patient may receive inconsistent information. To counter this, a more universal and systematic process of consent has been suggested, which would provide patients with a pre-printed list of significant complications for a particular procedure.

Risk benefit analysis remains problematic as patients may often only extract the gist of risk information and have poor recall. They may use a simplifying system to categorise a treatment as either safe or dangerous, and thus over or underestimate the true risk. They may be influenced by the immediacy of effect, perceived controllability of risk, novelty value and consequences, all of which may introduce bias into their analysis.

Providing full information to patients means ensuring that patients understand not only the consequences of the treatment options but also have a clear understanding of the impact of potential complications. The use of open questions can check understanding as the consultation progresses, and the verbal process can be supplemented with written information, diagrams and even audio-visual presentations. Written information plays a valuable part in reflection and discussion with family, and patients may need to be given sufficient time to reflect in order to make valid informed consent. In addition, patients expect the person taking consent to be familiar with the procedure and to be able to answer all their questions. Ideally, this should be someone who performs the procedure regularly.

Consent should be an integrated part of the whole communications process, but the sudden appearance of an official form to sign can rupture the personal and often intimate discussion. The purpose of consent as serving patients’ interests is not widely appreciated and it is not seen as ensuring and protecting their autonomy. Patients do not understand the status, function and remit of written consent, and they see it as protecting the hospital, doctors, or as a mere formality. Explaining the purpose of consent to patients at the outset of a consultation would clarify this, or providing a leaflet which explains how consent is of benefit to patients. It can then become part of the integrated communications process towards which the consultation progresses. In this way, informed valid consent ensures that the communications process was all that it should have been.

Literature searches were undertaken up to March 2007 for English language papers using Medline, Embase, the National Library for Health, the Cochrane Library and the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination.

Good Practice

Patient Perspectives

Patient Centred Consent

Communicating Risk

Information Presentation

Medico Legal

Special Circumstances

Good Practice

Good practice in consent begins with teaching in medical school and is underpinned by medical professionalism and adherence to codes of practice.

References

Raftery A, Scowen P. Survey of communication skills teaching at medical school Bulletin of the Royal College of Surgeons of England 2006; 88 (3):84-86 (link to full text here)

Wheeler R. Consent in surgery. Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England 2006; 88(3):261-4. (link to full text here)

Doctors in society. Medical professionalism in a changing world. Report of a Working Party. Royal College of Physicians December 2005. (link to full text here)

White S. Consent for anaesthesia. Journal of Medical Ethics 2004; 30(3):286-90. (link to full text here)
Other Resources

Code of Practice – Consent. Human Tissue Authority 2006. (link to full text here)

Consent for anaesthesia 2 revised edition. Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain & Ireland 2006. (link to full text here)

Informed consent in health and social care research: RCN guidance for nurses. Royal College of Nursing 2005. (link to full text here)

Consent Toolkit 4th Edition. British Medical Association. July 2008. (link to toolkit here)

Research: the role and responsibilities of doctors. General Medical Council 2002. (link to full text here)

Good practice in consent implementation guide: consent to examination or treatment. Department of Health 2001. (link to full text here)

Reference guide to consent for examination or treatment. Department of Health 2009. (link to full text here) 

Consent: patients and doctors making decisions together. General Medical Council 2008. (link to full text here)

Patient Perspectives

Survey, interview and questionnaire data has been used to gain a picture of the patients’ understanding of the legal implications of written consent both in elective and emergency situations, their attitudes to information giving, and the influence of the identity and experience of their surgeon in the consent process.

References

Chandrasenan J, Morris M, Williams J. Patients' views on consent for surgery: a questionnaire survey. Bulletin of the Royal College of Surgeons of England 2007; 89(4):140-2 (link to full text here)

Akaad A, Jackson C, Kenyon S, Dixon-Woods M, Taub N, Habiba M. Patients’ perceptions of written consent: questionnaire study. British Medical Journal 2006; 333(7567):528 (link to full text here)

Albera R, Argentero P, Bonziglia S, De Andreis M, Preti G, Palonta F et al. Informed consent in ENT. Patient's judgement about a specific consensus form. Acta Otorhinolaryngologica Italica 2005; 25(5):304-11 (link to full text here)

Habiba M, Jackson C, Akkad A, Kenyon S, Dixon-Woods M. Women's accounts of consenting to surgery: is consent a quality problem. Quality & Safety in Health Care 2004; 13(6):422-7 (link to full text)

Wiseman O, Wijewardena M, Calleary J, Masood J, Hill J. ‘Will you be doing my operation doctor?’ Patient attitudes to informed consent. Annals of The Royal College of Surgeons of England 2004; 86 (6):462-4 (link to full text here)
Other Resources

Picker Institute 'Is the NHS getting better or worse?' 18th April 2005 (link to full text here)

Patient-Centred Consent

Finding out what the patient wants from the treatment first before outlining the treatment options.

References

Bernat J, Peterson L. Patient-centered informed consent in surgical practice. Archives of Surgery 2006; 141(1):86-92 (Link to full text here)

O'Brien C, Thorburn T, Sibbel-Linz A, McGregor A. Consent for plastic surgical procedures. Journal of Plastic, Reconstructive & Aesthetic Surgery 2006; 59(9):983-989 (link to abstract here)

Bridson J, Hammond C, Leach A, Chester M. Making consent patient centred. BMJ 2003; 327:1159-1161 (link to full text here)

Vohra H, Ledsham J, Vohra H, Patel R. Issues concerning consent in patients undergoing cardiac surgery-the need for patient-directed improvements: a UK perspective. Cardiovascular Surgery 2003; 11(1):64-9 (link to abstract here)

Communication of Risk

Communication of risk information to the patient may vary according to the grade of the clinician and the risk thresholds for minor and major procedures. In turn the patient’s perception of risk may be influenced by the order in which it is presented from low to high risk procedures. Some studies also suggest that patients are inclined to underestimate risks and overestimate benefits of a procedure despite being given proper information.

References

Chen A, Leff D, Simpson J, Chadwick S, McDonald P. Variations in consenting practice for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England 2006; 88(5):482-5 (link to full text here)

Lemaire R. Informed consent--a contemporary myth? Journal of Bone & Joint Surgery - British Volume 2006; 88(1):2-7 

Pleat J, Dunkin C, Davies C, Ripley R, Tyler M. Prospective survey of factors affecting risk discussion during consent in a surgical specialty. British Journal of Surgery 2004; 91(10):1377-80 (link to abstract here)

Bergus G, Levin I, Elstein A. Presenting risks and benefits to patients. Journal of General Internal Medicine 2002; 17(8):612-7 (link to full text here)

Lloyd A. The extent of patients’ understanding of the risk of treatments Quality in Health Care 2001; 10(Suppl I):i14-i18 (link to full text here)

Mazur D, Hickam D, Mazur M. How patients' preferences for risk information influence treatment choice in a case of high risk and high therapeutic uncertainty. Medical Decision Making 1999; 15:485-94 (link to abstract here)

Presentation of Information

Consent forms can be complex and there are arguments for making surgical consent more consistent with the development of standard forms for each of the major operations. There are also differences in patient recall of information depending on the way that it is presented. Some studies suggest that written and visual aids assisted patients’ ability to remember information in combination with verbal communications.

References

Moseley T, Wiggins M, O'Sullivan P. Effects of presentation method on the understanding of informed consent. British Journal of Ophthalmology 2006; 90(8):990-3 (link to abstract here)

Cheung D, Sandramouli S. The consent and counselling of patients for cataract surgery: a prospective audit. Eye 2005; 19(9):963-71 (link to abstract here)

Ross N. Improving surgical consent. Lancet 2004. 364(9436):812-3 

Elder M, Suter A What patients want to know before they have cataract surgery. British Journal of Ophthalmology 2004; 88:331-332 (link to full text here)

Kriwanek S, Armbruster C, Beckerhinn P, Blauensteier W, Gschwantler M. Patients' assessment and recall of surgical information after laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Digestive Surgery 1998; 15(6):669-73 (link to abstract here)

Meredith P, Wood C. Inquiry into the potential value of an information pamphlet on consent to surgery to improve surgeon-patient communication. Quality in Health Care 1998; 7(2):65-69 (link to full text here) 

Armstrong A, Cole A, Page R. Informed consent: Are we doing enough?. British Journal of Plastic Surgery 1997; 50(8):637-640 (link to abstract here)

Medico-Legal Aspects

Case Studies

Chester v Afshar (2004) HL 41 (link to full judgment)

Bolam v Friern Hospital Management Committee (1957). 1 WLR 583. (link to full judgment)

Medico-legal anaesthesia. AnaesthesiaUK (link to website here)
Other Resources

Medico-legal information from the BMA (link to website here)

Medical Protection Society (MPS) - a mutual not-for-profit organisation aiming to support members with the legal and ethical problems that arise from their professional practice. (link to website here)

Medical Defence Union (MDU) - a mutual not-for-profit organisation owned by its members providing assistance in defence of professional reputations. (link to website here)

Special Circumstances

In some circumstances where an adult patient is incapacitated or unable to understand the consent process they may require a surrogate or proxy decision maker. In 2007 the Mental Capacity Act 2005 will come into force allowing health or social care decisions to be taken by a proxy decision maker. Circumstances could involve patients with a brain injury, dementia or learning disabilities. There are also implications for cultural or religious preferences in the consent process.

References

Bernat J, Peterson L. Patient-centered informed consent in surgical practice. Archives of Surgery 2006; 141(1):86-92 (link to full text here)
Other Resources

Mental Capacity Act 2005 - guidance for health professionals. British Medical Association. March 2007. (link to website here)

Assessment of capacity in adults : interim guidance for psychologists. British Psychological Society. April 2006. (link to full text here)

Mental Capacity Act 2005. Department of Health. (link to website here)

Reference guide to consent for examination or treatment. Department of Health 2009. (link to full text here)

Seeking consent: working with older people. Department of Health 2001. (link to full text here)

Seeking consent: working with people with learning disabilities. Department of Health 2001.(link to full text here)

Seeking consent: working with children. Department of Health 2001. (link to text here)

Management of anaesthesia for Jehovah's Witnesses 2nd edition. Association of Anaesthetists 2005. (link to full text here)

Code of practice for the surgical management of Jehovah's Witnesses. Royal College of Surgeons of England 2002. (link to text here)
Cite this resource:
Church J. Informed consent - a mini topic review. Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia, National Library for Health [published April 2007; downloaded (date of access)]. Available from: http://www.library.nhs.uk/theatres/viewResource.aspx?resid=259250&code=60aa7050a268a407c3333b03437d2799

document.title: Mini topic review: Postdural puncture headache
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Postdural puncture headache

By Dr Saravanavel Sagadai Topic Advisor, NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care and Consultant in Anaesthesia, James Paget University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust and Dr Gokulnath Rajendran ST3 in Anaesthesia, Ipswich Hospital, Ipswich.

Cite this resource


Introduction

Every year, about 707,000 central neuraxial blocks are performed in the UK1. Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is an iatrogenic complication of puncture of the dura mater. This could be secondary to spinal anaesthesia, epidural analgesia, combined spinal-epidural anaesthesia, diagnostic lumbar puncture, myelography or intrathecal chemotherapy. PDPH can be severe, incapacitating and potentially last for days to weeks or even months. It can cause a significant increase in anaesthetic workload and result in prolonged hospitalisation. A recent systematic review conservatively estimated the incidence of severe PDPH in the obstetric population alone as about 800 cases per year in the UK2. Hence the financial implications for this condition could be enormous.


Clinical Presentation

The International Headache Society3 has defined PDPH as a headache that develops within five days of dural puncture. The headache improves within 15 minutes of assuming the supine posture and worsens within 15 minutes of assuming a sitting or erect posture. It may be associated with nausea, vomiting, dizziness, tinnitus, hyperacusis, neck stiffness or photophobia4. Occasionally, visual and auditory disturbances have also been reported. In rare cases cranial nerve palsies can occur due to the stretching of vulnerable nerves secondary to cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) redistribution. The most common visual disturbance is diplopia due to stretching of the VI cranial nerve over the petrous part of the temporal bone5. Transient palsies of the III, IV, VII and VIII cranial nerves have also been reported6. Auditory disturbances include transient hearing loss and tinnitus because of the direct connection between CSF and perilymph across the cochlear aqueduct7.
The headache can be dull or throbbing, starting in the occipital or frontal region and later become generalised. It may radiate to the neck or shoulders and be exacerbated by coughing, straining or any manoeuvre that increase intracranial pressure.


Incidence

After diagnostic lumbar puncture with 22Gauge spinal needle, the incidence of PDPH with a standard needle and atraumatic needle was quoted as 36% and 3% respectively8. In a meta-analysis9 of PDPH in parturients, a group considered to be at the highest risk, the incidence of PDPH from small atraumatic spinal needles (Whitacre 27G) was calculated to be 1.7%.
The accepted rate of accidental dural puncture (ADP) associated with best practice 10 for epidural analgesia during labour is < 1%; 50-80% 11 (in some studies 12 unto 100%) of these patients subsequently develop PDPH.


Aetiology and pathogenesis

CSF is secreted by the choroid plexus and the total CSF volume in the central nervous system (CNS) is approximately 150 ml. Following dural puncture (intentional or unintentional), there is a possibility of leakage of CSF from the puncture site. When this leakage is greater than the CSF production rate (0.35 ml/min) intracranial hypotension occurs. Although the exact mechanism for PDPH is not clear, two hypotheses are well known:
Loss of CSF in the spinal space depletes the intracranial CSF cushion of the brain. Traction is exerted on the pain sensitive intracranial structures during upright posture. Pain arising on or above the tentorium cerebelli is transmitted via the V cranial nerve to the frontal region; pain from below the tentorium is transmitted via the IX & X cranial nerves and upper three cervical nerve fibres to the occipital region and neck 13.
Changes in cerebrovascular mechanisms (mediated via adenosine receptors 14), include compensatory cerebral venous dilatation secondary to loss of CSF (as explained by Monro-Kellie doctrine). This vasodilatation is considered to be responsible for PDPH 15.

Risk factors for PDPH

Patient characteristics

Incidence of PDPH is inversely related to age 16. Highest incidence is between 20–30 years of age and the incidence starts to decrease after the age of 40. It is rare after 60 yrs17. Previous history of PDPH is associated with higher risk 18 and so is the female sex17. Lower BMI has been shown to be associated with higher risk of PDPH8,17,19. Ironically, PDPH incidence is noted to be low in morbid obesity20. This may be because of the large abdominal panniculus acting like an abdominal binder and raising the intra-abdominal pressure, thus reducing the rate of leak of CSF through the dural defect.


Needle characteristics (size and design)

Incidence is directly related to the needle size. The incidence is 30% -36% with a 22G Quincke needle8,21. The incidence of PDPH and epidural blood patch (EBP) rates for different types of needles are given in Table 122. Due to technical difficulties, needles of size 29G or smaller are not commonly used for spinal anaesthesia23.

Table 1: Incidence of PDPH & EBP for different types of spinal needles22.


Needle size & Type Bevel Incidence of PDPH% % of PDPH cases needing EBP
25G Quincke cutting 8.7 66
26G Atraucan cutting 5 55
24G Gertie Marx atraumatic 4 12.5
24G Sprotte atraumatic 2.8 0
25G Whitacre atraumatic 3.1 0


Atraumatic needles with pencil-point tip separate the dural fibres rather than cut them, reducing the incidence of PDPH compared to needles with a cutting bevel. Lower incidence of PDPH with atraumatic needles has been reiterated in a recent study in paediatric population24. In addition, the need for epidural blood patch has been shown to be lower for the atraumatic needles when compared to the cutting bevel needles; this is most probably related to lower leak rates with atraumatic needles which lead to milder degrees of PDPH.
In-vitro studies have confirmed that both fluid loss and leakage rates after dural puncture were high with 22G compared to 26G spinal needles, whilst there is no or minimal leak with 29G needle. Also there was less fluid loss observed with atraumatic needle (Whitacre) compared to cutting needle (Quincke) of same size25.

A prospective randomized trial reported that after ADP with a 17G epidural (Tuohy) needle, 100% of patients developed PDPH whereas only 55.5% developed PDPH with 18G epidural (Special sprotteTM) needle12.

Needle orientation

Arrangements of dural fibres are thought to be longitudinal, but electron microscopy views revealed that dural collagen fibres are arranged in different directions26. Clinical studies favour use of parallel orientation of needles, both spinal16 and epidural27. With the use of pencil-point needles for spinal anaesthesia, needle orientation may not be important. However, the pathophysiology of PDPH is more related to the size and shape of the hole made in the arachnoid than in the dura mater due to the fact that arachnoid is the actual fibrous sac containing the CSF. It has been shown that the pencil point needle makes an irregular hole than that caused by cutting needle; in addition, they tend to cause more local oedema or tissue reaction than the cutting needle. This inflammatory reaction caused by the tearing of the collagen fibres after meningeal penetration may result in significant edema which might act as a plug, thus lowering the CSF leak rate through the defect28.

It has been shown that angle of puncture of the duramater was not a significant factor in the development of PDPH29.


Diagnostic LP and stylet replacement

After diagnostic lumbar puncture with 21G needle replacement of the stylet has been shown to reduce the incidence of PDPH from 16 to 5%30. The subarachnoid granulation is thought to enter the hole in the dura, by keeping it open there is a comparatively larger volume of CSF leak. If the stylet is replaced, the subarachnoid granulation is pushed out of the hole and CSF loss through the hole in the dura is minimised. Though 25G needles have been tried with negative pressure for CSF collection31, the American Academy of Neurologists has emphasised that diagnostic lumbar punctures should be done with at least 22G atraumatic spinal needle32,33.


Parturients

The obstetric population is at increased risk due to young age and widespread application of neuraxial techniques. Labouring women are particularly at high risk of developing PDPH after dural puncture due to the following factors: (i) peripartum dehydration and postpartum diuresis reducing the levels of CSF production, (ii) bearing down during second stage of labour increases CSF leak, (iii) abrupt release of intra-abdominal pressure and venacaval compression at delivery reducing epidural venous pressure, (iv) early ambulation and (v) anxiety. Interestingly, it has been shown that good quality labour analgesia is feasible with a 19G Tuohy needle and 23G epidural catheter34. For obvious reasons, the PDPH rates would be lesser with smaller gauge epidural needle compared to 16G needle12.


Intrathecal catheter

Following inadvertent dural puncture with an epidural needle, insertion of an epidural catheter into the subarachnoid space would prevent further leak and provoke an inflammatory reaction around the puncture site. However, evidence to support this is not clear. One study has shown reduced incidence of PDPH in obstetric patients when intrathecal catheter was left in situ for 24 hours35. Advantages of leaving an intrathecal catheter after ADP in a labouring parturient are threefold: (i) rapid establishment of analgesia, (ii) avoiding the risk of another dural puncture, (iii) reduction in the development of PDPH after ADP. However, this practice is associated with the risk of infection and accidental injections into the subarachnoid space.


Factors related to regional technique

Using loss of resistance to air (as opposed to saline) to identify the epidural space has been shown to increase the risk of PDPH36. A recent meta-analysis noted decreased incidence of PDPH in chronic pain setting when saline was used but there was no difference in obstetric population37. A Cochrane review reports no significant difference in the incidence of PDPH between patients who received epidural and those who received combined spinal-epidural38.

Operator factors

Operator inexperience, fatigue, sleep deprivation and multiple attempts might contribute to a higher incidence of accidental dural puncture and PDPH.


Natural course of PDPH after dural puncture

Usually, symptoms develop within 48 hours and may be delayed upto five days. But, presentations as late as 12 days after uneventful labour analgesia has been reported39. Generally, there is gradual improvement in the symptoms with time. 70% of them tend to resolve within one week, 95% within 6 weeks and 96% within six months40,41. With early hospital discharges becoming increasingly common, these patients often present to non-anaesthetists in the community.


Management

PDPH is usually a self-limiting process. Most treatments are aimed at reducing the symptoms until the hole in the dura can heal. The treatment options are discussed as conservative and invasive.


Conservative

The fact that several treatment options are available implies that there is no consensus in the management of PDPH.

Bed rest

Remaining supine after dural puncture was once thought to prevent the occurrence of PDPH. Although bed rest does not affect the incidence of PDPH, when it occurs bed rest reduces the severity of symptoms29.

Hydration

Dehydration can result in decreased CSF production. Maintaining hydration (oral or intravenous) improves the ratio of CSF production to CSF leak and may improve the clinical picture. However, if the patient is appropriately hydrated CSF production would be normal and overhydration is not beneficial.

Analgesics

Oral NSAIDs and opiods such as codeine and tramadol are often prescribed for symptomatic relief.

Caffeine

Caffeine sodium benzoate can reduce the headache by causing cerebral vasoconstriction or by limiting cerebral vasodilatation. It is available in oral or intravenous formulation and the dose is 300-500 mg once or twice daily15,43. If unavailable, advising the patient to drink caffeine containing beverages may be useful but caffeine levels vary between 66 and 142 mg in 150 ml of coffee44. Potential side effects include central nervous system toxicity and atrial fibrillation. There is a reported case of posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) triggered by intravenous caffeine in a patient with multiple sclerosis45. However, the effects of caffeine are only temporary44.

Theophylline

Single dose oral theophylline is found to be effective in treatment of PDPH, presumably due to its lasting action and potent cerebral vasoconstriction46,47. However, its narrow therapeutic range and side effects preclude its routine use.

5-HT1D receptor agonists

Sumatriptan (subcutaneous) and the newer, Frovatriptan (oral) could theoretically improve PDPH by promoting cerebral vasoconstriction, at present there is no strong evidence to support the use of these drugs48,49.

Methergine

Oral methergine, 0.25 mg, eight hourly for 48 hours was found to be effective for PDPH following spinal anaesthesia in obstetric patients50. No studies on its use for PDPH following epidural have been published to date.

ACTH and corticosteroids

ACTH is thought to increase CSF production through active sodium transport mechanism and also raise the pain threshold through an increase in beta-endorphin levels51. Multiple doses of adrenocorticotrophic hormone have proven effect52 whilst single depot injection was not effective51. A double blind controlled study found that Hydrocortisone 100 mg eight hourly for 48 hours was effective53.

Gabapentin & Pregabaline

Gabapentin 400 mg eight hourly54 and Pregabaline 50 mg eight hourly55 have been shown to be useful within 24 hours in 2 different case reports. But there are no randomized trials to prove their usefulness.


Invasive

Epidural blood patch (EBP)

EBP is the definitive treatment for PDPH and is dealt with in detail later.

Epidural saline or colloids

Epidural saline or Hartmann’s solution or dextran-40 (bolus or infusion) increases the pressure in the epidural space thereby reducing the CSF leak. 100% success rate has been reported in a series of 56 patients who received 20-30 ml of epidural dextran-40 over two minutes without any reported complications56. This impressive result has not been reproduced elsewhere, though a case report describes successful treatment of intracranial hypotension with epidural dextran-40 and paramethasone followed by oral steroids57.

Epidural or intrathecal opioids

There are case reports that claim epidural morphine as beneficial for treatment of PDPH58. But there is no strong evidence to confirm this.

Fibrin glue

Although fibrin glue injection is found to be an alternative to EBP, it is associated with aseptic meningitis and poor success rate (65%) despite being performed under CT guidance59.

Occipital Nerve block (ONB)

Nerve stimulator guided blockade of greater and lesser occipital nerves with a mixture of local anaesthetics, fentanyl and clonidine has been shown to be superior in relieving symptoms compared to conventional analgesics in a randomised controlled trial60. Greater occipital nerve was blocked for PDPH in the parietal and occipital areas whereas lesser occipital nerve was chosen for PDPH in the frontal and temporal distribution. ONB was tried on the physiological basis that the clinical features of PDPH are very similar to those of cervicogenic headache that responded well to this nerve blockade. ONB is thought to act by interrupting the pain transmission via the greater and lesser occipital nerves or their nerve roots or ganglia. ONB relieved the PDPH and accompanying symptoms in two-thirds of patients after 1-2 injections with the rest requiring up to 4 injections. ONB has also resulted in earlier hospital discharge and shorter sick leave duration.

Surgical repair

For PDPH remaining unresolved after the above treatments, surgical repair of the dura may be necessary.

Table 2: Summary of treatment options for PDPH

Conservative Measures Invasive Measures Prophylactic Measures
Bed rest & Hydration Epidural blood patch Epidural morphine
Analgesics: NSAIDS, Opioids Epidural saline / colloid ACTH Analogue
Caffeine Epidural opioids Epidural blood patch
Theophylline Epidural fibrin glue
5-HT1D receptor agonist (Sumatriptan / Flavitriptan) Occipital nerve block
Methergine Surgical repair of the dura
ACTH & Corticosteroids
Gabapentine & Pregabaline



Epidural blood patch (EBP)

The first EBP was reported by Gormley in 196044. EBP is the gold standard treatment for PDPH against which other treatment options are compared.The first EBP was reported by Gormley in 196061.

Indications

EBP is indicated for moderate to severe PDPH when conservative treatment is unsatisfactory, durocutaneous fistulae and spontaneous low CSF pressure headache (Schaltenbrand’s syndrome) 62.

Contraindications

Contraindications include patient refusal, coagulopathy, systemic sepsis, fever, localised infection in the back and anatomical abnormalities that could lead to higher risk of dural puncture. There is a theoretical risk of seeding the neuraxis with neoplastic cells and hence risks and benefits should be analysed in oncology patients. However, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is not a contraindication.

Practical conduct of the procedure

Ideally, EBP should be performed in a sterile environment with two operators, one aspirating blood from a sterile site and the other injecting 15 to 20 ml of blood using Tuohy needle into the epidural space, at the level of previous puncture or one level below it. The exact volume to be injected is not conclusive, but the injection should be stopped if the patient complains of any pain or discomfort in the back. Interestingly, one study has shown that low volume (7.5ml) EBP is as effective as high volume (15 ml) and is associated with less nerve root irritation pain in the low volume group63. A recent randomised controlled trial reiterated that EBP is an effective treatment of PDPH64. Sending blood cultures at the time of EBP is controversial.

Remaining in decubitus position for two hours after the EBP improves the success rate compared to bed rest for 30 minutes65. This period of decubitus gives sufficient time for the organisation of the clot and the regeneration of CSF to mitigate the effects of intracranial hypotension.

Timing of the EBP

The timing of the EBP in relation to the dural puncture is important. The general consensus is that EBP is less effective if performed within 24 hours after dural puncture66. This window of 24 hours is useful because it allows time for (i) confirmation of diagnosis, (ii) trial of conservative management, (iii) complete regression of the neuraxial block, if present and (iv) disappearance of local anaesthetic from epidural space. Epidural injection of blood while residual neuraxial block is still present might result in an extensive neuraxial block and the local anaesthetic might inhibit blood coagulation67. It might also confound the clinical picture if the patient develops any neurological deficit. However, if the symptoms of PDPH are incapacitating, there is no strong evidence to delay EBP, especially if it occurs after ADP with wider gauge epidural needles.

There are reported cases of PDPH that have been treated successfully with EBP even months after the dural puncture68-70.

Success rate

The success rate following the first EBP is 61-75%, even though more than 90% of patients had initial resolution of symptoms71-73. If unsuccessful, repeating the EBP has been shown to increase the success rate upto 97%74.

Complications

Complications of EBP include back pain (25%), paresthesia, radiculitis, temporary cranial nerve palsies75, permanent paralysis, cauda equina syndrome76, pneumocephalus, epidural abscess and possible late arachnoiditis. There is no evidence to show that remote EBP could affect the subsequent conduct of epidural analgesia.

Jehovah’s witness

EBP for Jehovah’s Witness may require a continuous circuit established from antecubital vein to the epidural78. All the options must be discussed with each individual patient and informed consent obtained.

Mechanism of action of epidural blood patch

It has been shown that blood clotting was accelerated (four times faster than activated clotting time) by the presence of CSF79, but even instantaneous clotting of epidurally injected blood cannot explain the rapid relief EBP provides80. EBP has two distinctive effects81: (i) The immediate effect due to volume replacement by compression of dura that will restore CSF pressure and relieve headache. This effect lasts up to seven hours. (ii) The sustained effect (after seven hours and up to 18 hours or possibly longer) is due to the sealing of the dural defect by the blood clot. An EBP also augments the fibroblast proliferation which is a normal response to a dural tear and forms a network for collagen deposition79. While the organised clot is occluding the hole in the dura, the ‘repair work’ continues to seal the dural tear. When the clot starts to resolve, the dural defect has been completely repaired or the defect is so small that the symptoms of PDPH are less intense. Unfortunately, if the blood clot gets dislodged for any reason before the repair of dural tear could be completed, failure of EBP occurs. The extent of spread of the injected blood has been shown to positively correlate with the total volume of the blood injected, an average of one spinal segment for every 1.6 ml of blood81. The clot resulting from EBP spreads significantly over three to five segments around injection site and it spreads principally upwards from the site of injection. Hence, EBP should be performed below the level of dural puncture or at least at the level; for the same reasons, performance of EBP by injecting blood through an epidural catheter in situ is less likely to be successful.

Repeat EBP:

If EBP did not relieve the symptom, then the original diagnosis of PDPH should be questioned, especially after two consecutive failed EBPs. Detailed neurological assessment and investigation should be considered to rule out other sinister causes of headache. The clinician should always look for any change in the clinical features (e.g., change from postural headache to constant headache), which might give a clue to the development of complications of intracranial hypotension. Development of cranial subdural haematoma following untreated PDPH has been reported82. CT guided EBP directed to the exact site of CSF leak might be a safe option in selected patients when repeated EBPs failed to resolve PDPH83.

Causes of epidural blood patch failure:

  • Injection at inappropriate level or injection through an epidural catheter
  • Inadequate blood volume
  • Presence of local anaesthetics or steroids in epidural space
  • Incorrect timing of EBP (too early or too late)
  • Headache due to other cause(s) (Table 3)

Use of substances other than blood for epidural patching:

Different substances including dextran, hetastarch, gelatine, fibrin glue and cryoprecipitate are administered instead of autologous blood for epidural patching due to various reasons including religious beliefs, concerns of infectious complications related to blood, arachnoiditis, cancer and thrombocytopenia84.


Table 3: Differential diagnosis of headache after dural puncture (intentional or unintentional)15,85.


Primary Secondary
Migraine PDPH
Tension / non-specific headache Pre-eclampsia or eclampsia
Sinus headache Cerebral arterial or venous sinus thrombosis
Orgasmic headache Ischaemic or haemorrhagic stroke
Subarachnoid or intracranial haemorrhage
Hypertensive encelphalopathy or bleeding
Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)
Postpartum cerebral angiopathy
Pituitary apoplexy
Intracranial tumour or pseudo-tumour
Uncal herniation
Meningitis (viral, bacterial, chemical)
Caffeine withdrawal headache

Strategies to prevent PDPH following accidental dural puncture

Various strategies including prophylactic epidural injection of saline, dextran or autologous blood, intrathecal placement of epidural catheter, avoidance of bearing down in the second stage of labour, subarachnoid opioid injection, cerebral vasoconstrictors and abdominal binders have been suggested as prophylaxis to reduce the incidence of PDPH after unintentional dural puncture, but there is no strong evidence favouring these interventions. A recent Cochrane review concluded that the benefit of prophylactic EBP to prevent PDPH remains unclear86.

A recent systematic review and other studies have shown that prophylactic epidural morphine decreases the incidence of PDPH after ADP2,87,88.

A recent randomised controlled trial has claimed that a single prophylactic intravenous administration of cosyntrophin (ACTH analogue) after ADP has halved the incidence of PDPH89.


Conclusion

PDPH could potentially increase the workload of anaesthetists and physicians. In addition, the resultant increase in hospital stay, investigations and treatment required could have significant financial repercussions. Also the physicians and general practitioners should be aware of late presentations in the community.


EBP is the gold standard treatment for PDPH. But conservative management should be considered for the first 24 hours, while the diagnosis is being confirmed. EBP performed within the first 24 hours may not be very effective. But certainly, EBP should not be delayed more than 24 hours in a patient with incapacitating symptoms. Other pathologies that may coexist in these patients should be excluded and hence a structured multidisciplinary approach is advisable, especially if EBP fails twice.


For diagnostic lumbar puncture, larger needles (20G) are still widely used outside theatres. This practice needs to be addressed and the physicians should be encouraged to use atraumatic needles with at least 22G.


Smaller gauge spinal and epidural needles would not only reduce the incidence of PDPH, but also the rate of EBP required. While smaller gauge Tuohy needles are available and could be used to provide good quality labour analgesia, 16G needles are still widely being used. Routine use of smaller gauge epidural needles should be strongly considered, especially for labour analgesia. It remains to be seen if further explorations on ACTH analogues and lesser invasive procedures, such as occipital nerve blocks, would alter our current management of PDPH.





References

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Prevention of hypotension during regional anaesthesia for caesarean section - Effective use of vasopressors
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.description: This article reviews effective methods to prevent hypotension during spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Prevention of hypotension during regional anaesthesia for caesarean section - Effective use of vasopressorsBy Dr Girish Sadhu, Topic Advisor for the Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia and SpR in Anaesthetics, Wythenshawe Hospital, University Hospital Of South Manchester NHS Foundation Trust

Cite this resource


Introduction

Regional anaesthesia is now used in more than 90% of caesarean sections[1] presently due to its advantages for both mother and baby. The mother can remain awake and avoid the risks of general anaesthesia and it facilitates early nursing and bonding with the baby. The baby in turn is not exposed to the detrimental effects of multiple drugs.

Hypotension is the most common side effect of regional anaesthesia, which if not treated properly can cause severe vomiting, loss of consciousness, aspiration and cardiac arrest in the mother. The baby may suffer from hypoxia, acidosis and hypoxic brain injury. There are various strategies to prevent hypotension following regional anaesthesia namely lateral uterine displacement, mechanical leg compression [2][3], intravenous fluid pre-load [2][3][4][5][6] and vasopressors. The most effective strategy is the use of the appropriate vasopressor with intravenous fluid.

Historical studies supported the use of ephedrine as the gold standard for treating hypotension after regional anaesthesia because of its low propensity to reduce uteroplacental blood flow (UBF). More recent evidence supports the use of a pure alpha-agonist such as phenylephrine as the vasopressor of choice for maintaining maternal blood pressure close to normal levels, due to its benefits on mother and baby.


What is the level at which the maternal blood pressure must be maintained?

Present recommendations are to maintain maternal blood pressure (BP) at near baseline values. Traditionally, maintenance of low placental vascular resistance and thus better UBF was considered more important than any adverse effects resulting from a 20-30% decrease in maternal arterial pressure. Vasopressors were thought to cause decreased UBF [7][8] and were avoided until all other modalities of treating hypotension failed [9]. Vasopressors were administered only when maternal BP fell below 70-80% of baseline or below 90-100mmHg [10].

More recent evidence has shown that maintaining maternal BP near baseline was associated with the best outcome for the baby (highest umbilical artery pH) and the mother (fewer incidences of nausea and vomiting) [11]. This is particularly important in the compromised fetus who will be more sensitive to even minimal decrease in maternal BP [12]. The higher the maternal BP, the better the uterine blood flow and placental perfusion. So the primary aim should be to maintain the maternal BP at baseline value without sparing the use of appropriate vasopressors and intravenous fluids.


What is the role of intravenous fluids in preventing hypotension?

Recent studies have shown that rapid crystalloid infusion given immediately after spinal injection (‘cohydration’ or ‘coload’) reduce hypotension and vasopressor requirement. Early studies showed that administration of a 1-2 litre crystalloid bolus before spinal anaesthesia was effective at preventing or attenuating hypotension. Thus prehydration or ‘preload’ became established as a routine and accepted part of neuraxial techniques in obstetrics. However it has been a matter of some dispute and many studies have questioned the efficacy of hydration at preventing hypotension during the administration of regional anesthesia [31]. It has been noted that the incidence of hypotension was reduced from 71% in patients without hydration to 55% in elective cesarean delivery patients receiving intravenous fluid administration as the primary method of prophylaxis during administration of spinal anesthesia [32]. This lack of efficacy of crystalloid prehydration may be explained by the rapid redistribution into the interstitial space that occurs after infusion of crystalloids, limiting the effective expansion of the intravascular volume [33]. Colloid preload may be more effective than crystalloid in preventing postspinal hypotension [4][5][6], but is more expensive and is associated with high potential for allergic reactions. However, whichever fluid is administered, even aggressive expansion of the intravascular space cannot completely abolish the risk of hypotension and a vasopressor drug is often required [34][35]. Hence cohydration enables the augmentation of circulating volume at the same time that peripheral vasodilatation occurs, and in addition may facilitate more rapid distribution of concomitantly delivered vasopressors [27].


What is the vasopressor of choice?

Present recommendations support the use of phenylephrine, a pure alpha agonist, as the primary vasopressor.

Ephedrine, which is an alpha and beta agonist, had been the gold standard for prophylaxis and treatment of spinal hypotension. This was based on several sheep studies [7][8], which showed that ephedrine maintained UBF much better than other pressors that were primarily vasoconstrictors (e.g. phenylephrine and metaraminol).

Recent evidence show that doses of ephedrine large enough to maintain homeostasis after the induction of spinal anaesthesia may be detrimental to the fetus. Ephedrine, when given to mothers to treat hypotension, caused dose-dependent increase in fetal acidosis, tachycardia and abnormal variability in fetal heart rate (indicative of fetal stress), or an increase in metabolic activity [13] [14][15][16]. Ephedrine also caused significant hypertension and tachycardia in mothers when used to treat spinal hypotension [3][17].

Phenylephrine, a pure alpha agonist is as efficient as ephedrine in restoring and maintaining maternal BP [3][14] [16][18][19] [20]. Smaller doses are required compared to ephedrine and it does not cause clinically significant decrease in uterine blood flow. This may be due to decreased sensitivity of uterine blood vessels to vasopressors in pregnancy and preferential shunting of blood from peripheries to the uterine vessels [21]. Studies have shown that Phenylephrine does not have detrimental effects such as acidosis on the fetus even in large doses as it does not have beta-agonist activity and thus does not increase metabolism in the fetus [11][14][16][20][22][23]. It does not cause maternal tachycardia but does cause bradycardia as a physiological effect. This bradycardia is not detrimental to the neonate or the mother if the BP is maintained, but may need treatment with anticholenergics such as glycopyrolate 25 if associated with hypotension.


What is the mode of administration of Phenylephrine?

Phenylephrine must be administered intravenously for prophylaxis and treatment of maternal hypotension immediately after the spinal anaesthetic. It can be administered as boluses of 50-100mcg [14][20][23] to maintain maternal BP at baseline values or it can be administered as an infusion of 100mcg/min started immediately after spinal anaesthesia and then titrated to response [11][17][26][27][28][29][30].


Guideline

Caesarean section
National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence, 2004
Link to guideline

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Safety of breast implants
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Safety of breast implantsBy Miss Rakhee Nayar, Clinical Research Fellow, and Mr Rowan Pritchard-Jones, Topic Advisor for the Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia and SpR, Royal Liverpool Children's Hospital

Cite this resource

Introduction

The British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS) recently announced the results of the UK’s largest-ever survey of breast augmentation trends1 at their annual meeting. The survey examines six years’ worth of data. Twenty-six thousand, eight hundred and fifty-two breast augmentation procedures were carried out by BAAPS members from 2002 to 2007. The number of breast augmentations has risen by 275% in this period. Since the early 1990s, a number of independent systematic comprehensive reviews have examined studies in this growing group of patients, concerning links between silicone gel breast implants and systemic/breast disease. Links investigated include higher incidence of breast cancer within this patient group, capsular contracture and neurological and rheumatological problems. This review seeks to clarify current opinion based on high level evidence currently available in each of these areas.


Breast implants and cancer

The current estimate is that 8,000 women in the UK have breast implants each year for augmentation or reconstruction purposes. Current Cancer Research UK statistics state that the lifetime risk of developing breast cancer is 1 in 9. Therefore, some women with implants will also coincidentally develop mammary malignancies. Controversy that a link may exist began in the 1940s, when clinicians observed sarcoma formations in response to foreign bodies implanted in rodents2. These findings, coupled with case reports, led clinicians to hypothesize that breast implants might cause cancer in humans, in particular breast cancer3,4,5. Subsequently, this conjecture was extended to more rare cancers. A literature review and meta-analysis of the data concluded that women with implants should be reassured by the consistency of scientific studies which have uniformly determined that, compared with women without implants, they are not at increased risk of breast cancer, are not diagnosed with later-stage breast malignancies, are not at increased risk of breast cancer recurrence and do not have a decreased length of survival6. At present, although high level evidence is lacking, there is no convincing evidence that breast implants alter the risk of development of non-breast malignancies7.


Capsular contracture

A meta-analysis of findings of six prospective randomised controlled trials suggested that surface texturisation of the implant reduces capsular contracture in subglandular breast augmentation8. All trials included were similarly structured and well designed. Outcome measures were reduction in capsular contracture as defined by Baker grade, a universally accepted standard for breast firmness assessment, applanation tonometry and patient self-assessment. Six randomised controlled trials were identified with a total of 235 patients (470 breasts). Textured implants were associated with less capsular contracture as evaluated by Baker grade at one year (relative risk 4.16; 95% confidence interval, 1.58 to 10.96), three years (relative risk 7.25; 95% confidence interval, 2.42 to 21.69), and seven years (relative risk 2.98; 95% confidence interval, 0.86 to 10.37) of follow-up. Applanation tonometry used as an objective measure of firmness was not sensitive enough to detect any significant difference in contractures in the two groups (weighted mean differences -1.54; 95% confidence interval, -6.83 to -3.75). The authors favoured the use of textured implants over smooth implants in subglandular breast augmentation in the short term. Better long-term studies were recommended to determine whether this advantage is maintained over time. Similarly, a meta-analysis of seven RCTs found significantly lower rates of capsular contracture with the use of textured implants9. However, when all seven studies were pooled, the odds ratio was found to be 0.19 (95% confidence interval, 0.07 to 0.52), indicating a protective effect for surface texturing on the rate of capsular contracture. Submuscular placement was the only subgroup in which significance was not achieved. However, this subgroup consisted of a single study, which was dramatically underpowered.


Connective tissue disease

A systematic review of relevant cohort, cross-sectional and case control studies, for which an independent scientific panel was appointed to determine whether a link exists between rheumatologic disease and silicone breast implants has been published10. Twenty-four suitable studies were identified and no link was found between connective disease and silicone breast implants. A further meta-analysis included 20 case–control, cohort and cross-sectional studies with and without adjustment for confounding factors and a separate analysis restricted to studies of silicone-gel–filled breast implants11. There was no evidence of an association between breast implants in general, or silicone gel–filled breast implants specifically, and any of the individual connective-tissue diseases, all definite connective-tissue diseases combined, or other autoimmune or rheumatic conditions.

Guidelines

Patient information

References


Guidelines

  • Breast Implants
    Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency
    Link to website   Link to printable summary (April 2007) [PDF]


Patient information

  • Breast implants
    NHS Choices
    Link to website

  • Information for women considering breast implants (2005)
    Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency
    Link to full text [PDF]

  • Breast implant (mammaplasty)
    Department of Health
    Link to website

  • Breast augmentation
    The British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons
    Link to website

  • FDA Breast Implant Consumer Handbook (2004)
    US Food and Drug Administration
    Link to 80-page handbook [PDF]

References

1. Surgeons reveal UK's largest-ever breast augmentation survey. The British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons Link to website


2. Turner FC, Sarcomas at sites of subcutaneously implanted Bakelite disks in rats. Journal of the National Cancer Institute 1941; 2: 81. (no abstract available)


3. Oppenheimer BS, Oppenheimer ET, Stout AP. Sarcomas induced in rats by implanting cellophane.Proceedings of the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine 1948; 67(1): 33. (no abstract available)


4. Hoopes JE, Edgerton MT, Shelley W. Organic synthetics for augmentation mammaplasty: Their relation to breast cancer. Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery 1967; 39(3): 263-270. (no abstract available)


5. Harris HI. Survey of breast implants from the point of view of carcinogenesis. Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery and the Transplantation Bulletin 1961; 28: 81-3. (no abstract available)


6. Hoshaw SJ, Klein PJ, Clark, BD, Cook RR, Perkins LL. Breast implants and cancer: causation, delayed detection, and survival. Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery 2001; 107(6): 1393-1408. Link to abstract


7. Brinton LA. The relationship of silicone breast implants and cancer at other sites. Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery 2007; 120(7 Suppl 1): 94S-102S. Link to abstract


8. Wong CH, Samuel M, Tan B K, Song C. Capsular contracture in subglandular breast augmentation with textured versus smooth breast implants: a systematic review. Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery 2006; 118(5): 1224-36. Link to abstract


9. Barnsley GP, Sigurdson LJ, Barnsley SE. Textured surface breast implants in the prevention of capsular contracture among breast augmentation patients: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Plastic Reconstructive Surgery 2006; 117(7): 2182-90. Link to abstract


10. Tugwell P, Wells G, Peterson J, Welch V, Page J, Davison C, McGowan J, Ramroth D, Shea B. Do silicone breast implants cause rheumatologic disorders? A systematic review for a court-appointed national science panel. Arthritis and Rheumatism 2001; 44(11): 2477-84. Link to abstract


11. Janowsky EC, Kupper LL, Hulka BS. Meta-analyses of the relation between silicone breast implants and the risk of connective-tissue diseases. New England Journal of Medicine 2000; 342: 781-90. Link to full text
