document.title: Mini topic review: Sentinel lymph node biopsy for breast cancer
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.description: Summary of evidence on technical aspects and potential new indications for sentinel lymph node biopsy
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Sentinel lymph node biopsy for breast cancer

By AR Carmichael, Consultant breast surgeon, Russells Hall Hospital, Dudley


Cite this resource


Introduction

Sentinel node biopsy (SLNB) is one of the most exciting developments in the surgical management of breast cancer in the modern era. This technique significantly reduces the upper limb morbidity in patients with node negative breast cancer while providing accurate staging of breast cancer.
Evidence was reviewed regarding indications for SLNB such as tumour characteristics, previous surgery and patient gender. The technical aspects of the operation were also explored such as site of injection for dye or radioactive trace, and usefulness and timing of imaging techniques such as lymphoscintigraphy.

Literature searches were undertaken for guidelines, systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials using Medline, Embase, the National Library for Health, the Cochrane Library and the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination. Searches were performed for English language papers on indications for SLNB, injection techniques and use of lymphoscintigraphy from 2000 to October 2006. The results of the searches showed that, though SLNB has been established for some years, there is a relative paucity of evidence from randomised controlled trials.


Indications

Injection Site

Lymphoscintigraphy

Ongoing Trials

Patient Information

Indications
Sentinel node biopsy is a procedure of choice for early stage, clinically node-negative breast cancer. But the evidence suggests that SLNB may also be safely undertaken for the following patient groups:
  • Patients who have received pre-operative chemotherapy
  • Patients who have undertaken previous diagnostics or therapeutic breast surgery
  • Patients with multifocal breast cancer without compromising the accuracy of axillary staging
  • Male patients
  • Pregnant patients

References - indications

Xing Y, Foy M, Cox D, Kuerer H, Hunt K, Cormier J. Meta-analysis of sentinel lymph node biopsy after preoperative chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. British Journal of Surgery 2006; 93(5):539-46. (link to abstract here)

Mamounas E, Brown A, Anderson S, Smith R, Julian T, Miller B, et al. Sentinel node biopsy after neoadjuvant chemotherapy in breast cancer: results from National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project Protocol B-27. Journal of Clinical Oncology 2005; 23(12):2694-702. (link to full text here)

Luini A, Galimberti V, Gatti G, Arnone P, Vento AR, Trifiro G, et al. The sentinel node biopsy after previous breast surgery: preliminary results on 543 patients treated at the European Institute of Oncology. Breast Cancer Research & Treatment 2005; 89(2):159-63. (link to abstract here) 

Gentilini O, Trifiro G, Soteldo J, Luini A, Intra M, Glimberti V, et al. Sentinel lymph node biopsy in multicentric breast cancer. The experience of the European Institute of Oncology. European Journal of Surgical Oncology 2006; 32(5):507-10. (link to abstract here)

Knauer M, Konstantiniuk P, Haid A, Wenzl E, Riegler-Keil M, Postlberger S, et al. Multicentric breast cancer: a new indication for sentinel node biopsy-a multi-institutional validation study. Journal of Clinical Oncology 2006; 24(21):3374-80. (link to abstract here) 

Boughey J, Bedrosian I, Meric-Bernstam F, Ross M, Kuerer H, Akins J, et al. Comparative Analysis of Sentinel Lymph Node Operation in Male and Female Breast Cancer Patients. Journal of the American College of Surgeons 2006; 203(4):475-80. (link to abstract here)

Goyal A, Horgan K, Kissin M, Yiangou C, Sibbering M, Lansdown M, et al. Sentinel lymph node biopsy in male breast cancer patients. European Journal of Surgical Oncology 2004; 30(5):480-3. (link to abstract here)

Gentilini O, Cremonesi M, Trifiro G, Ferrari M, Baio SM, Caracciolo M, et al. Safety of sentinel node biopsy in pregnant patients with breast cancer. Annals of Oncology 2004; 15(9):1348-51. (link to full text here)


Injection site
It was found that periareolar injection has a better sentinel node detection rate than peritumour injection of the dye or radio-labelled material.
The evidence also suggests that an intradermal or subcutaneous approach was better in identifying the sentinel lymph node as compared to intratumour approach

References - injection site

Anan K, Mitsuyama S, Kuga H, Saimura M, Tanabe Y, Suehara N, et al. Double mapping with subareolar blue dye and peritumoral green dye injections decreases the false-negative rate of dye-only sentinel node biopsy for early breast cancer: 2-site injection is more accurate than 1-site injection. Surgery 2006;139(5):624-29. (link to abstract here)

Chagpar A, Martin R, Chao C, Wong S, Edwards M, Tuttle T, et al. Validation of subareolar and periareolar injection techniques for breast sentinel lymph node biopsy. Archives of Surgery 2004; 139(6):614-8. (link to full text here)

van Wessem K, Meijer W. Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast cancer: results of intradermal periareolar tracer injection and follow-up of sentinel lymph node-negative patients. Breast 2004; 13(4):290-6. (link to abstract here)

Pelosi E, Bello M, Giors M, Ala A, Giani R, Bussone R, et al. Sentinel lymph node detection in patients with early-stage breast cancer: comparison of periareolar and subdermal/peritumoral injection techniques. Journal of Nuclear Medicine 2004; 45(2):220-5. (link to full text here)

Motomura K, Komoike Y, Hasegawa Y, Kasugai T, Inaji H, Noguchi S, et al. Intradermal radioisotope injection is superior to subdermal injection for the identification of the sentinel node in breast cancer patients. Journal of Surgical Oncology 2003; 82(2):91-6. (link to abstract here)


Lymphoscintigraphy
The evidence suggested that:
  • Lymphoscintigraphy was shown to be helpful but not essential to detect axillary sentinel nodes.
  • Lymphoscintigraphy can be helpful in detecting extra-axillary sentinel nodes, but the exact clinical significance of this is not clear.
  • A negative lymphoscintigram does not exclude axillary metastasis.
  • A delayed lymphoscintigram (after 24 hours) may improve sentinel node pick up rate.

References - lymphoscintigraphy

Goyal A, Newcombe R, Mansel R, Chetty U, Ell P, Fallowfield L, et al. Role of routine preoperative lymphoscintigraphy in sentinel node biopsy for breast cancer. European Journal of Cancer 2005; 41(2):238-43. (link to abstract here)

Rubello D, Zavagno G, Bozza F, Lise M, De Salvo G, Saladini G, et al. Analysis of technical and clinical variables affecting sentinel node localization in patients with breast cancer after a single intradermal injection of 99mTc nanocolloidal albumin. Nuclear Medicine Communications 2004; 25(11):1119-24. (link to abstract here)


Ongoing Trialstext
  • Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy and Primary Tumor Gene Expression Profiling in Finding Axillary Lymph Node Metastases in Women Who Have Received Neoadjuvant Therapy for Stage II, Stage III, or Stage IV Breast Cancer (link to record on ClinicalTrials.gov)
  • Sentinel Node Biopsy and Axillary Sampling in Operable Breast Cancer (link to record on ClinicalTrials.gov)
  • Prospective Multicentric Study of Sentinel Lymph Node Assessment Following Previous Surgical Biopsy for Early Breast Cancer (link to record on ClinicalTrials.gov)
  • Evaluation of Two New Medical Instruments Dedicated to the Sentinel Lymph Node Technique in Case of Breast Cancer (link to record on ClinicalTrials.gov)
  • Technetium Tc 99m Sulfur Colloid and Blue Dye In Detecting Sentinel Lymph Nodes in Patients With Breast Cancer (link to record on ClinicalTrials.gov)
  • Identification of Sentinel Lymph Nodes With Methylene Blue and Isotope (link to record on ClinicalTrials.gov)

Patient Information

Cancernews.com (USA): sentinel lymph node biopsy: what breast cancer patients need to know. (link to website)

National Cancer Institute (USA): sentinel lymph node questions and answers. (link to website)

BreastCancer.org (USA): section on sentinel lymph node dissection. (link to website)

Cancer Research UK: Targeted lymph node removal (sentinel lymph node biopsy) (link to website) 

Cite this resource:
Carmichael AR. Sentinel lymph node biopsy for breast cancer - a mini topic review. National Library for Health [published February 2007; downloaded (date of access)]. Available from: http://www.library.nhs.uk/theatres/ViewResource.aspx?resID=235956&tabID=290

document.title: Mini topic review: Surgical Management of Atrial Fibrillation
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CONDITIONS,ARRHYTHMIA,SURGICAL PROCEDURES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,GENERAL/OTHER,SURGERY,SURGERY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,HEART,CARDIAC ARRHYTHMIAS,COMPLICATIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR,ATRIAL FIBRILLATION]]>
document.description: An introduction to the management of atrial fibrillation and a summary of the current evidence.
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Surgical Management of Atrial Fibrillation

By Antonios Kourliouros MRCS Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery, St George’s Hospital, London, UK


Cite this resource


Introduction

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common arrhythmia in clinical practice with an incidence of 19.2/1000 patient-years in males >= 65 [1]. Pharmacological treatment has been the mainstay of AF management aiming at heart rate control, prevention of thromboembolism and restoration of sinus rhythm [2]. Available data on the electrophysiological mechanisms of AF led to the development of surgical techniques resulting in the disruption of conduction of electric re-entrant wavelets in the atria which are responsible for the development and maintenance of AF. These procedures are typically performed as part of concomitant cardiac operations such as mitral valve replacement or repair. Isolated AF surgery can also be performed, but this is not routine practice. The Cox-maze has been the first non-pharmacological procedure for the treatment of AF. Although first described in 1991 [3], technical difficulties and complications associated with the original procedure led to modifications, namely the Cox-maze II and finally the Cox-maze III procedure [4]. Atrial lesion sets as described in the Cox-maze III procedure can also be achieved with energy-based techniques using radiofrequency ablation, cryoablation, microwave and ultrasound ablation [5].

The Cox-maze III 'cut and sew' procedure has remained the gold standard for AF surgery with restoration of sinus rhythm in >90% of patients, to which all other ablative techniques are compared. However, most ablative techniques have shown similar success rates with the advantage of shorter and technically less demanding operations. More recently, thoracoscopic ablative procedures that can be performed in isolation and without the need for cardiopulmonary bypass have been developed and show promising results but further evaluation is necessary [6], [7].

Literature searches were undertaken for guidelines, systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials using Medline, Embase, the National Library for Health, the Cochrane Library and the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination. Searches were performed for English language papers from 2004 to February 2007.
Key text words included atrial fibrillation, concomitant, cardiac surgery, Cox maze, microwave ablation, radiofrequency ablation and cryo-ablation to capture the gold standard surgical procedures along with alternative ablative techniques.

Searches were also undertaken to find patient information and locate details of current and forthcoming trials relevant to the surgical treatment of atrial fibrillation as part of concomitant cardiac surgery.


Current Evidence

Guidelines

Meta-analyses

Systematic Reviews


Guidelines
  • Maze procedure: [12] Calkins H, Brugada J, Packer DL, Cappato R, Chen SA, Crijns HJ, et al. EuroHRS/EHRA/ECAS Expert consensus statement on catheter and surgical ablation of atrial fibrillation: Recommendations for personnel, policy, procedures and follow-Up. Europace 2007 Jun;9(6):335-379.
    Link to abstract (the full text of this article will not be freely available until one year from publication)

    General guidelines for the treatment of atrial fibrillation, where the 'cut and sew' approach is offered as an option when medical treatment fails, have been published by NICE and in the American Heart Association’s Circulation Journal.
    • Atrial fibrillation - full guideline. NICE, June 2006
      Link to guideline
    • ACC/AHA/ESC 2006 Guidelines for the management of patients with atrial fibrillation. Circulation, August 2006
      Link to guidelines


  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA): Radiofrequency ablation for atrial fibrillation in association with other cardiac surgery. NICE, May 2005
    Link to guideline


  • Cryoablation: Cryoablation for atrial fibrillation in association with other cardiac surgery. NICE, May 2005
    Link to guideline


  • Microwave ablation: Microwave ablation for atrial fibrillation in association with other cardiac surgery. NICE, May 2005
    Link to guideline


  • Ultrasound ablation: High intensity focused ultrasound ablation for atrial fibrillation as an associated procedure with other cardiac surgery. NICE, July 2006
    Link to guideline

Meta-analyses
  • [8] Barnett SD, Ad N. Surgical ablation as treatment for the elimination of atrial fibrillation: a meta-analysis. Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery. 2006 May;131(5):1029-35. (link to abstract)


  • [9] Wong JW, Mak KH. Impact of maze and concomitant mitral valve surgery on clinical outcomes. Annals of Thoracic Surgery. 2006 Nov;82(5):1938-47. (link to abstract)


  • [10] Reston JT, Shuhaiber JH. Meta-analysis of clinical outcomes of maze-related surgical procedures for medically refractory atrial fibrillation. European Journal of Cardiothoracic Surgery. 2005 Nov;28(5):724-30. (link to abstract)

Systematic Reviews
  • [5] Jahangiri M, Weir G, Mandal K, Savelieva I, Camm J. Current strategies in the management of atrial fibrillation. Annals of Thoracic Surgery. 2006 Jul;82(1):357-64. (link to abstract)


  • Ablation for atrial fibrillation. Health technology policy assessment. Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care, Ontario, Canada. March 2006 (link to documents)


  • [11] Khargi K, Hutten BA, Lemke B, Deneke T. Surgical treatment of atrial fibrillation; a systematic review. European Journal of Cardiothoracic Surgery. 2005 Feb;27(2):258-65. (link to full text)


  • A systematic review of intraoperative ablation for the treatment of atrial fibrillation. Royal Australasian College of Surgeons ASERNIP-S. July 2004 (link to documents)

Public Information from NICE (National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence)

In addition to publishing guidelines for healthcare professionals, NICE also provides public information on the following surgical treatments for atrial fibrillation.

  • Radiofrequency ablation for atrial fibrillation in association with other cardiac surgery - information for people considering the procedure, and for the public
    Link to public information from NICE


  • Cryoablation for atrial fibrillation in association with other cardiac surgery - information for people considering the procedure, and for the public
    Link to public information from NICE


  • Microwave ablation for atrial fibrillation in association with other cardiac surgery - information for people considering the procedure, and for the public
    Link to public information from NICE


  • High-intensity focused ultrasound for atrial fibrillation as an associated procedure with other cardiac surgery - information for the public
    Link to public information from NICE

Ongoing Trials

Trials relevant to the surgical treatment of atrial fibrillation and concomitant cardiac surgery are listed in ClinicalTrials.gov, a service that provides information on clinical research studies worldwide.

  • Concomitant utilization of radio frequency energy for atrial fibrillation (CURE-AF) study
    View trial details


  • Atrial fibrillation ablation device comparison study
    View trial details


  • Clinical and economic consequences of left atrial bipolar radiofrequency ablation of persistent and permanent atrial fibrillation during cardiac surgery
    View trial details

References

  • [1] Psaty BM, Manolio TA, Kuller LH, Kronmal RA, Cushman M, Fried LP, et al. Incidence of and risk factors for atrial fibrillation in older adults. Circulation. 1997 Oct 7;96(7):2455-61. (link to full text)


  • [2] Fuster V, Ryden LE, Cannom DS, Crijns HJ, Curtis AB, Ellenbogen KA, et al. ACC/AHA/ESC 2006 Guidelines for the Management of Patients with Atrial Fibrillation: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines and the European Society of Cardiology Committee for Practice Guidelines (Writing Committee to Revise the 2001 Guidelines for the Management of Patients With Atrial Fibrillation): developed in collaboration with the European Heart Rhythm Association and the Heart Rhythm Society. Circulation. 2006 Aug 15;114(7):e257-354. (link to full text)


  • [3] Cox JL, Schuessler RB, D'Agostino HJ, Jr., Stone CM, Chang BC, Cain ME, et al. The surgical treatment of atrial fibrillation. III. Development of a definitive surgical procedure. Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery. 1991 Apr;101(4):569-83. (link to abstract)


  • [4] Cox JL, Jaquiss RD, Schuessler RB, Boineau JP. Modification of the maze procedure for atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation. II. Surgical technique of the maze III procedure. Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery. 1995 Aug;110(2):485-95. (link to abstract)


  • [5] Jahangiri M, Weir G, Mandal K, Savelieva I, Camm J. Current strategies in the management of atrial fibrillation. Annals of Thoracic Surgery. 2006 Jul;82(1):357-64. (link to abstract)


  • [6] Pruitt JC, Lazzara RR, Dworkin GH, Badhwar V, Kuma C, Ebra G. Totally endoscopic ablation of lone atrial fibrillation: initial clinical experience. Annals of Thoracic Surgery. 2006 Apr;81(4):1325-30; discussion 30-1. (link to full text)


  • [7] Sagbas E, Akpinar B, Sanisoglu I, Caynak B, Tamtekin B, Oral K, et al. Video-assisted bilateral epicardial pulmonary vein isolation for the treatment of lone atrial fibrillation. Annals of Thoracic Surgery. 2007 May;83(5):1724-30. (link to abstract)


  • [8] Barnett SD, Ad N. Surgical ablation as treatment for the elimination of atrial fibrillation: a meta-analysis. Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery. 2006 May;131(5):1029-35. (link to abstract)


  • [9] Wong JW, Mak KH. Impact of maze and concomitant mitral valve surgery on clinical outcomes. Annals of Thoracic Surgery. 2006 Nov;82(5):1938-47. (link to abstract)


  • [10] Reston JT, Shuhaiber JH. Meta-analysis of clinical outcomes of maze-related surgical procedures for medically refractory atrial fibrillation. European Journal of Cardiothoracic Surgery. 2005 Nov;28(5):724-30. (link to abstract)


  • [11] Khargi K, Hutten BA, Lemke B, Deneke T. Surgical treatment of atrial fibrillation; a systematic review. European Journal of Cardiothoracic Surgery. 2005 Feb;27(2):258-65. (link to full text)


  • [12] Calkins H, Brugada J, Packer DL, Cappato R, Chen SA, Crijns HJ, et al. HRS/EHRA/ECAS Expert consensus statement on catheter and surgical ablation of atrial fibrillation: Recommendations for personnel, policy, procedures and follow-Up. Europace 2007 Jun;9(6):335-379. (link to full text
Cite this resource:
Kourliouros A. Surgical Management of Atrial Fibrillation – a mini topic review. Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia, National Library for Health [published July 2007; downloaded (date of access)]. Available from: http://www.library.nhs.uk/theatres/ViewResource.aspx?resID=262329&tabID=290

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: The diagnosis and management of gynaecomastia
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: The diagnosis and management of gynaecomastia

By  Mr Ahmed El Gawad MD, SpR Plastic Surgery, Whiston Hospital, Liverpool and Mr Rowan Pritchard Jones, SpR Plastic Surgery, Royal Liverpool Children's Hospital and Topic Advisor for NHS Evidence – surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care

Cite this resource

Introduction

Gynaecomastia is a common benign proliferation of the glandular component of the male breast and is caused by an increase in the ratio of estrogen to androgen activity1. It can be unilateral or bilateral and consists of a palpable mass of tissue. Most males experience some degree of gynaecomastia during their lives, and up to 65% of adolescent boys may be affected2.

Causes

Common causes of gynaecomastia include:

  • Idiopathic – of an unknown cause
  • Physiologic (not related to disease) – Bembo et al state that physiological gynaecomastia is commonly observed during the following three phases of the male lifespan2:
    • Neonatal period –  transient gynaecomastia may occur in 60–90% of infants "due to transplacental transfer of maternal estrogens"2.
    • Puberty – may be observed in 48–64% of boys at puberty due to a relative excess of oestrogen2.
    • Later life –a high incidence of gynaecomastia has been observed in men aged 50–80 years and is associated with a drop in circulating testosterone2.
  • Pathologic (related to diseases) - typically this is due to liver disease such as cirrhosis, or tumours of the thyroid, adrenals or testis. It is also seen with congenital or acquired hypogonadism.
  • Pharmacologic (drug related) – Bembo et al have listed a number of drugs that can cause gynaecomastia including the drug mechanism2. Gynaecomastia can be associated with the use of anabolic steroids by bodybuilders.

Clinical examination and investigation

Clinical examination must include the breast, testis, thyroid, liver and hair distribution. Appropriate laboratory testing may include:

  1. FBC – full blood count
  2. Hormone levels – oestrogen, testosterone, prolactin, growth hormone
  3. Mammogram – if there is a suspicion of a breast cancer (although there is no excess risk of breast cancer in patients with gynaecomastia)
  4. Ultrasound scan of testes or thyroid if there is concern about a possible tumour
  5. Testing for alpha foeto-protein or beta HCG if testicular problem suspected
  6. Core biopsy of the breast to confirm clinical diagnosis and exclude male breast cancer

The treatment of gynaecomastia

Non-operative treatments

Treatment options vary depending on the cause of the individual’s gynaecomastia. Some gynaecomastia cases require no treatment such as in the neonate. Also, when presented in the adolescent, it will usually subside with time2. Careful explanation and follow-up is important. It most commonly regresses 3-18 months after enlargement, but if presence continues beyond 12 months it regresses less well due to tissue fibrosis2.

Pharmacological gynaecomastia will often respond to modification or elimination of the medication regimen. Metabolic gynaecomastia may be treated with restoration of proper nutrition or treatment of the underlying liver disease.

Patients whose condition is endocrine-dependent (hormone driven) may benefit from treatment with antioestrogen medications such as Tamoxifen or Anastrazole3. These are unlicensed indications, but can  be useful for men with enlargement of the breast disc, as opposed to fatty type gynaecomastia. 

Operative treatments

Cordova et al propose a classification of gynaecomastia by severity to assist in the choice of surgical technique4. An illustration of the morphological classification is illustrated in Figure 14. Patients may be considered candidates for surgical intervention if they are rated as Grade II, III or IV and when systemic conditions have been ruled out1. Various surgical techniques have been used. The technique employed depends on the consistency of the tissue and the amount of redundant skin.

The traditional technique for gynaecomastia is subcutaneous mastectomy. In some cases, fatty excess may be removed by liposuction and true breast disc enlargement by vacuum assisted core (Mammotome®)5.

Subcutaneous mastectomy
Surgeons use a hemicircumareolar or periareolar incision and preservation of the nipple. Understandably, surgery may be associated with complications, such as a doughnut deformity (excessive flattening around the nipple where tissue has been removed), nipple necrosis, nipple flattening, inversion or loss of sensation and the most common early complication, bleeding1.


Liposuction
Liposuction can correct abnormal and excessive collections of adipose tissue and is regarded by many investigators as one of the most effective treatments for fatty type gynaecomastia as it is associated with few adverse sequelae6. Different modalities of liposuction have been used. Hodgson et al advocate better results with ultrasound assisted liposuction7. This resulted in less bruising and swelling and improved postoperative skin contraction7. Liposuction combined with excision of the gland resulted in higher patient satisfaction, better cosmesis and fewer complications compared to traditional surgical excision alone1.

Vacuum assisted core (Mammotome®)5
This technique can be useful in men with true enlargement of the breast parenchymal disc as well as fatty enlargement. Liposuction is generally not effective in treating men with parenchymal thickening, as the breast tissue is too tough for the liposuction cannula.

 

Guidelines

Patient information

References

document.title: Mini topic review: The management of gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST)
document.publisher: NLH Specialist Library for Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,STOMACH & DUODENUM,SMALL INTESTINE,GASTRIC TUMOURS,SMALL BOWEL TUMOURS]]>
document.description: This review provides an introduction to the management of gastrointestinal stromal tumours.
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: The management of gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST)

By Zaher Toumi, ST2 General Surgery, Lancashire Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust


Cite this resource


Introduction to GISTs (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumours)

1. What are GISTs?

Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs) are the most common mesenchymal neoplasms of the gastrointestinal tract. Most are small benign nodules detected incidentally, but 20-30% are malignant.

2. Are GISTs common?

No, GISTs are rare. Among the histological types of gastrointestinal (GI) tumours, they are third in prevalence behind adenocarcinomas and lymphomas. They constitute 0.1-3% of GI cancers.

3. What kind of cells do GISTs originate from?

GISTs are thought to originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal. These are GI pacemaker cells and are largely responsible for initiating and coordinating GI motility. Around 90% of GISTs express KIT (CD117 or stem cell factor) receptors, detected by immunohistochemistry, 60-70% express CD34. The interstitial cells of Cajal share KIT positivity with GISTs. They also have similar ultrastructural features and have a similar form of embryonic smooth muscle myosin.

4. What are the common sites for GISTs?

  • 50-70% of GISTs originate in the stomach
  • 20-30% originate in the small intestine
  • Less frequent sites include the colon and rectum (5-15%), and oesophagus (<5%)

5. What are the epidemiological features of GISTs?

Approximately 10-20 persons per million population are diagnosed with GISTs each year. GISTs have no known racial proclivity. Slightly more males than females are diagnosed with GISTs. GISTs are most commonly diagnosed in the age group 55-65 years. GISTs are extremely uncommon in children.

6. What are the causes of GISTs?

KIT is part of the family of receptor tyrosine kinases. It is a transmembrane growth factor receptor for stem cell factor. It is functionally important and expressed in the interstitial cell of Cajal. Activation of KIT is important in the development of many GISTs. A gain-of-function mutation in KIT’s gene (c-kit) is usually present.

7. What is the treatment for GISTs?

Surgery is the definitive therapy for patients with GISTs. Radical and complete surgical resection offers the only chance for cure, but not all lesions are completely resectable. The only effective, specific, nonsurgical therapy for GISTs is the protein kinase inhibitor, imatinib mesylate. The optimal dose for imatinib mesylate in the adjuvant or neoadjuvant setting remains to be defined.

View the entry for imatinib on the British National Formulary (BNF) website. Please note that this site requires free registration to view content.


Are there any guidelines for the treatment of GISTs?

  • Guidelines for the management of gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs)
    Association of Upper Gastrointestinal Surgeons (AUGIS), September 2005.
    Link to guidelines

  • Scottish GISTs Guidelines
    Beatson Oncology Centre, June 2006.
    Link to guidelines


What are the conclusions of Randomised Controlled Trials which have been carried out for GISTs?

2007

The research paper:
Blay JY, Le Cesne A, Ray-Coquard I, Bui B, Duffaud F, Delbaldo C, et al. Prospective multicentric randomized phase III study of imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors comparing interruption versus continuation of treatment beyond 1 year: the French Sarcoma Group. Journal of Clinical Oncology 2007 Mar 20;25(9):1107-13.
Link to abstract

The research question:
For patients who have GISTs treated by imatinib, is it safe to stop the treatment after 1 year?.

The paper’s conclusion:
Imatininb interruption results in rapid progression in most patients with advanced GIST.


2006

The research paper:
Debiec-Rychter M, Sciot R, Le Cesne A, Schlemmer M, Hohenberger P, van Oosterom AT, et al EORTC Soft Tissue and Bone Sarcoma Group. The Italian Sarcoma Group. Australasian GastroIntestinal Trials Group. KIT mutations and dose selection for imatinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours. European Journal of Cancer 2006 May;42(8):1093-103.
Link to abstract

The research question:
Is there correlation of tumour mutational status with clinical response to imatininb?

The paper’s conclusion:

  • presence of exon-9 activating mutation was the strongest adverse prognostic factor for response to imatinib. It increases risk of progression by 171% and relative risk of death by 190%
  • Absence of detectable KIT or PDGFRA mutations increases risk of progression by 108% and relative risk of death by 76%
  • In the presense of Exon 9 KIT oncoprotein: treatment with high dose imatininb lead to a significantly superior progression free survival and decrease risk of death by 61%

The research paper:
Glabbeke MV, Verweij J, Casali PG, Simes J, Cesne AL, Reichardt P, et al. Predicting toxicities for patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours treated with imatinib: A study of the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer, the Italian Sarcoma Group, and the Australasian Gastro-Intestinal Trials Group (EORTC-ISG-AGITG). European Journal of Cancer 2006 Sep;42(14):2277-85.
Link to abstract

The research question:
What are the factors which predict imatininb toxicities for patient with advanced GIST?

The paper’s conclusion:
Anaemia:

  • dose
  • baseline haemoglobin level
Neutropaenia:
  • baseline neutrophil count
  • Haemoglobin level
Non haematological toxicities:
  • dose dependent
  • females
  • advanced age
  • poor performance status
  • prior chemoptherapy
  • tumours of identified GI origin

The research paper:
Demetri GD, van Oosterom AT, Garrett CR, Blackstein ME, Shah MH, Verweij J, et al. Efficacy and safety of sunitinib in patients with advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumour after failure of imatinib: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet 2006 Oct 14;368(9544):1329-38.
Link to abstract
Full text available for NHS Athens holders Log in here to view

The research question:
Is sunitinib an efficacious and well tolerated treatment for unresectable imatinib resistant GISTs?

The paper’s conclusion:
Significantly longer time to tumour progression with sunitinib. Therapy was reasonably well tolerated.


2005

The research paper:
Zalcberg JR, Verweij J, Casali PG, Le Cesne A, Reichardt P, Blay JY, et al. Outcome of patients with advanced gastro-intestinal stromal tumours crossing over to a daily imatinib dose of 800 mg after progression on 400 mg. European Journal of Cancer 2005 Aug;41(12):1751-7.
Link to abstract

The research question:
Is it feasible, safe and efficacious to crossover from 400mg imatinib to 800 mg imatinib upon progression?

The paper’s conclusion:
A cross-over is safe, feasible and beneficial.

The research paper:
Van Glabbeke M, Verweij J, Casali PG, Le Cesne A, Hohenberger P, Ray-Coquard I, et al. Initial and late resistance to imatinib in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors are predicted by different prognostic factors: a European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer-Italian Sarcoma Group-Australasian Gastrointestinal Trials Group study. Journal of Clinical Oncology 2005 Aug 20;23(24):5795-804.
Link to full text

The research question:
What are the prognostic factors in initial and late resistance to imatinib in advanced GISTs.

The paper’s conclusion:
Initial resistance can be predicted by:

  • Presence of lung metastasis
  • Absence of liver metastasis
  • Low haemoglobin
  • High granulocytes
Late resistance can be predicted by:
  • high granulocyte count
  • primary tumour outside of the stomach
  • large tumour size
  • low initial imatinib dose
Impact of initial dose on resistance was mainly significant in:
  • high granulocyte count
  • tumours of GI origin outside stomach and small intestine

2004

The research paper:
Verweij J, Casali PG, Zalcberg J, LeCesne A, Reichardt P, Blay JY, et al. Progression-free survival in gastrointestinal stromal tumours with high-dose imatinib: randomised trial. Lancet 2004 Sep 25-Oct 1;364(9440):1127-34.
Link to abstract
Full text available for NHS Athens holders Log in here to view

The research question:
What is the optimal dose of imatinib for induction of response and for prolongation of progression free survival?

The paper’s conclusion:
A daily dose of 400 mg of imatinib is sufficient if response induction was the only aim of treatment
A dose of 400 mg twice a day achieves significant longer progression free survival.


Are there any ongoing clinical trials relevant to the management of GISTs?

There are number of ongoing trials relevant to the management of GISTs. These are listed in ClinicalTrials.gov, a service that provides information on clinical research studies worldwide.

Trial Condition(s) Status (August 2007)
Radiation therapy as palliative treatment of GIST Sarcoma Recruiting
Study comparing 12 months Versus 36 months of imatinib in the treatment of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) Sarcoma; GIST Recruiting
Gastrointestinal stromal tumors Registry GISTs Recruiting
Safety study of IPI-504 in patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) or soft tissue sarcomas (STS) GISTs; Soft tissue sarcomas Recruiting
The biological activity of AZD2171 in GIST GIST; Soft tissue sarcomas Recruiting
Post-marketing clinical study of postoperative adjuvant therapy With imatinib mesylate in patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) GIST Recruiting
Phase II study of perifosine plus Gleevec for patients with GIST GIST Recruiting
Preoperative and postoperative imatinib mesylate study in patients With c-Kit positive GIST GIST Recruiting
Phase I Study of imatinib mesylate and SU011248 (sunitinib) for Patients With GIST GIST Not yet recruiting
Prospective multicentric randomized study of Glivec® in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumors expressing c-Kit: interruption after 3 years vs maintenance Sarcoma; GIST Recruiting
Adjuvant imatinib in high-risk GIST with c-Kit mutation GIST; Sarcoma Recruiting
Imatinib mesylate in treating patients with locally advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumor GIST Recruiting
Efficacy and safety of AMN107 compared with current treatment options in patients with GIST who have failed both imatinib and sunitinib GIST Recruiting
Efficacy and safety of AMN107 (nilotinib) compared with current treatment options in patients with GIST who have failed both imatinib and sunitinib - extension GIST Recruiting
Imatinib mesylate or observation only in treating patients who have undergone surgery for localized gastrointestinal stromal tumor GIST Recruiting
PTK787/ZK222584 in the treatment of metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumors resistant to imatinib Sarcoma Recruiting
Treatment of patients with everolimus and imatinib mesylate who have progressive gastro intestinal stromal tumors (GIST) and are resistant to imatinib mesylate Progressive GIST Recruiting
Chromosome abnormalities in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) on imatinib. GIST patients on imatinib Chronic myeloid leukemia; GIST; Chromosome abnormality Recruiting
Safety and effectiveness of daily dosing with sunitinib or imatinib in patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumors GIST Recruiting
Gleevec administered preoperatively to reduce gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) GIST Recruiting
Imatinib mesylate with or without bevacizumab in treating patients With metastatic or unresectable gastrointestinal stromal tumor GIST Not yet recruiting
Sorafenib in treating patients with malignant gastrointestinal stromal tumor that progressed during or after previous treatment with imatinib mesylate and sunitinib malate GIST Recruiting
Phase II trial of locally advanced/metastatic soft tissue sarcoma or imatinib mesylate refractory advanced/metastatic malignant GIST Sarcoma; Malignant GIST Recruiting
Perifosine + sunitinib malate for patients with advanced cancers Renal cancer; GIST Recruiting
Post marketing surveillance study to observe safety And efficacy of sutent GIST; Carcinoma, renal cell Not yet recruiting
Doxorubicin and flavopiridol in treating patients with metastatic or recurrent sarcoma that cannot be removed by surgery GIST; Sarcoma Recruiting
FR901228 in treating patients with metastatic or unresectable soft tissue sarcoma GIST; Sarcoma Recruiting
A continuation study to provide sunitinib malate for patients leaving treatment on a previous sunitinib study. Breast neoplasms; Carcinoma, renal cell; Pancreatic neoplasms; GIST Recruiting
Rapamycin with grapefruit juice for advanced malignancies Tumours; Neoplasm metastasis Recruiting
UCN-01 and irinotecan in treating patients with metastatic or unresectable solid tumors Cancer Recruiting
Sorafenib and bevacizumab in treating patients with refractory, metastatic, or unresectable solid tumors Cancer Recruiting
Early intervention palliative care or a standard palliative care program in improving end-of-life care in patients with advanced lung, gastrointestinal, genitourinary, or breast cancer Cancer Recruiting
Erlotinib and cetuximab in treating patients with advanced gastrointestinal cancer, head and neck cancer, non-small cell lung cancer, or colorectal cancer Cancer Recruiting
Phase 1 study of OSI-930 in cancer patients Advanced solid tumours Recruiting
Imatinib mesylate in patients with various types of malignancies involving activated tyrosine kinase enzymes Hypereosinophilic syndrome; Systemic mastocytosis; Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia; Dermatofibrosarcoma Recruiting
A study of the combination of sirolimus and sutent in patients with advanced solid tumors that are non-curable with standard therapy Tumours Recruiting

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Mini topic review: Total Intravenous Anaesthesia (TIVA)
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - surgery, anaesthesia, perioperative and critical care
document.body:
111-1Mini topic review: Total Intravenous Anaesthesia (TIVA)By Dr David Mulvey, Consultant Anaesthetist, Royal Derby Hospital, Uttoxeter Road, Derby DE22 3NE

Cite this resource


Introduction

Developments made over the last twenty five years have allowed total intravenous anaesthesia (TIVA) to become an everyday technique. These include the introduction of propofol and remifentanil into clinical practice, sophisticated mathematical modelling of plasma and brain drug concentrations, and infusion devices programmed with pharmacokinetic profiles.


Drugs used for TIVA

Theoretically any combination of intravenous hypnotic and opioid agents can be used in a synergistic/additive manner to achieve general anaesthesia. In practice, agents with fast onset and offset times prove most useful in maintaining a balance between adequacy of anaesthesia/analgesia and rapid recovery.1 The decrement time of a drug’s plasma concentration tends to increase with the duration of continuous administration (“context sensitive half-time - CSHT”).2 Of the hypnotic agents with short CSHT, propofol has the least unwanted side effects making it the preferred choice.1 Remifentanil shows little CSHT in contrast to opioids such as alfentanil and fentanyl and is preferred in a TIVA technique.3 Some clinicians supplement intravenous infusions with inhaled nitrous oxide in order to reduce required plasma/brain concentrations and enhance awakening times, although strictly speaking this is not TIVA.3,4


Propofol-related infusion syndrome (PRIS)

This is defined as metabolic acidosis plus cardiac dysfunction and =1 of rhabdomyolysis, hypertriglyceridemia or renal failure occurring after the start of propofol therapy.5 The majority of reports concern paediatric and adult patients requiring support in an intensive care environment. The aetiology is unclear, but in a recent prospective study of 1017 adult patients an incidence of 1.1% was observed.6 Propofol is not recommended for sedation on paediatric ICU but is currently considered safe for TIVA in this age group.7 The same authors pointed out that the syndrome is not confined to the prolonged use of propofol.7 Reports of perioperative lactic acidosis and/or hyperkalaemia in patients receiving propofol infusions as part of the anaesthetic technique have been published. It has been recommended that PRIS should be remembered as a possible complication of using propofol for anaesthesia.7


Hyperalgesia with Remifentanil

Hyperalgesia after remifentanil infusion has been proposed8,9, and refuted10,11,12 but represents a potential disadvantage to using this agent for TIVA.13 The importance of administering morphine at least 40 minutes in advance of discontinuing remifentanil infusion has been demonstrated14, as well as the need for doses greater than 0.15 mg/kg.15


Target controlled infusion (TCI)

Administration of hypnotic/opioid infusions can be performed manually using established dosing regimens to achieve clinically appropriate plasma drug concentrations. It is far easier for the anaesthetist to use a target controlled infusion (TCI) device which has pharmacokinetic data programmed into a microprocessor24. Additionally the use of TCI devices allows better control of anaesthesia, fewer haemodynamic side effects and a more predictable recovery than conventional infusions.16 However a systematic review found insufficient evidence to make firm recommendations about the advantage of target controlled infusions in clinical practice.17


Pharmacokinetic models

Most debate about pharmacokinetic models has centred on propofol infusions. The earliest TCI devices incorporated the “Diprifusor” module and accepted only syringes pre-filled with propofol by AstraZeneca. This module uses the pharmacokinetic data of Marsh and colleagues to achieve a target plasma concentration, adjusting the central volume of distribution according to weight. It is suggested that this model may lead to a relative overdosing of an elderly subject and underdosing of the young fit patient18, although it has proved robust in clinical practice.19 Subsequent investigators have broadened the models for propofol by encompassing a wider range of patient variables and currently ten data sets are available from an expert source20 (www.eurosiva.org). Whilst it is ideal to choose a model appropriate to the age and sex of the patients to be treated21, commercially available TCI devices offer a limited choice at present, namely the “Marsh” and “Schnider” adult models, and the “Kataria” and “Paedfusor” paediatric data sets. Current infusion devices accept syringes filled with generic propofol (“open TCI”) offering a potential for cost saving. In addition, these “open” devices allow the use of a wider range of hypnotic/opioid agents and their relevant pharmacokinetic models to achieve a TCI. Another important difference is the ability to target the “effect site” (i.e. the brain) concentration of the drug, thereby limiting the delay between plasma and brain equilibration and reducing adverse cardiovascular effects in the elderly. This choice is available for both the “Marsh” and “Schnider” models for propofol in commercial devices. At present there is no evidence to suggest that the choice of model or site of targeting has advantage in clinical practice.22 However it is recommend that the Marsh model is used in plasma target mode, and the Schnider model in effect site mode.22 Clinicians must exercise particular care when changing from models that target plasma to effect site concentration or vice versa. Varying masses of propofol are delivered into the patient’s circulation with the different models and this may lead to unexpected clinical consequences.23 In common with inhalational anaesthesia, adjustments in TIVA dosing must be made on the basis of clinical response.24 The “Minto” model for remifentanil TCI is used most widely in clinical practice, both in plasma and effect site target modes. In common with propofol there is no evidence to show a benefit of effect-site targeting for remifentanil and the possibility of exaggerated haemodynamic effects which may be disadvantageous.25


Morbidly obese patients

Anomalies arise with “Schnider” model for propofol and “Minto” model for remifentanil which use Lean Body Mass (LBM) as a limiting parameter on the infusion rate required with increasing total body weight. The calculation of LBM is by the “James” equation26 which gives a declining value for LBM when BMI exceeds 42 kg m-2 in males and 35 kg m-2 in females.27 This allows the pharmacokinetic model to deliver an exponential rise in infusion rate to maintain the target concentration with the potential for marked haemodynamic side effects. The TCI device manufacturers have prevented pump software from calculating an absurdly low LBM thereby limiting the use of the devices in patients with BMIs exceeding the critical values. It has been noted that the currently available pharmacokinetic models have not been validated for use in the morbidly obese.24. Some success has been obtained by empirical corrections of body mass28,29, but caution is urged if TIVA is given to this group of patients.24


Awareness

It is often stated that TIVA is associated with an increased risk of awareness and that neuromuscular blocking agents should be avoided with this method of anaesthesia as a result. Relatively few patients are given TIVA compared to balanced inhalational anesthesia (BIA) which makes comparison difficult.30 A further analytical complexity is the absence of standardisation of intravenous drug and dosing regimen used in published studies, and of a recognised end-point akin to minimal alveolar concentration for BIA. The susceptibility of TIVA to technical failures that result in awareness has been highlighted.31 In large prospective trial of propofol/alfentanil TIVA the incidence of awareness was similar to that with BIA, although most TIVA cases were due to technical problems in delivery.30 In a prospective observational study of 4001 patients, the incidence of awareness in patients receiving ‘TIVA-propofol’ was 1% versus 0.59% in the BIA group – however no details of anaesthetic technique or additional drugs given to the TIVA-propofol group are available to allow detailed evaluation of these data.32 A small number of case reports of awareness in patients receiving TIVA administered as propofol/remifentanil TCI have been published but a large prospective trial is required to determine if extra risk truly exists. In studies using the isolated forearm technique and bispectral index endpoints for adequate anaesthesia, TIVA and BIA provided similar numbers of patients able to respond to command with no difference in awareness.33,34 Currently there is no reason to believe that TIVA increases the risk of awareness, and good reasons to minimise the use of neuromuscular blocking agents in all modes of anaesthesia.35,36


Nausea and Vomiting

In an early systematic review, propofol maintenance anaesthesia and omitting nitrous oxide in general anaesthesia had approximately the same effect on early and late post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and the data were considered insufficient to recommend TIVA as the preferred method.37 Recent expert opinion emphasises the value of TIVA in a multimodal approach to patients at high risk for PONV.38


Daycase surgery

The use of TIVA for ambulatory surgery seems to be increasing, with rapid, clear-headed emergence and low incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting cited as advantages of the technique, in combination with simplicity of TCI administration, increased experience and declining costs with the propofol and remifentanil combination.3,39 This contrasts with a much earlier review which did not find TIVA to be cost-effective in this setting.40


Anaesthesia for lung isolation

In a systematic review, there was no evidence of important differences in outcomes for anaesthesia maintained by intravenous versus inhalational anaesthesia during one-lung ventilation.41 Nevertheless, TIVA is preferable for certain thoracic procedures incompatible with effective delivery of inhalational anaesthetics.42


Neurosurgical procedures

TIVA appears to confer advantage over traditional anaesthetic techniques in patients with raised intracranial pressure43 and those requiring intraoperative nuerophysiological monitoring44 but is the subject of ongoing studies.


Conclusion

TIVA is used in an ever widening range of clinical applications with quality of recovery considered the major advantage offered by the technique. More formal prospective clinical trials are required to determine the role of TIVA in modern anaesthetic practice.


References

2. Hughes MA, Glass PSA, Jacobs JR. Context-sensitive half-time in multicompartment pharmacokinetic models for intravenous anesthetic drugs. Anesthesiology 1992; 76:334-41. [Link to abstract]

3. Hitchcock M. Total Intravenous Anaesthesia (TIVA). Chapter 7, pp 65-77. in Practical Analgesia and Anesthesia for Day Case Surgery. Millar JM, Rudkin GE, Hitchcock M. 1997, BIOS Scientific Publishers Ltd.

4. Handa-Tsutsui F, Kodaka M. Effect of nitrous oxide on propofol requirement during target-controlled infusion for oocyte retrieval. Int J Obstet Anesth. 2007; 16(1):13-16. [Link to abstract]

5. Fudickar A, Bein B, Tonner P. Propofol infusion syndrome in anaesthesia and intensive care medicine. Curr Opin Anesthesiol. 2006; 19(4):404-10. [Link to abstract]

6. Roberts RJ, Barletta JF, Fong JJ et al. Incidence of propofol-related infusion syndrome in critically ill adults: a prospective, multicenter study. Crit Care 2009; 13(5): R169. Epub 2009 Oct 29. [Link to full text]

7. Fudickar A, Bein B. Propofol infusion syndrome: update of clinical manifestation and pathophysiology. Minerva Anestesiol. 2009; 75(5): 339-44. [Link to abstract]

8. Hood DD, Curry R, Eisenach JC. Intravenous remifentanil produces withdrawal hyperalgesia in volunteers with capsaicin-induced hyperalgesia. Anesth Analg. 2003; 97(3):810-5. [Link to abstract]

9. Crawford MW, Hickey C, Zaarour C et al. Development of acute opioid tolerance during infusion of remifentanil for pediatric scoliosis surgery. Anesth Analg. 2006; 102(6):1662-7. [Link to abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Minimally invasive arthroplasty in the management of hip arthritic disease: systematic review and economic evaluation
document.publisher: Canadian Agency for Drugs and Technologies in Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,ARTHROPLASTY,SURGERY,SURGERY,LIMBS,PELVIS & HIP,JOINT DISEASE,OSTEOARTHRITIS,HIP REPLACEMENT,HIP AND PELVIS,HIP OSTEOARTHRITIS]]>
document.description: This health technology assessment reviews the clinical and financial impact of adopting minimally invasive total hip replacement (MI THR) techniques.
document.body:
Aims: This health technology assessment reviews the clinical and financial impact of adopting minimally invasive total hip replacement (MI THR) techniques.


Methods; The report outlines the search and selection strategies for literature on MI THR including databases searched, selection criteria, quality assessment and data analysis.


Results: The report outlines the results of the literature searches for the clinical review and economic analysis.


Conclusions: The report states the following conclusions:

  • "Despite the number of studies identified, there was little evidence of any longer-term differences between MI THR and standard THR. This is mainly because of the lack of data available".
  • "Overall, it seems likely that the MI approach offers some peri-operative advantages regarding blood loss and operative time, although these may be of limited clinical significance. The MI approach may also offer a shorter recovery period, as identified by the shorter length of hospital stay and time to return to usual activities".
  • "The MI approach may also offer a shorter recovery period, as identified by the shorter length of hospital stay and time to return to usual activities".

Please note that conclusions on cost effectiveness are applicable for the Canadian healthcare setting.


Citation: Coyle D, Coyle K, Vale L, de Verteuil R, Imamura M, Glazener C, Zhu S. Minimally invasive arthroplasty in the management of hip arthritic disease: systematic review and economic evaluation [technology report number 102]. Ottawa: Canadian Agency for Drugs and Technologies in Health; 2008. Available from: http://cadth.ca/media/pdf/336_Invasive-Arthroplasty-Man-Hip-Arthritic-Disease_tr_e.pdf


Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.title: Multimedia Manual of Cardiothoracic Surgery
document.body:
The Multimedia Manual of Cardiothoracic Surgery is a growing online resource provided by the European Association of Cardio-Thoracic Surgery (EACTS).
It includes how-to descriptions for cardiovascular and thoracic surgery along with videos and illustrations which can be searched for or browsed by condition. Peer-reviewed comments about new alternative techniques are also available.
It is aimed at cardiothoracic trainees but is also useful for specialists seeking technical information.
Please note that RealPlayer software is required to view the videos.

Access: freely available

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: National Audit of Major Complications of Central Neuraxial Block in the United Kingdom - 3rd National Audit Project (NAP3)
document.body:
Aims: The third national audit project aimed to determine both the prevalence and incidence in the UK of serious complications of central neuraxial blockade.

Results: Please refer to the full report for details of results.

Conclusions:The largest ever prospective study into the major complications of epidurals and spinal anaesthetics concludes that previous studies have over-estimated the risks of severe complications of these procedures. The study concludes that the estimated risk of permanent harm following a spinal anaesthetic or epidural is lower than 1 in 20,000 and in many circumstances the estimated risk is considerably lower. 

Publication history: Published on 12th January 2009 in the British Journal of Anaesthesia (Advance Access / Special Article) 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: National Audit of Theatre Equipment 2010
document.publisher: Association of Laparoscopic Surgeons of Great Britain and Ireland (ALSGBI)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HEALTH MANAGEMENT,SERVICE SECTORS,QUALITY AND MONITORING,PATIENT SAFETY,RISK MANAGEMENT,ACUTE SERVICES,SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN]]>
document.body:
The National Audit of Theatre Equipment 2010 surveyed 474 hospitals across Great Britain and Northern Ireland and graded respondents either “Bronze”, “Silver” or “Gold”. The audit asked hospitals to outline the types of laparoscopic procedures regularly performed, the age, standard and type of equipment and how their equipment was powered and maintained. It found that uptake of new equipment was varied:

  • 61% of hospitals were operating with “Silver” standard equipment
  • Nearly 25% of hospitals did not have a maintenance contract to replace broken equipment
  • 19% of hospitals were using Sharp Metal Trocars – old, reusable equipment
  • Around 3% of hospitals were not using modern energy sources for their equipment e.g. Ultrasound

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.title: National Oesophago-Gastric Cancer Audit 2008
document.publisher: NHS Information Centre for Health and Social Care
document.body:
The National Oesophago-Gastric Cancer Audit has been commissioned by the Healthcare Commission to examine the quality of care given to patients with oesophago-gastric (OG) cancer, and thereby help services to improve. The Audit evaluates the process of care and the outcomes of treatment for all OG cancer patients, both curative and palliative.

The national results for this audit will be published in three annual reports. This is the first report, the second report was published in September 2009 and the third will be published in September 2010.  


Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.title: National prospective tonsillectomy audit - final report
document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England
document.body:
In the Spring of 2003, the ENT community in England and Northern Ireland was invited to participate in a national audit of tonsillectomies. The Audit provided a unique opportunity to review our practice and the response has been impressive.
It was only with the support of all professionals and hospitals involved that the National Prospective Tonsillectomy Audit could investigate the occurrence of postoperative haemorrhage and other complications in more than 40,000
tonsillectomies. This investigation into the safety of tonsillectomy is unique because of its data quality, statistical power, and generalisability.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: National total hip replacement outcome study - final report to the Department of Health
document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,PROSTHETICS,ARTHROPLASTY,SURGERY,SURGERY,LIMBS,PELVIS & HIP,HIP REPLACEMENT,HIP AND PELVIS]]>
document.description: Report from The Royal College of Surgeons of England and the British Orthopaedic Association on an observational outcome study of total hip replacement surgery.
document.body:
A joint report from The Royal College of Surgeons of England and the British Orthopaedic Association. The report documents the results of an observational outcome study of primary total hip replacement surgery. The study looked at current surgical practice, types of prostheses used and outcomes.

Contents-

Aims and objectives: there were four main aims for this study-

  • To describe the clinical practice in the management of total hip replacement (THR) surgery

  • To investigate the incidence of complications in the twelve month period following THR surgery

  • To measure the health status of patients in the twelve months following THR surgery

  • To establish a group of patients that will be followed up at five and ten years to study medium- and long-term outcomes

Methods: the report describes the study design involving surgeon and patient questionnaires and case notes.

Results: see report for a full description of the findings.

Discussion: a summary of findings, discussion of the results and the limitations of the study.

Future research: opportunities for further analyses of the data.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Natural Orifice Translumenal Endoscopic Surgery (NOTES): A systematic review
document.publisher: Australian Safety and Efficacy Register of New Interventional Procedures -Surgical (ASERNIP-S)
document.body:
Authors' objectives: To assess the safety and efficacy of various intra-abdominal Natural Orifice Translumenal Endoscopic Surgery (NOTES) procedures which do not cut the dermis, in comparison with traditional intra-abdominal surgery which cuts the dermis, through a systematic review of the literature. 

Methods: Please refer to the original documents for the methods used. 

Results: Please refer to the original document for the results obtained.  

Authors' conclusions: The available evidence was assessed as being poor. At this point in time, NOTES for intra-abdominal surgery is less safe than laparoscopic and laparotomic alternatives. NOTES for intra-abdominal surgery is currently less efficacious than laparoscopic and laparotomic alternatives. NOTES is still in early stages of development and more robust technologies will be needed to achieve reliable closure and overcome technical challenges. Well-managed human studies need to be conducted to determine the safety and efficacy of NOTES in a clinical setting. This may be approached by performing hybrid NOTES/laparoscopic procedures, which may help to evaluate the safety of NOTES in a human model, before moving into larger trials. NOTES procedures and studies should be performed under strict guidelines.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.title: Natural rubber latex allergy: considerations for anesthesiologists
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,THEATRE MANAGEMENT,PATIENT SAFETY,INTRAOPERATIVE,STAFF SAFETY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,PREOPERATIVE PREPARATIONS,LATEX ALLERGY,MONITORING & SAFETY,OPTIMISING PATIENT HEALTH,ALLERGIES & DRUG REACTIONS,ALLERGIES]]>
document.description: Guidance aimed at the anaesthetist on latex allergy in both the patient and healthcare professional
document.body:
This document has been prepared by the Task Force on Latex Sensitivity of the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA). Latex allergy is an increasing problem, and this document provides a useful source of guidance for the anaesthetist confronted by a patient with latex allergy including:
  • Identification of high-risk patient groups
  • Prevention of reactions in previously sensitized individuals
  • Operating room management of the patient with latex allergy
  • Treatment of an allergic reaction to latex
  • Management of the health care worker with latex allergy

Please note: that this document has not been reviewed or approved as a practice parameter or policy statement by the ASA House of Delegates. The recommendations are designed to encourage quality care and safety for patients and health care workers in the workplace but must be used with the judgment of the responsible anaesthesiologist.

Publication history information: published in 2005

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.body:
The National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD) aims to review medical clinical practice and to make recommendations to improve the quality of the delivery of care. NCEPOD undertakes confidential surveys covering many different aspects of medical care and makes recommendations for clinicians and management to implement. In 2007 NCEPOD reviewed all of the recommendations that have been made in its reports and produced a list of those that remain relevant.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Negative pressure wound therapy
document.publisher: Medical Advisory Secretariat (MAS), Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-term Care
document.description: This Health Technology Assessment reviews the evidence on the clinical and cost effectiveness of negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) in wound healing compared to standard care.
document.body:
Aims: This Health Technology Assessment reviews the evidence on the clinical and cost effectiveness of negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) in wound healing compared to standard care. NPTW may also be referred to as "negative topical pressure, subatmospheric pressure therapy, vacuum sealing, vacuum pack therapy, and sealing aspirative therapy".


Methods: The report outlines the search strategy for literature on negative pressure wound therapy including databases searched, keywords and criteria for inclusion.


Results: The results provide a summary of the existing health technology assessments and a summary of the randomised controlled trials that met the inclusion criteria for this review.


Conclusions: The summary of findings stated "that the health technology assessments consistently reported that NPWT may be useful for healing various types of wounds, but that its effectiveness could not be empirically quantified because the studies were poorly done, the patient populations and outcome measures could not be compared, and the sample sizes were small". The study concluded that "Based on the evidence to date, the clinical effectiveness of NPWT to heal wounds is unclear". Please note that conclusions on cost effectiveness are applicable in the Canadian healthcare setting.


Citation: Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee. Negative pressure wound therapy: update. Ontario; Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care; 2006. Available from: http://www.health.gov.on.ca/english/providers/program/ohtac/tech/reviews/pdf/rev_npwt_070106.pdf


Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Devices
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.body:
Aims: To review and compare the wound healing outcomes of different negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) devices. To answer the four key questions:

"1. Does any single NPWT system have a significant therapeutic distinction in terms of wound healing outcomes compared to any other NPWT system for the treatment of acute or chronic wounds?
2. Does any component of a NPWT system have a significant therapeutic distinction in terms of wound healing outcomes compared to any other similar component of a NPWT system for the treatment of acute or chronic wounds?
3. What are the reported occurrences of pain, bleeding, infection, other complications, and mortality for NPWT systems?
4. Do patients being treated with one NPWT system have a significant therapeutic distinction in terms of less pain, bleeding, infection, other complications, or mortality than other NPWT systems?"

Methods: The review outlines the literature search strategy, inclusion and exclusion criteria and critical appraisal.

Results and conclusions: These sections highlight the results of studies that address the key questions of the review and a discussion of the evidence.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.title: Never Events Annual Report 2009/10
document.body:
The National Patient Safety Agency has developed the Never Events Framework to guide PCT commissioners in implementing the Never Events policy. Never Events are described as 'serious, largely preventable patient safety incidents that should not occur if the available preventative measures have been implemented'.

This document provides an overview of the Never Events reported to the NPSA by NHS organisations in England from 1 April 2009 to 31 March 2010. It describes how the objectives of the Never Event policy have been met, the number of Never Events reported to the NPSA, and the learning at national level. It highlights how commissioners and providers are using the policy to promote patient safety.

]]>

document.title: NHS locum doctor spend rises
document.publisher: Royal College of Surgeons of England
document.body:
The results of a survey of 165 NHS Trusts reveal that spending on hiring of locum or temporary doctors has almost doubled since 2007. The report concludes that this is due to gaps in rotas caused by the European Working Time Regulation (EWTR).

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: NICEM consensus on neurological monitoring in acute neurological disease
document.publisher: European Society of Intensive Care Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM,PROCEDURES AND INTERVENTIONS,DRUGS AND THERAPEUTICS,ORGAN SUPPORT,NEUROLOGICAL,CLINICAL TOPICS,NEUROLOGICAL,CRITICAL CARE]]>
document.body:
Abstract: This manuscript summarises the consensus on neuromonitoring in neuro-intensive care promoted and organised by the Neuro-Intensive Care and Emergency Medicine (NICEM) Section of the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine (ESICM). It is expected that continuous monitoring using multi-modal techniques will help to overcome the limitations of each individual method and will provide a better diagnosis. More specific treatment can then be applied; however, it remains to be determined which combination of parameters is optimal. The questions discussed and addressed in this manuscript are:
  1. Who should have ICP monitoring and for how long?
  2. What ICP technologies are available and what are their relative advantages/disadvantages?
  3. Should CPP monitoring and autoregulation testing be used?
  4. When should brain tissue oxygen tension (PbrO2) be monitored?
  5. Should structurally normal or abnormal tissue be monitored with PbrO2?
  6. Shouldmicrodialysis be considered in complex cases?
It is hoped that this document will prove useful to clinicians working in NICU and also to those developing specialist NICU services within their hospital practice. 

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.body:
The NIOSH pocket guide (NPG) is maintained by the US Government agency, the National Institute for Occupational Safety & Health.
It is a searchable online repository holding key information including physical chemical properties, protection advice and exposure routes, for a wide range of chemicals used industrially.
It is also available to download as standalone database.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: NPSA incident reporting form
document.description: This form has been developed by the National Patient Safety Agency to help healthcare staff report patient safety incidents.
document.body:
This form has been developed by the National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) to help healthcare staff report patient safety incidents. These are any unintended or unexpected incidents which could have or did lead to harm for one or more patients receiving NHS-funded health care. It should be used as soon as possible after the incident has happened.

To ensure staff feel comfortable reporting under all circumstances, the NPSA only retains anonymous information. This means the form should not be used for incidents that need specific and immediate investigation.

If a medical device was involved in the incident it should instead be reported directly to the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA).

Please note: terms and conditions must be accepted to access the form

 

]]>

document.title: NPSA learning from reporting - chest drains
document.description: This learning from reporting section, taken from Quarterly Data Summary Issue 13, focuses on the problems surrounding the insertion of chest drains.
document.body:
The National Reporting and Learning Service (NRLS) published a Rapid Response Report (RRR) on the risks surrounding the insertion of chest drains in May 2008, but a review of this RRR in June 2009 showed that whilst it had raised awareness amongst clinicians, just over a third of eligible trusts had still not completed the actions outlined.

This learning from reporting section, taken from Quarterly Data Summary Issue 13, focuses on the problems surrounding the insertion of chest drains.

document.title: NPSA Signal - wrong site nerve block
document.body:
This Signal is about the risk of administering a nerve block to the wrong site perioperatively. Issues identified included distraction of the anaesthetist, lack of mark specific to the block, lack of anaesthetic time-out and discrepancy between operating list and mark or consent form. Some reports stated the site was marked but either covered up by drapes or obscured when the patient was positioned. This is particularly likely if the surgical site mark is distant from the nerve block site. The Surgical Safety Checklist Alert (2009) contains the supporting information, “The anaesthetist should only proceed with a regional block when he/she has confirmed that the site for surgery has been marked.” Further guidance on the marking of the site is in the appendix.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: NSAID-analgesia, pain control and morbidity in cardiothoracic surgery
document.body:
Bottom –line conclusion:
In patients less than 70 years of age undergoing cardiothoracic surgery, the adjunctive use of NSAIDs with narcotic analgesia reduces 24 hour VAS (visual analogue scale) pain score and narcotic requirements.

Method:
A literature search was undertaken up to September 2005 to identify all randomised trials in cardiothoracic patients receiving NSAIDs plus narcotics versus narcotics without NSAIDs. Databases searched were MEDLINE, Cochrane Collection, EMBASE, Current Contents, DARE, NEED, and INAHTA with follow up of reference lists and personal contact with experts. The primary outcome was VAS pain score, and secondary outcomes included 24 hour cumulative morphine-equivalents, rescue medications required, mortality, myocardial infarction, atrial fibrillation, stroke, renal failure, hospital readmissions, and in-hospital costs.
Inclusion and exclusion criteria were stated and studies were checked by two independent assessors for quality using the A. R. Jahad quality scoring system.

Results:
Twenty randomized trials involving 1,065 patients were included. A significant reduction in 24 hour VAS pain score was found in patients receiving NSAIDs [weighted mean difference (WMD) –0.91 points, 95% confidence interval (CI) –1.48 to –0.34 points]. In addition, patients required significantly less morphine-equivalents in the first 24 hr (WMD –7.67 mg, 95% CI –8.97 to –6.38 mg). No significant difference was found with respect to mortality [odds ratio (OR) 0.19, 95% CI 0.01 to 4.22], myocardial infarction (OR 0.71, 95% CI 0.09 to 5.71), renal dysfunction (OR 0.95, 95% CI 0.37 to 2.46), or gastrointestinal bleeding (OR 0.96, 95% CI 0.13 to 7.09). See full text for detail.

Citation: Bainbridge B, Cheng DC, Martin JE & Novick R. NSAID-analgesia, pain control and morbidity in cardiothoracic surgery. Canadian Journal of Anesthesia 2006; 53 (1): 46-59

Publication history information: Published in January 2006.

Access: freely available

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: On the face of it: a review of the organisational structures surrounding the practice of cosmetic surgery
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.body:
This report examines organisational factors in the delivery of cosmetic surgery. It recommends closer monitoring of cosmetic surgery providers after finding fundamental weaknesses in the delivery of cosmetic surgery.

The key findings from this report were:

  • around half of cosmetic surgery providers were not fully equipped to carry out cosmetic surgery and many did not have a policy to readmit patients who experience postoperative complications
  • there were deficencies in obtaining consent with one third not carrying out a two-stage consent process and only 35% of sites carrying out routine psychological assessments of patients
  • 30% of independent hospitals with inpatient beds did not have an anaesthetic consultant rota
  • many sites offered procedures which were rarely performed 

 

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>

document.title: OncoSurge Decision Model
document.description: Decision model for patients with metastatic colorectal cancer
document.body:
The OncoSurge Decision Model is a risk prediction tool designed to evaluate the appropriateness of performing liver resection and/or other local destructive therapies for metastatic colorectal cancer at the level of the individual patient.
The model is based on evidence from the literature and the collective judgement of a multi-disciplinary multinational expert panel of healthcare professionals.

Topic Advisor's comment: this model may be particularly helpful for those hospitals that do not have regular communication with a local liver unit.

Please note:
1. Local provision and expertise in the UK may vary and these guidelines therefore serve as a guide rather than an absolute entity.
2. It is not clear from the website how frequently the literature is updated so model may not represent the most current evidence to date.

Access:  Available to the general public.

 

]]>
