document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of cochlear implants for severe to profound deafness in children and adults: a systematic review and economic model
document.body:
Objectives: To investigate whether it is clinically effective and cost-effective to provide (i) a unilateral cochlear implant for severely to profoundly deaf people (using or not using hearing aids), and (ii) a bilateral cochlear implant for severely to profoundly deaf people with a single cochlear implant (unilateral or unilateral plus hearing aid).

Data sources: Main electronic databases [MEDLINE; EMBASE; Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews; CENTRAL; NHS EED; DARE; HTA (NHS-CRD); EconLit; National Research Register; and ClinicalTrials. gov] searched in October 2006, updated July 2007.

Review methods: A systematic review of the literature was undertaken according to standard methods. A statetransition (Markov) model of the main care pathways deaf people might follow and the main complications and device failures was developed.

Results: The clinical effectiveness review included 33 papers, of which only two were RCTs. They used 62 different outcome measures and overall were of moderate to poor quality. All studies in children comparing one cochlear implant with non-technological support or an acoustic hearing aid reported gains on all outcome measures, some demonstrating greater gain from earlier implantation. The strongest evidence for an advantage from bilateral over unilateral implantation was for understanding speech in noisy conditions (mean improvement 13.2%, p < 0.0001); those receiving their second implant earlier made greater gains. Comparison of bilateral with unilateral cochlear implants plus an acoustic hearing aid was compromised by small sample sizes and poor reporting, but benefits were seen with bilateral implants. Cochlear implants improved children’s quality of life, and those who were implanted before attending school were more likely to do well academically and attend mainstream education than those implanted later. In adults, there was a greater benefit from cochlear implants than from nontechnological support in terms of speech perception. Increased age at implantation may reduce effectiveness and there is a negative correlation between duration of deafness and effectiveness. Speech perception measures all showed benefits for cochlear implants over acoustic hearing aids [e.g. mean increase in score of 37 points in noisy conditions (p < 0.001) with BKB sentences]; however, prelingually deafened adults benefited less than those postlingually deafened (mean change scores 20% versus 62%). For unilateral versus bilateral implantation, benefits in speech perception were significant in noisy conditions on all measures [e.g. 76% for HINT sentences (p < 0.0001)]. Quality of life measured with generic and disease-specific instruments or by interview mostly showed significant gains or positive trends from using cochlear implants. The Markov model base-case analysis estimated that, for prelingually profoundly deaf children, the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) for unilateral implantation compared with no implantation was £13,413 per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY). Assuming the utility gain for bilateral implantation is the same for adults and children, the ICERs for simultaneous and sequential bilateral implantation versus unilateral implantation were £40,410 and £54,098 per QALY respectively. For postlingually sensorineurally profoundly deaf adults, the corresponding ICERs were £14,163, £49,559 and £60,301 per QALY respectively. Probabilistic threshold analyses suggest that unilateral implants are highly likely to be cost-effective for adults and children at willingness to pay thresholds of £20,000 or £30,000 per QALY.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: The effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of minimal access surgery amongst people with gastro-oesophageal reflux disease – a UK collaborative study. The REFLUX trial
document.body:
Objectives: To evaluate the clinical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and safety of a policy of relatively early laparoscopic surgery compared with continued medical management amongst people with gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) judged suitable for both policies.

Design: Relative clinical effectiveness was assessed by a randomised trial (with parallel non-randomised preference groups) comparing a laparoscopic surgery-based policy with a continued medical management policy. The economic evaluation compared the cost-effectiveness of the two management policies in order to identify the most efficient provision of future care and describe the resource impact that various policies for fundoplication would have on the NHS.

Setting: A total of 21 hospitals throughout the UK with a local partnership between surgeon(s) and gastroenterologist(s) who shared the secondary care of patients with GORD.

Participants: The 810 participants, who were identified retrospectively or prospectively via their participating clinicians, had both documented evidence of GORD (endoscopy and/or manometry/24-hour pH monitoring) and symptoms for longer than 12 months. In addition, the recruiting clinician(s) was clinically uncertain about which management policy was best.

Intervention: Of the 810 eligible patients who consented to participate, 357 were recruited to the randomised arm of the trial (178 allocated to surgical management, 179 allocated to continued, but optimised, medical management) and 453 recruited to the parallel non-randomised preference arm (261 chose surgical management, 192 chose to continue with best medical management). The type of fundoplication was left to the discretion of the surgeon.

Main outcome measures: Participants completed a baseline REFLUX questionnaire, developed specifically for this study, containing a disease-specific outcome measure, the Short Form with 36 Items (SF-36), the EuroQol-5 Dimensions (EQ-5D) and the Beliefs about Medicines and Surgery questionnaires (BMQ/BSQ). Postal questionnaires were completed at participant-specific time intervals after joining the trial (equivalent to approximately 3 and 12 months after surgery). Intraoperative data were recorded by the surgeons and all other in-hospital data were collected by the research nurse. At the end of the study period, participants completed a discrete choice experiment questionnaire.

Results: The randomised groups were well balanced at entry. Participants had been taking GORD medication for a median of 32 months; the mean age of participants was 46 years and 66% were men. Of 178 randomised to surgery, 111 (62%) actually had fundoplication. There was a mixture of clinical and personal reasons why some patients did not have surgery, sometimes related to long waiting times. A total or partial wrap procedure was performed depending on surgeon preference. Complications were uncommon and there were no deaths associated with surgery. By the equivalent of 12 months after surgery, 38% in the randomised surgical group (14% amongst those who had surgery) were taking reflux medication compared with 90% in the randomised medical group. There were substantial differences (one-third to one-half standard deviation) favouring the randomised surgical group across the health status measures, the size depending on assumptions about the proportion that actually had fundoplication. These differences were the same or somewhat smaller than differences observed at 3 months. The lower the REFLUX score, the worse the symptoms at trial entry and the larger the benefit observed after surgery. The preference surgical group had the lowest REFLUX scores at baseline. These scores improved substantially after surgery, and by 12 months they were better than those in the preference medical group. The BMQ/BSQ and discrete choice experiment did distinguish the preference groups from each other and from the randomised groups. The latter indicated that the risk of serious complications was the most important single attribute of a treatment option. A within-trial cost-effectiveness analysis suggested that the surgery policy was more costly (mean £2049) but also more effective [+0.088 quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs)]. The estimated incremental cost per QALY was £19,000–£23,000, with a probability between 46% (when 62% received surgery) and 19% (when all received surgery) of cost-effectiveness at a threshold of £20,000 per QALY. Modelling plausible longer-term scenarios (such as lifetime benefit after surgery) indicated a greater likelihood (74%) of cost-effectiveness at a threshold of £20,000, but applying a range of alternative scenarios indicated wide uncertainty. The expected value of perfect information was greatest for longer-term quality of life and proportions of surgical patients requiring medication.

Conclusions: Amongst patients requiring long-term medication to control symptoms of GORD, surgical management significantly increases general and reflux-specific health-related quality of life measures, at least up to 12 months after surgery. Complications of surgery were rare. A surgical policy is, however, more costly than continued medical management. At a threshold of £20,000 per QALY it may well be cost-effective, especially when putative longer-term benefits are taken into account, but this is uncertain. The more troublesome the symptoms, the greater the potential benefit from surgery. Uncertainty about cost-effectiveness would be greatly reduced by more reliable information about relative longer-term costs and benefits of surgical and medical policies. This could be through extended follow-up of the REFLUX trial cohorts or of other cohorts of fundoplication patients.  

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.title: The gag reflex is a poor discriminator for the need for intubation
document.body:
Best Evidence Topics or BETs were developed in the Emergency Department of Manchester Royal Infirmary, UK, to provide rapid evidence-based answers to real-life clinical questions, using a systematic approach to reviewing the literature.

They are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

The site includes original articles, guest publications and a forum together with main techniques section.
Techniques are arranged anatomically under basic, intermediate, ultrasound-guided, advanced and equipment subsections. Each technique has well annotated diagrams to demonstrate patient positioning and landmarks and as well as information on anatomy, choice of anaesthetic, perioperative management and complications.
Please note: the web site material has not been peer reviewed

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Third report of the mandatory surveillance of surgical site infection in orthopaedic surgery: April 2004 to March 2007
document.description: This report presents data collected during the first three years of the mandatory surveillance of surgical site infections in orthopaedic surgery.
document.body:
All NHS Trusts where orthopaedic procedures are performed are now required to undertake a minimum of three months surveillance of surgical site infections in at least one of the following: hip replacement, knee replacement, hip hemiarthroplasty or open reduction of long bone fracture. This report presents data collected during the first three years of the mandatory surveillance.

Contents:

  • The key points highlighted from the surveillance results
  • Introduction to the surveillance methods and analyses
  • Rates of surgical site infection in orthopaedic surgery
  • Characteristics of surgical site infections (SSI)
  • Variation of rates of SSI between trusts
  • Conclusions

Publication history: For information on previous reports please go to the Health Protection Agency website.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Total knee replacement
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.description: Systematic review on outcomes including baseline and follow-up symptom scale scores, revision rates and perioperative complications occurring within six months of surgery.
document.body:
Bottom–line conclusion:
In general, the outcomes research on total knee arthroplasty (TKA) emphasises before and after studies that are variations on case series of various techniques and prostheses with little attention to the role of other factors or to attrition.
Although demographic and clinical factors are recorded, they are rarely used in the analysis. A consistent body of evidence suggests substantial improvement in function associated with TKA and total knee arthroplasty revision (TKAR). The follow-up periods vary but the mean is greater than five years. More informed decision making about indicators for TKAs will require stronger research designs. These need to be planned as prospective studies with multivariate analysis. Such analyses will require larger samples and more consistent and comprehensive data collection than was found in this review.

Method: 
A literature search was performed on PubMed from 1990 to April 2003. Non-English language, animal and unicompartmental (unicondylar) knee replacement studies were excluded.
The nature of this topic required heavy reliance on observational studies. Studies included were of primary TKAs with a sample size of at least 100 and patient characteristics, baseline and follow-up symptom scale scores, revision rates, and perioperative complications occurring within six months of surgery. Data were extracted by trained assessors with a sample checked by an independent assessor.

Results: see full evidence report for details.

Citation: Prepared by the University of Minnesota Evidence-based Practice Center, Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA for the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. AHRQ Publication No. 04-E006-2, December 2003

Publication history information: Published on the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, USA website in December 2003.

Access:  Available to the general public.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Transmyocardial laser revascularization (TMR)
document.description: A clinical guideline with specific recommendations for the selection of patients for TMR
document.body:
Aims: A significant percentage of patients with chronic, severe angina cannot be completely revascularised using percutaneous catheter intervention (PCI) or coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) despite maximal medical therapy. Transmyocardial revascularisation (TMR) may be an appropriate form of therapy for some of these patients, either as sole therapy or in combination with CABG or PCI.

Recommendations: evidence and recommendations are presented for the following sections:

  • TMR as sole therapy
  • TMR as an adjunct to CABG
Intended audience:
The guidelines are designed to assist physicians and other health care providers in clinical decision-making by describing a range of generally acceptable approaches for disease management. They are not intended to be inclusive of all proper methods of care.

Methodology and development:
Medline, the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), and PubMed databases were searched up to 2002. Additional references were obtained through direct communication with investigators and selected manuscripts cited in the references were also reviewed. The evidence was classified following the format established in previous American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines for diagnostic and therapeutic procedures.

Implications for practice:
NOTE: Transmyocardial revascularisation is not used in many centres in the UK but is more widespread in the USA.

Publication history information:
Published in 2003 on the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (USA) website

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Unicompartmental knee arthroplasty for unicompartmental osteoarthritis of the knee
document.body:
Bottom–line conclusion:
The ASERNIP-S Review Group agreed on the following classifications and recommendations concerning the safety and efficacy of unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA):
Note: the evidence-base in this review was rated as average.
Safety: unicompartmental knee arthroplasty is considered at least as safe as total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and high tibial osteotomy (HTO).
Efficacy: in terms of function, UKA appears to be at least as efficacious as TKA and HTO.
In terms of knee survival, the efficacy of UKA compared to TKA and HTO can not be determined.
Recommendations: Current trials in progress should reduce some uncertainty surrounding the treatment of osteoarthritis in the knee. The continuing contribution of data to national joint registries will aid in validating the current trends, particularly in knee survival after unicompartmental or total knee arthroplasty.

Method:
Randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and non-randomised comparative studies assessing patients treated with UKA compared with either TKA or HTO were included for review. Efficacy outcomes included knee function and pain scores, range of motion, operative time, length of stay, knee failure and revision. Safety outcomes included complications such as deep vein thrombosis and infection.
Literature searches were conducted to April 2004 on MEDLINE, EMBASE, Cochrane Library and Current Contents together with searching of The Clinical Trials Database (US), NHS CRD, NHS HTA, National Research Register and Current Controlled Trials (mRCT) in May 2004. Additional articles were identified through the reference sections of the articles. Exclusion/Inclusion criteria were defined.
2 reviewers independently selected papers according to inclusion/exclusion criteria. Data was extracted and evidence graded according to the ASERNIP-S policy and checked by a second reviewer.

Results: See executive summary and full report ( 1.4 mb in size) for details

Citation: Prepared by the Australian Safety and Efficacy Register of New Interventional Procedures – Surgical (ASERNIP-S) June 2005

Publication history information: Published on the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons website in June 2005.

Note: there is also a patient/consumer version available.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.body:
UroSource is an educational resource aimed at urology professionals funded by the European Association of Urology (EAU). The editorial panel for the website are also responsible for the production of the EAU newsletter and also includes members of the EAU scientific journal team.
It features a digest (abstracts) of the literature for urology topics sorted into key articles, conference reports, meta-analyses, randomised controlled trials, guidelines and expert reviews.
Tables of 'Web of Science' most cited papers (2005 - present) by urology topic are also available.
There is also a video library, a database of conference abstracts, a calendar of international events and conference reports with video footage. 

Note: Videos and guidelines require Macromedia Flash

Access:  Available to the general public.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Utility of monitoring mycophenolic acid in solid organ transplant patients
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,URINARY TRACT,KIDNEY & URETER,LIVER & SPLEEN,HEART,THORAX,LIVER TRANSPLANTATION,HEART FAILURE,LUNG TRANSPLANTATION,HEART TRANSPLANTATION,LUNGS,KIDNEY TRANSPLANTATION]]>
document.body:
Aims and objectives: The report states three main objectives for this study:
  • "To investigate whether monitoring concentrations of mycophenolic acid (MPA) in the serum or plasma of persons who receive a solid organ transplant will result in a lower incidence of transplant rejections and adverse events versus no monitoring of MPA.
  • To investigate whether the incidence of rejection or adverse events differs according to MPA dose or frequency, type of MPA, the form of MPA monitored, the method of MPA monitoring, or sample characteristics.
  • To assess whether monitoring is cost-effective versus no monitoring".*

*from the structured abstract


Methods: The report states the key questions and describes the review methodology including the literature search strategy, selection criteria and screening, and quality assessment.


Results: The report describes the results of the literature search and the evidence relating to each of the key questions set out in the Methods chapter.


Discussion and Conclusions: The report discusses the evidence for each of the key questions. The overall conclusions state that the published evidence is inconclusive and:
"Until there is more evidence on the utility of routine MPA monitoring in solid organ transplant recipients, patients, clinicians, and other stakeholders (e.g., public and private insurers) will have to decide on a case by case basis whether the possible but uncertain benefits are worth the extra time and expense of monitoring".

Please note that conclusions on cost effectiveness are not necessarily applicable for the UK healthcare setting.


Citation: Oremus M, Zeidler J, Ensom MHH, Matsuda-Abedini M, Balion C, Booker L, Archer C, Raina P. Utility of monitoring mycophenolic acid in solid organ transplant patients. evidence report/technology assessment No. 164. (Prepared by the McMaster University Evidence-based Practice Center, under Contract No. 290-02-0020.) AHRQ Publication No.08-E006. Rockville, MD: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality; 2008. Available from: http://www.ahrq.gov/downloads/pub/evidence/pdf/mpa/mpaorgan.pdf


Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

    ]]>

Peer-reviewed comments are also posted about new alternative techniques.

Access: Available to the general public

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Virtual Anaesthesia Textbook
document.description: Aims to organise all internet resources on anaesthesia into one concise, textbook style website.
document.body:
The Virtual Anaesthesia Textbook is a collaborative project developed by a clinician based in Australia which aims to maintain a comprehensive set of links to internet-based anaesthesia resources organised into textbook style chapters.
It is supported by industry advertising on the proviso that no content can be influenced by sponsorship.
It can be searched or browsed by chapter headings including professional issues, anaesthetic equipment, patient care, basic sciences and specialist anaesthesia.

Please note that the chapter content is not peer reviewed and that some chapters are still under development.

Access: freely available

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: WeBSurg
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,ABDOMEN,BLOOD VESSELS & LYMPHATICS,URINARY TRACT,FEMALE REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS,MALE REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS,HEART,THORAX]]>
document.body:
WeBSurg is a ‘virtual surgical university’ produced by the European Institute of TeleSurgery (EITS) in Strasbourg, France.
It is a busy website that aims to offer online training resources and information on the latest developments in surgery to the surgical community. Features include videos, lectures, CME (continuing medical education), events and editorials. There is a strong focus on laparoscopic techniques and procedures. 
Please note that media software such as Windows Media Player, RealPlayer or QuickTime is required to download and view the videos.

Access: Freely available after registration.

 

]]>

document.title: What is the best treatment for hyperkalaemia in a preterm infant?
document.body:
Best Evidence Topics or BETs were developed in the Emergency Department of Manchester Royal Infirmary, UK, to provide rapid evidence-based answers to real-life clinical questions, using a systematic approach to reviewing the literature.

They are designed for use in Emergency Medicine, where many of the questions raised by the varied clinical workload are not addressed by high quality clinical trials. BETs allow the inclusion of lower quality evidence, by listing weaknesses of papers included for evaluation. The same rigorous approach to finding papers is taken. It should be noted, however, that BETs are not systematic reviews of the sort conducted by the Cochrane Collaboration, and therefore include only published evidence.

More information is available from the BestBETS website

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Who Operates When? II (2003)
document.publisher: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death (NCEPOD)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,THEATRE MANAGEMENT,ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS,EFFICIENCY,CLINICAL AUDIT,SURGERY,ANAESTHESIA,PERIOPERATIVE PRACTICE,STAFFING & SKILL MIX]]>
document.description: An update of the first "Who operates when?" report in 1997
document.body:
Aims: This report updates the first "Who operates when?" report in 1997.
Recommendations are summarised for each chapter:
  • Revise NCEPOD classification
  • Provide adequate information systems to record surgical and anaesthetic activity
  • Ensure that SHAs collaborate with NHS Trust to ensure emergency access to theatres
  • Ensure that all essential services (including IC and HDUs) are available on site
  • Look at elective surgery in extended hours in light of new junior doctor working hours
Intended audience: Clinicians and managers
Methodology: Trusts were asked to submit details of all operations undertaken over a 7 day period in 2002. The data were reviewed by a large multidisciplinary group of advisors. The group discussed the cases done out of hours, which operations truly needed to be done out of hours on clinical grounds, and which could be managed during the day time with better organisation.

Publication history information: Published on the NCEPOD website in 2003

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Why children die: a pilot study
document.publisher: Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health (CEMACH)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,OUTCOMES,ALL CAUSES OF MORBIDITY & MORTALITY,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,PUBLIC HEALTH,DETERMINANTS,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,PAEDIATRIC,CRITICAL CARE,CLINICAL TOPICS,MARCH 2010,ABUSE]]>
document.body:
Aims: The aim of this pilot study was to assess the feasibility of using the confi dential enquiry approach to investigate children’s deaths in the UK. It was anticipated that the study would also make a useful contribution to the health and safety of children. Wherever possible CEMACH has also sought to support and advise LSCBs through the production of interim reports relating to the progress of the study. Nevertheless this CEMACH project was not a ‘pilot’ for the processes to be implemented by LSCBs, particularly because it did not include review of neonatal deaths which are covered by the existing perinatal enquiry at CEMACH.

Objectives: The objectives of the CEMACH Child Death Review were:

  1. To identify all child deaths aged 28 days to 17 years 364 days in the selected regions during the calendar year 2006
  2. To collect a “core” dataset on all those deaths
  3. To conduct a detailed review, through multidisciplinary panel enquiry, of a subset of the deaths with a focus on identifying avoidable factors
  4. To inform the feasibility of conducting national confi dential enquiry work into child deaths.
In addition to the information provided at registration, a child death review should help understand child deaths, the social and environmental context, underlying medical conditions, and the complexity of contributing factors. CEMACH currently has a national core dataset and surveillance programme on the 40% of all child deaths that occur in the neonatal period (<28 completed days of age). This study did not collect data on this group to avoid duplication.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: Wound-healing technologies: low-level laser and vacuum-assisted closure
document.publisher: U.S. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SURGERY,SURGERY,BLOOD VESSELS & LYMPHATICS,SKIN,PERIPHERAL ARTERIAL DISEASE,DIABETIC FOOT,LEG ULCERATION,WOUND HEALING]]>
document.description: A review of low-level laser therapy or vacuum-assisted closure on wound-healing outcomes
document.body:
Bottom–line conclusion:
Evidence was limited by poor trial quality. Concerns included: randomisation adequacy, group comparability, use of complete healing as the primary endpoint, and small sample sizes.
Vacuum-assisted closure trials did not find a significant advantage for the intervention on the primary endpoint, complete healing, and did not consistently find significant differences on secondary endpoints and may have been insufficiently powered to detect differences. Ongoing RCT protocols may provide better evidence on outcomes of interest.
The best available trial did not show a higher probability of complete healing at 6 weeks with the addition of low-level laser compared to sham treatment.
Note: Laser treatment is less relevant to UK practice

Method: MEDLINE and EMBASE were searched to June 2004 and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register to December 2003. Primary published evidence was supplemented with recent meeting abstracts and clinical trial protocols.
Randomised controlled trials (RCTs) were included with explicit inclusion criteria stated on wound type for each intervention. Primary outcomes of interest were incidence of complete wound closure, time to complete closure, and adverse events.

Results: see full report for studies meeting inclusion criteria

Citation: Prepared by the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Evidence-based Practice Center, Chicago for the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. AHRQ Publication No. 05-E005-2, December 2004

Publication history information: Published on the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, USA website in December 2004.

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Surgery, Theatres & Anaesthesia]]>
document.title: WTD - Implications and Practical Suggestions to Achieve Compliance
document.publisher: Royal College of Anaesthetists (RCoA)/Royal College of Surgeons of England (RCS)
document.body:
Background: This report by the Royal College of Anaesthetists (RCoA) and the Royal College of Surgeons of England (RCS) is based on a research project in two distinct phases. The first phase aimed to describe how surgical and anaesthesia services are attempting to meet the requirements of the Working Time Directive 2009; the second phase involved the evaluation of the information received, and the formulation of appropriate advice and validated examples of good practice.  

Methodology: For details of the methodology employed in the project please refer to Appendix A of the report.

Intended Audience: Clinical Leads and Senior NHS Managers, Perioperative Practitioners 

Publication history information: Published on the RCS website on 20th November 2008  

Access:  Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader

]]>
